Text

In the days when the spinning - wheels hummed busily in [the farmhouses]166-the farmhouses — and even [great ladies , clothed in silk and thread - lace]167-great ladies , clothed in silk and thread - lace , had [their]167-great ladies , clothed in silk and thread - lace toy spinning - wheels of polished oak — there might be seen , in districts far away among [the lanes]168-the lanes , or deep in the bosom of [the hills]169-the hills , [certain pallid undersized men , who , by the side of [the brawny country - folk]171-the brawny country - folk]170-certain pallid undersized men , who , by the side of the brawny country - folk , looked like [the remnants of a disinherited race]172-the remnants of a disinherited race . [The shepherd]173-the shepherd 's dog barked fiercely when one of [these alien - looking men]174-these alien - looking men appeared on [the upland]175-the upland , dark against the early winter sunset ; for what dog likes [a figure bent under a heavy bag?—and these pale men]176-a figure bent under a heavy bag?—and these pale men rarely stirred [abroad]177-abroad without that mysterious burden . [The shepherd]173-the shepherd [himself]173-the shepherd , though [he]173-the shepherd had good reason to believe that the bag held nothing but flaxen thread , or else the long rolls of strong linen spun from that thread , was not quite sure that this trade of weaving , indispensable though it was , could be carried on entirely without the help of [the Evil One]179-the evil one . In that far - off time superstition clung easily round every person or thing that was at all unwonted , or even intermittent and occasional merely , like the visits of [the pedlar]180-the pedlar or [the knife - grinder]181-the knife - grinder . [No one]182-no one knew where [wandering men]183-wandering men had [[their]183-wandering men homes]184-their homes or [their]183-wandering men origin ; and how was [a man]185-a man to be explained unless [you]186-you at least knew [somebody who knew [[his]185-a man father and [mother]189-mother]188-his father and mother]187-somebody who knew his father and mother ? To [the peasants of old times]190-the peasants of old times , [the world outside [their]190-the peasants of old times own direct experience]191-the world outside their own direct experience was a region of vagueness and mystery : to [their]190-the peasants of old times untravelled thought a state of wandering was a conception as dim as the winter life of the swallows that came back with the spring ; and even [a settler]192-a settler , if [he]192-a settler came from [distant parts]193-distant parts , hardly ever ceased to be viewed with a remnant of distrust , which would have prevented any surprise if a long course of inoffensive conduct on [his]192-a settler part had ended in the commission of a crime ; especially if [he]192-a settler had any reputation for knowledge , or showed any skill in handicraft . All cleverness , whether in the rapid use of that difficult instrument the tongue , or in some other art unfamiliar to [villagers]194-villagers , was in itself suspicious : [honest folks , born and bred in a visible manner]195-honest folks , born and bred in a visible manner , were mostly not overwise or clever — at least , not beyond such a matter as knowing the signs of the weather ; and the process by which rapidity and dexterity of any kind were acquired was so wholly hidden , that [they]190-the peasants of old times partook of the nature of conjuring . In this way it came to pass that [those scattered linen - weavers]196-those scattered linen - weavers — emigrants from [the town]197-the town into [the country]198-the country — were to the last regarded as aliens by [[their]196-those scattered linen - weavers rustic neighbours]199-their rustic neighbours , and usually contracted the eccentric habits which belong to a state of loneliness . In the early years of this century , [such a linen - weaver]200-such a linen - weaver , named [Silas Marner]38-silas , worked at [his]38-silas vocation in [a stone cottage that stood among [the nutty hedgerows]202-the nutty hedgerows near [the village of Raveloe]203-the village of raveloe]201-a stone cottage that stood among the nutty hedgerows near the village of raveloe , and not far from [the edge of [a deserted stone - pit]205-a deserted stone - pit]204-the edge of a deserted stone - pit . The questionable sound of [Silas]38-silas 's loom , so unlike the natural cheerful trotting of the winnowing machine , or the simpler rhythm of the flail , had a half - fearful fascination for [the [Raveloe]1-raveloe boys , who would often leave off [their]207-their nutting or birds'-nesting to peep in at the window of [the stone cottage]208-the stone cottage , counterbalancing a certain awe at the mysterious action of the loom , by a pleasant sense of scornful superiority , drawn from the mockery of its alternating noises , along with the bent , tread - mill attitude of [the weaver]209-the weaver]206-the raveloe boys , who would often leave off their nutting or birds'-nesting to peep in at the window of the stone cottage , counterbalancing a certain awe at the mysterious action of the loom , by a pleasant sense of scornful superiority , drawn from the mockery of its alternating noises , along with the bent , tread - mill attitude of the weaver . But sometimes it happened that [Marner]38-silas , pausing to adjust an irregularity in [his]38-silas thread , became aware of [the small scoundrels]210-the small scoundrels , and , though chary of [his]38-silas time , [he]38-silas liked [their]210-the small scoundrels intrusion so ill that [he]38-silas would descend from [his]38-silas loom , and , opening the door , would fix on [them]210-the small scoundrels a gaze that was always enough to make [them]210-the small scoundrels take to [their]210-the small scoundrels legs in terror . For how was it possible to believe that those large brown protuberant eyes in [Silas Marner]38-silas 's pale face really saw nothing very distinctly that was not close to [them]210-the small scoundrels , and not rather that [their]210-the small scoundrels dreadful stare could dart cramp , or rickets , or a wry mouth at [any boy who happened to be in the rear]211-any boy who happened to be in the rear ? [They]210-the small scoundrels had , perhaps , heard [[their]210-the small scoundrels fathers]212-their fathers and [mothers]213-mothers hint that [Silas Marner]38-silas could cure [folks]214-folks ' rheumatism if [he]38-silas had a mind , and add , still more darkly , that if [you]215-you could only speak the devil fair enough , [he]38-silas might save [you]215-you the cost of [the doctor]216-the doctor . [Such strange lingering echoes of the old demon - worship]217-such strange lingering echoes of the old demon - worship might perhaps even now be caught by [the diligent listener]218-the diligent listener among [the grey - haired peasantry]219-the grey - haired peasantry ; for [the rude mind with difficulty]220-the rude mind with difficulty associates the idea of power and benignity . A shadowy conception of power that by much persuasion can be induced to refrain from inflicting harm , is the shape most easily taken by the sense of the Invisible in the minds of [men who have always been pressed close by primitive wants , and to whom a life of hard toil has never been illuminated by any enthusiastic religious faith]221-men who have always been pressed close by primitive wants , and to whom a life of hard toil has never been illuminated by any enthusiastic religious faith . To [them]210-the small scoundrels pain and mishap present a far wider range of possibilities than gladness and enjoyment : [their]210-the small scoundrels imagination is almost barren of the images that feed desire and hope , but is all overgrown by recollections that are a perpetual pasture to fear . " Is there anything [you]222-an old labouring man can fancy that [you]222-an old labouring man would like to eat ? "[0-i] [I]0-i once said to [an old labouring man]222-an old labouring man , who was in [his]222-an old labouring man last illness , and who had refused all the food [[his]222-an old labouring man wife]223-his wife had offered [him]222-an old labouring man . " No , "[222-an old labouring man] [he]222-an old labouring man answered , " [I]222-an old labouring man 've never been used to nothing but common victual , and [I]222-an old labouring man ca n't eat that . "[222-an old labouring man] [Experience]39-experience had bred no fancies in [him]222-an old labouring man that could raise the phantasm of appetite . And [Raveloe]1-raveloe was [a village where many of the old echoes lingered , undrowned by new voices]224-a village where many of the old echoes lingered , undrowned by new voices . Not that [it]1-raveloe was [one of [those barren parishes lying on the outskirts of civilisation — inhabited by meagre sheep and thinly - scattered [shepherds]227-shepherds]226-those barren parishes lying on the outskirts of civilisation — inhabited by meagre sheep and thinly - scattered shepherds]225-one of those barren parishes lying on the outskirts of civilisation — inhabited by meagre sheep and thinly - scattered shepherds : on the contrary , [it]1-raveloe lay in [the rich central plain of what [we]229-we are pleased to call [Merry England]2-merry england]228-the rich central plain of what we are pleased to call merry england , and held [farms which , speaking from a spiritual point of view , paid highly]230-farms which , speaking from a spiritual point of view , paid highly - desirable tithes . But [it]1-raveloe was nestled in [a snug well - wooded hollow]231-a snug well - wooded hollow , quite an hour 's journey on horseback from [any turnpike]232-any turnpike , where [it]1-raveloe was never reached by the vibrations of the coach - horn , or of public opinion . [It]1-raveloe was [an important - looking village]233-an important - looking village , with [a fine old church]234-a fine old church and [large churchyard in the heart of [it]1-raveloe]235-large churchyard in the heart of it , and [two or three large brick - and - stone homesteads , with well - walled orchards and ornamental weathercocks , standing close upon the road]236-two or three large brick - and - stone homesteads , with well - walled orchards and ornamental weathercocks , standing close upon the road , and lifting more imposing fronts than [the rectory]237-the rectory , which peeped from among the trees on the other side of the [churchyard;—a village which showed at once the summits of [its]1-raveloe social life , and told [the practised eye]239-the practised eye that there was [no great park and manor - house in [the vicinity]241-the vicinity]240-no great park and manor - house in the vicinity]238-churchyard;—a village which showed at once the summits of its social life , and told the practised eye that there was no great park and manor - house in the vicinity , but that there were [several chiefs in [Raveloe]1-raveloe]242-several chiefs in raveloe who could farm badly quite at [their]242-several chiefs in raveloe ease , drawing enough money from [their]242-several chiefs in raveloe bad farming , in those war times , to live in a rollicking fashion , and keep a jolly Christmas , Whitsun , and Easter tide . It was fifteen years since [Silas Marner]38-silas had first come to [Raveloe]1-raveloe ; [he]38-silas was then simply [a pallid young man]243-a pallid young man , with prominent , short - sighted brown eyes , whose appearance would have had nothing strange for [people of average culture and experience]244-people of average culture and experience , but for [the villagers near whom [he]38-silas had come to settle]245-the villagers near whom he had come to settle it had mysterious peculiarities which corresponded with the exceptional nature of [his]38-silas occupation , and [his]38-silas advent from [an unknown region called " [North'ard]3-north'ard]2043-an unknown region called " north'ard . "[38-silas] So had [his]38-silas way of life:—he invited [no comer]246-no comer to step across [his]38-silas door - sill , and [he]38-silas never strolled into [the village]247-the village to drink a pint at [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow , or to gossip at the wheel - wright 's : [he]38-silas sought [no man]248-no man or [woman]249-woman , save for the purposes of [his]38-silas calling , or in order to supply [himself]38-silas with necessaries ; and it was soon clear to [the Raveloe lasses]250-the raveloe lasses that [he]38-silas would never urge one of [them]250-the raveloe lasses to accept [him]38-silas against [her]250-the raveloe lasses will — quite as if [he]38-silas had heard [them]250-the raveloe lasses declare that [they]250-the raveloe lasses would never marry [a dead man]251-a dead man come to life again . This view of [Marner]38-silas 's personality was not without another ground than [his]38-silas pale face and unexampled eyes ; for [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney , [the mole - catcher]252-the mole - catcher , averred that , one evening as [he]40-jem rodney was returning [homeward]253-homeward , [he]40-jem rodney saw [Silas Marner]38-silas leaning against a stile with a heavy bag on [his]38-silas back , instead of resting the bag on the stile as [a man in [his]254-a man in his senses would have done senses would have done]254-a man in his senses would have done ; and that , on coming up to [him]38-silas , [he]40-jem rodney saw that [Marner]38-silas 's eyes were set like [a dead man]251-a dead man 's , and [he]38-silas spoke to [him]38-silas , and shook [him]38-silas , and [his]38-silas limbs were stiff , and [his]38-silas hands clutched the bag as if they 'd been made of iron ; but just as [he]38-silas had made up [his]38-silas mind that [the weaver]209-the weaver was dead , [he]38-silas came all right again , like , as [you]257-you might say , in the winking of an eye , and said " Good - night , "[38-silas] and walked off . All this [Jem]40-jem rodney swore [he]40-jem rodney had seen , more by token , that it was the very day [he]38-silas had been mole - catching on [[Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's land]258-squire cass 's land , down by [the old saw - pit]259-the old saw - pit . [Some]260-some said [Marner]38-silas must have been in a " fit , "[260-some] a word which seemed to explain things otherwise incredible ; but the argumentative [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , [clerk of [the parish]262-the parish]261-clerk of the parish , shook [his]41-mr macey head , and asked if [anybody]263-anybody was ever known to go off in a fit and not fall down . A fit was a stroke , was n't it ? and it was in the nature of a stroke to partly take away the use of [a man]185-a man 's limbs and throw [him]185-a man on [the parish]262-the parish , if [he]185-a man 'd got [no children]266-no children to look to . No , no ; it was no stroke that would let [a man]185-a man stand on [his]185-a man legs , like a horse between the shafts , and then walk off as soon as [you]268-you can say " Gee ! "[268-you] But there might be such a thing as [a man]185-a man 's soul being loose from [his]185-a man body , and going out an in , like a bird out of its nest and back ; and that was how [folks]214-folks got over - wise , for [they]214-folks went to school in this shell - less state to [those who could teach [them]214-folks more than [[their]214-folks neighbours]272-their neighbours could learn with [their]214-folks five senses and [the parson]273-the parson]271-those who could teach them more than their neighbours could learn with their five senses and the parson . And where did [Master Marner]42-master marner get [his]42-master marner knowledge of herbs from — and charms , too , if [he]42-master marner liked to give them away ? [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney 's story was no more than what might have been expected by [anybody who had seen how [Marner]38-silas had cured [Sally Oates]43-sally oates , and made [her]43-sally oates sleep like [a baby]275-a baby , when [her]43-sally oates heart had been beating enough to burst [her]43-sally oates body , for two months and more , while [she]43-sally oates had been under [the doctor]216-the doctor 's care]274-anybody who had seen how marner had cured sally oates , and made her sleep like a baby , when her heart had been beating enough to burst her body , for two months and more , while she had been under the doctor 's care . [He]38-silas might cure [more folks]277-more folks if [he]38-silas would ; but [he]38-silas was worth speaking fair , if it was only to keep [him]38-silas from doing [you]278-you a mischief . It was partly to this vague fear that [Marner]38-silas was indebted for protecting [him]38-silas from the persecution that [his]38-silas singularities might have drawn upon [him]38-silas , but still more to the fact that , [the old linen - weaver in [the neighbouring parish of [Tarley]6-tarley]280-the neighbouring parish of tarley]279-the old linen - weaver in the neighbouring parish of tarley being dead , [his]38-silas handicraft made [him]38-silas [a highly welcome settler to [the richer housewives of [the district]283-the district]282-the richer housewives of the district]281-a highly welcome settler to the richer housewives of the district , and even to [the more provident cottagers , who had [their]284-the more provident cottagers , who had their little stock of yarn at the year 's end little stock of yarn at the year 's end]284-the more provident cottagers , who had their little stock of yarn at the year 's end ; and [their]284-the more provident cottagers , who had their little stock of yarn at the year 's end sense of [his]38-silas usefulness would have counteracted any repugnance or suspicion which was not confirmed by a deficiency in the quality or the tale of the cloth [he]38-silas wove for [them]284-the more provident cottagers , who had their little stock of yarn at the year 's end . And the years had rolled on without producing any change in the impressions of [the neighbours]285-the neighbours concerning [Marner]38-silas , except the change from novelty to habit . At the end of fifteen years [the Raveloe men]286-the raveloe men said just the same things about [Silas Marner]38-silas as at the beginning : [they]286-the raveloe men did not say [them]286-the raveloe men quite so often , but [they]286-the raveloe men believed [them]286-the raveloe men much more strongly when [they]286-the raveloe men did say [them]286-the raveloe men . There was only one important addition which the years had brought : it was , that [Master Marner]42-master marner had laid by a fine sight of money somewhere , and that [he]42-master marner could buy up [" bigger men "[42-master marner] than [himself]42-master marner]2044-" bigger men " than himself . But while opinion concerning [him]38-silas had remained nearly stationary , and [his]38-silas daily habits had presented scarcely any visible change , [Marner]38-silas 's inward life had been a history and a metamorphosis , as that of every fervid nature must be when it has fled , or been condemned , to solitude . [His]38-silas life , before [he]38-silas came to [Raveloe]1-raveloe , had been filled with the movement , the mental activity , and the close fellowship , which , in that day as in this , marked the life of [an artisan]287-an artisan early incorporated in [a narrow religious sect , where [the poorest layman]289-the poorest layman has the chance of distinguishing [himself]289-the poorest layman by gifts of speech , and has , at the very least , the weight of a silent voter in the government of [[his]289-the poorest layman community]290-his community]288-a narrow religious sect , where the poorest layman has the chance of distinguishing himself by gifts of speech , and has , at the very least , the weight of a silent voter in the government of his community . [Marner]38-silas was highly thought of in [that little hidden world]291-that little hidden world , known to [itself]291-that little hidden world as [the church assembling in [Lantern Yard]7-lantern yard]292-the church assembling in lantern yard ; [he]38-silas was believed to be [a young man of exemplary life and ardent faith]293-a young man of exemplary life and ardent faith ; and a peculiar interest had been centred in [him]38-silas ever since [he]38-silas had fallen , at a prayer - meeting , into a mysterious rigidity and suspension of consciousness , which , lasting for an hour or more , had been mistaken for death . To have sought a medical explanation for this phenomenon would have been held by [Silas]38-silas [himself]38-silas , as well as by [[his]38-silas minister]294-his minister and [fellow - members]295-fellow - members , a wilful self - exclusion from the spiritual significance that might lie therein . [Silas]38-silas was evidently [a brother selected for a peculiar discipline]296-a brother selected for a peculiar discipline , and though the effort to interpret this discipline was discouraged by the absence , on [his]38-silas part , of any spiritual vision during [his]38-silas outward trance , yet it was believed by [himself]38-silas and [others]297-others that its effect was seen in an accession of light and fervour . [A less truthful man]298-a less truthful man than [he]38-silas might have been tempted into the subsequent creation of a vision in the form of resurgent memory ; [a less sane man]299-a less sane man might have believed in such a creation ; but [Silas]38-silas was both sane and honest , though , as with [many honest and fervent men]300-many honest and fervent men , culture had not defined any channels for [his]38-silas sense of mystery , and so it spread itself over the proper pathway of inquiry and knowledge . [He]38-silas had inherited from [[his]38-silas mother]301-his mother some acquaintance with medicinal herbs and [their]302-their preparation — a little store of wisdom which [she]301-his mother had imparted to [him]38-silas as a solemn bequest — but of late years [he]38-silas had had doubts about the lawfulness of applying this knowledge , believing that herbs could have no efficacy without prayer , and that prayer might suffice without herbs ; so that the inherited delight [he]38-silas had in wandering in [the fields]303-the fields in search of foxglove and dandelion and clotsfoot , began to wear to [him]38-silas the character of a temptation . Among [the members of [his]38-silas church]304-the members of his church there was [one young man , a little older than [himself]38-silas]305-one young man , a little older than himself , with whom [he]38-silas had long lived in such close friendship that it was the custom of [[their]306-their Lantern Yard brethren]307-their lantern yard brethren to call [them]306-their [David]44-david and [Jonathan]45-jonathan . The real name of [the friend]308-the friend was [William Dane]46-william , and [he]308-the friend , too , was regarded as a shining instance of youthful piety , though somewhat given to over - severity towards [weaker brethren]309-weaker brethren , and to be so dazzled by [his]308-the friend own light as to hold [himself]308-the friend wiser than [[his]308-the friend teachers]310-his teachers . But whatever blemishes [others]297-others might discern in [William]46-william , to [[his]38-silas friend]312-his friend 's mind [he]46-william was faultless ; for [Marner]38-silas had one of those impressible self - doubting natures which , at an inexperienced age , admire imperativeness and lean on contradiction . The expression of trusting simplicity in [Marner]38-silas 's face , heightened by that absence of special observation , that defenceless , deer - like gaze which belongs to large prominent eyes , was strongly contrasted by the self - complacent suppression of inward triumph that lurked in the narrow slanting eyes and compressed lips of [William Dane]46-william . One of the most frequent topics of conversation between [the two friends]313-the two friends was Assurance of salvation : [Silas]38-silas confessed that [he]38-silas could never arrive at anything higher than hope mingled with fear , and listened with longing wonder when [William]46-william declared that [he]46-william had possessed unshaken assurance ever since , in the period of [his]46-william conversion , [he]46-william had dreamed that [he]46-william saw the words " calling and election sure "[313-the two friends] standing by [themselves]313-the two friends on a white page in the open Bible . Such colloquies have occupied [many a pair of pale - faced weavers]314-many a pair of pale - faced weavers , whose unnurtured souls have been like young winged things , fluttering forsaken in the twilight . It had seemed to [the unsuspecting Silas]38-silas that the friendship had suffered no chill even from [his]38-silas formation of another attachment of a closer kind . For some months [he]38-silas had been engaged to [a young servant - woman]315-a young servant - woman , waiting only for a little increase to [their]313-the two friends mutual savings in order to [their]313-the two friends marriage ; and it was a great delight to [him]38-silas that [Sarah]43-sally oates did not object to [William]46-william 's occasional presence in [their]313-the two friends Sunday interviews . It was at this point in [their]313-the two friends history that [Silas]38-silas 's cataleptic fit occurred during the prayer - meeting ; and amidst the various queries and expressions of interest addressed to [him]38-silas by [[his]38-silas fellow - members]316-his fellow - members , [William]46-william 's suggestion alone jarred with the general sympathy towards [a brother thus singled out for special dealings]317-a brother thus singled out for special dealings . [He]38-silas observed that , to [him]38-silas , this trance looked more like a visitation of [Satan]47-satan than a proof of divine favour , and exhorted [[his]38-silas friend]312-his friend to see that [he]38-silas hid no accursed thing within [his]38-silas soul . [Silas]38-silas , feeling bound to accept rebuke and admonition as [a brotherly office]319-a brotherly office , felt no resentment , but only pain , at [[his]38-silas friend]312-his friend 's doubts concerning [him]38-silas ; and to this was soon added some anxiety at the perception that [Sarah]43-sally oates 's manner towards [him]38-silas began to exhibit a strange fluctuation between an effort at an increased manifestation of regard and involuntary signs of shrinking and dislike . [He]38-silas asked [her]43-sally oates if [she]43-sally oates wished to break off [their]321-their engagement ; but [she]43-sally oates denied this : [their]321-their engagement was known to [the church]322-the church , and had been recognised in the prayer - meetings ; it could not be broken off without strict investigation , and [Sarah]43-sally oates could render no reason that would be sanctioned by the feeling of [the community]323-the community . At this time [the senior deacon]324-the senior deacon was taken dangerously ill , and , being [a childless widower]325-a childless widower , [he]324-the senior deacon was tended night and day by [some of [the younger brethren]327-the younger brethren or [sisters]328-sisters]326-some of the younger brethren or sisters . [Silas]38-silas frequently took [his]38-silas turn in the night - watching with [William]46-william , the one relieving [the other]329-the other at two in the morning . [The old man]330-the old man , contrary to expectation , seemed to be on the way to recovery , when one night [Silas]38-silas , sitting up by [his]38-silas beside , observed that [his]38-silas usually audible breathing had ceased . The candle was burning low , and [he]38-silas had to lift it to see [the patient]331-the patient 's face distinctly . Examination convinced [him]38-silas that [the deacon]332-the deacon was dead — had been dead some time , for the limbs were rigid . [Silas]38-silas asked [himself]38-silas if [he]38-silas had been asleep , and looked at the clock : it was already four in the morning . How was it that [William]46-william had not come ? In much anxiety [he]38-silas went to seek for help , and soon there were [several friends]333-several friends assembled in [the house]334-the house , [the minister]335-the minister among [them]333-several friends , while [Silas]38-silas went away to [his]38-silas work , wishing [he]38-silas could have met [William]46-william to know the reason of [his]46-william non - appearance . But at six o'clock , as [he]38-silas was thinking of going to seek [[his]38-silas friend]312-his friend , [William]46-william came , and with [him]38-silas [the minister]335-the minister . [They]333-several friends came to summon [him]38-silas to [Lantern Yard]7-lantern yard , to meet [the church members there]338-the church members there ; and to [his]38-silas inquiry concerning the cause of the summons the only reply was , " [You]335-the minister will hear . "[333-several friends] Nothing further was said until [Silas]38-silas was seated in [the vestry]339-the vestry , in front of [the minister]335-the minister , with the eyes of [those who to [him]38-silas represented [[God]48-god 's people]342-god 's people]341-those who to him represented god 's people fixed solemnly upon [him]38-silas . Then [the minister]335-the minister , taking out a pocket - knife , showed it to [Silas]38-silas , and asked [him]38-silas if [he]38-silas knew where [he]38-silas had left that knife ? [Silas]38-silas said , [he]38-silas did not know that [he]38-silas had left it anywhere out of [his]38-silas own pocket — but [he]38-silas was trembling at this strange interrogation . [He]38-silas was then exhorted not to hide [his]38-silas sin , but to confess and repent . The knife had been found in the bureau by [the departed deacon]344-the departed deacon 's bedside — found in the place where the little bag of church money had lain , which [the minister]335-the minister [himself]335-the minister had seen the day before . Some hand had removed that bag ; and whose hand could it be , if not that of [the man to whom the knife]346-the man to whom the knife belonged ? For some time [Silas]38-silas was mute with astonishment : then [he]38-silas said , " [God]48-god will clear [me]38-silas : [I]38-silas know nothing about the knife being there , or the money being gone . Search [me]38-silas and [[my]38-silas dwelling]2045-my dwelling : [you]335-the minister will find nothing but three pound five of [my]38-silas own savings , which [William Dane]46-william knows [I]38-silas have had these six months . "[38-silas] At this [William]46-william groaned , but [the minister]335-the minister said , " The proof is heavy against [you]38-silas , [brother Marner]38-silas . The money was taken in the night last past , and [no man]248-no man was with [[our]2047-our departed brother]2048-our departed brother but [you]38-silas , for [William Dane]46-william declares to [us]2047-our that [he]46-william was hindered by sudden sickness from going to take [his]46-william place as usual , and [you]38-silas [yourself]38-silas said that [he]46-william had not come ; and , moreover , [you]38-silas neglected the dead body . "[335-the minister] " [I]38-silas must have slept , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas . Then , after a pause , [he]38-silas added , " Or [I]38-silas must have had another visitation like that which [you]38-silas have all seen [me]38-silas under , so that [the thief]2049-the thief must have come and gone while [I]38-silas was not in the body , but out of the body . But , [I]38-silas say again , search [me]38-silas and [[my]38-silas dwelling]2045-my dwelling , for [I]38-silas have been nowhere else . "[38-silas] The search was made , and it ended — in [William Dane]46-william 's finding the well - known bag , empty , tucked behind the chest of drawers in [[Silas]38-silas 's chamber]348-silas 's chamber ! On this [William]46-william exhorted [[his]46-william friend]312-his friend to confess , and not to hide [his]312-his friend sin any longer . [Silas]38-silas turned a look of keen reproach on [him]46-william , and said , " [William]46-william , for nine years that [we]2051-we have gone in and out together , have [you]46-william ever known [me]38-silas tell a lie ? But [God]48-god will clear [me]38-silas . "[38-silas] " [Brother]49-brother , "[46-william] said [William]46-william , " how do [I]46-william know what [you]49-brother may have done in [the secret chambers of [your]49-brother heart]2052-the secret chambers of your heart , to give [Satan]47-satan an advantage over [you]49-brother ? "[46-william] [Silas]38-silas was still looking at [[his]38-silas friend]312-his friend . Suddenly a deep flush came over [his]38-silas face , and [he]38-silas was about to speak impetuously , when [he]38-silas seemed checked again by some inward shock , that sent the flush back and made [him]38-silas tremble . But at last [he]38-silas spoke feebly , looking at [William]46-william . " [I]46-william remember now — the knife was n't in [my]46-william pocket . "[46-william] [William]46-william said , " [I]46-william know nothing of what [you]38-silas mean . "[46-william] [The other persons present]351-the other persons present , however , began to inquire where [Silas]38-silas meant to say that the knife was , but [he]38-silas would give no further explanation : [he]38-silas only said , " [I]38-silas am sore stricken ; [I]38-silas can say nothing . [God]48-god will clear [me]38-silas . "[38-silas] On [their]351-the other persons present return to [the vestry]339-the vestry there was further deliberation . Any resort to legal measures for ascertaining [the culprit]353-the culprit was contrary to the principles of [the Church]8-the church : prosecution was held by [them]351-the other persons present to be forbidden to [Christians]354-christians , even if it had been a case in which there was no scandal to [the community]323-the community . But [they]351-the other persons present were bound to take other measures for finding out the truth , and [they]351-the other persons present resolved on praying and drawing lots . This resolution can be a ground of surprise only to [those who are unacquainted with that obscure religious life]356-those who are unacquainted with that obscure religious life which has gone on in [the alleys of [[our]358-our towns]359-our towns]357-the alleys of our towns . [Silas]38-silas knelt with [[his]38-silas brethren]360-his brethren , relying on [his]38-silas own innocence being certified by immediate divine interference , but feeling that there was sorrow and mourning behind for [him]38-silas even then — that [his]38-silas trust in [man]361-man had been cruelly bruised . [The lots]362-the lots declared that [Silas Marner]38-silas was guilty . [He]38-silas was solemnly suspended from [church]363-church - membership , and called upon to render up the stolen money : only on confession , as the sign of repentance , could [he]38-silas be received once more within the fold of [the church]322-the church . [Marner]38-silas listened in silence . At last , when [every one]365-every one rose to depart , [he]38-silas went towards [William Dane]46-william and said , in a voice shaken by agitation — " The last time [I]38-silas remember using [my]38-silas knife , was when [I]38-silas took it out to cut a strap for [you]46-william . [I]38-silas do n't remember putting it in [my]38-silas pocket again . [You]46-william stole the money , and [you]46-william have woven a plot to lay the sin at [my]38-silas door . But [you]46-william may prosper , for all that : there is no just [God]48-god that governs [the earth]2053-the earth righteously , but [a God of lies , that bears witness against the innocent]2054-a god of lies , that bears witness against the innocent . "[38-silas] There was a general shudder at this blasphemy . [William]46-william said meekly , " [I]46-william leave [[our]2055-our brethren]2056-our brethren to judge whether this is the voice of [Satan]47-satan or not . [I]46-william can do nothing but pray for [you]50-poor marner , [Silas]38-silas . "[46-william] [Poor Marner]50-poor marner went out with that despair in [his]50-poor marner soul — that shaken trust in [God]48-god and [man]361-man , which is little short of madness to a loving nature . In the bitterness of [his]50-poor marner wounded spirit , [he]50-poor marner said to [himself]50-poor marner , " [She]367-she will cast [me]50-poor marner off too . "[50-poor marner] And [he]50-poor marner reflected that , if [she]367-she did not believe the testimony against [him]50-poor marner , [her]367-she whole faith must be upset , as [his]50-poor marner was . To people accustomed to reason about the forms in which [their]368-their religious feeling has incorporated itself , it is difficult to enter into that simple , untaught state of mind in which the form and the feeling have never been severed by an act of reflection . [We]369-we are apt to think it inevitable that [a man]185-a man in [Marner]38-silas 's position should have begun to question the validity of an appeal to the divine judgment by drawing lots ; but to [him]38-silas this would have been an effort of independent thought such as [he]38-silas had never known ; and [he]38-silas must have made the effort at a moment when all [his]38-silas energies were turned into the anguish of disappointed faith . If there is [an angel who records the sorrows of]371-an angel who records the sorrows of [men]372-men as well as [their]372-men sins , [he]371-an angel who records the sorrows of knows how many and deep are the sorrows that spring from false ideas for which [no man]248-no man is culpable . [Marner]38-silas went [home]374-home , and for a whole day sat alone , stunned by despair , without any impulse to go to [Sarah]43-sally oates and attempt to win [her]43-sally oates belief in [his]50-poor marner innocence . The second day [he]38-silas took refuge from benumbing unbelief , by getting into [his]38-silas loom and working away as usual ; and before many hours were past , [the minister]335-the minister and [one of [the deacons]377-the deacons]376-one of the deacons came to [him]38-silas with the message from [Sarah]43-sally oates , that [she]43-sally oates held [her]43-sally oates engagement to [him]38-silas at an end . [Silas]38-silas received the message mutely , and then turned away from [the messengers]378-the messengers to work at [his]38-silas loom again . In little more than a month from that time , [Sarah]43-sally oates was married to [William Dane]46-william ; and not long afterwards it was known to [the brethren in [Lantern Yard]7-lantern yard]379-the brethren in lantern yard that [Silas Marner]38-silas had departed from [the town]197-the town . Even [people whose lives have been made various by learning]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning , sometimes find it hard to keep a fast hold on [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning habitual views of life , on [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning faith in the Invisible — nay , on the sense that [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning past joys and sorrows are a real experience , when [they]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning are suddenly transported to [a new land]382-a new land , where [the beings around [them]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning]383-the beings around them know nothing of [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning history , and share none of [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning ideas — where [[their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning mother earth]384-their mother earth shows another lap , and human life has other forms than those on which [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning souls have been nourished . Minds that have been unhinged from [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning old faith and love , have perhaps sought this Lethean influence of exile , in which the past becomes dreamy because its symbols have all vanished , and the present too is dreamy because it is linked with no memories . But even [their]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning experience may hardly enable [them]381-people whose lives have been made various by learning thoroughly to imagine what was the effect on [a simple weaver like [Silas Marner]38-silas]385-a simple weaver like silas marner , when [he]38-silas left [[his]38-silas own country]386-his own country and [people]387-people and came to settle in [Raveloe]1-raveloe . Nothing could be more unlike [[his]38-silas native town , set within sight of [the wide - spread hill - sides]389-the wide - spread hill - sides than [this low , wooded region]390-this low , wooded region , where [he]38-silas felt hidden even from the heavens]388-his native town , set within sight of the wide - spread hill - sides than this low , wooded region , where he felt hidden even from the heavens by the screening trees and hedgerows . There was nothing here , when [he]38-silas rose in [the deep morning quiet]391-the deep morning quiet and looked out on the dewy brambles and rank tufted grass , that seemed to have any relation with that life centering in [Lantern Yard]7-lantern yard , which had once been to [him]38-silas the altar - place of high dispensations . The white - washed walls ; the little pews where [well - known figures]392-well - known figures entered with a subdued rustling , and where first one well - known voice and then another , pitched in a peculiar key of petition , uttered phrases at once occult and familiar , like the amulet worn on the heart ; [the pulpit where [the minister delivered unquestioned doctrine , and swayed to and fro]394-the minister delivered unquestioned doctrine , and swayed to and fro , and handled the book in a long - accustomed manner]393-the pulpit where the minister delivered unquestioned doctrine , and swayed to and fro , and handled the book in a long - accustomed manner ; the very pauses between the couplets of the hymn , as it was given out , and the recurrent swell of voices in song : these things had been the channel of divine influences to [Marner]38-silas — they were [the fostering home of [his]38-silas religious emotions]395-the fostering home of his religious emotions — they were Christianity and [[God]48-god 's kingdom upon [earth]397-earth]396-god 's kingdom upon earth . [A weaver who finds hard words in [his]38-silas hymn - book]398-a weaver who finds hard words in his hymn - book knows nothing of abstractions ; as [the little child]399-the little child knows nothing of parental love , but only knows one face and one lap towards which it stretches its arms for refuge and nurture . And what could be more unlike [that Lantern Yard world]400-that lantern yard world than [the world in [Raveloe]1-raveloe]401-the world in raveloe ? — orchards looking lazy with neglected plenty ; [the large church in [the wide churchyard]403-the wide churchyard , which [men]372-men gazed at lounging at [their]372-men own doors in service - time]402-the large church in the wide churchyard , which men gazed at lounging at their own doors in service - time ; the purple - faced farmers jogging along [the lanes]168-the lanes or turning in at the Rainbow ; [[homesteads]406-homesteads , where [men]372-men supped heavily and slept in the light of the evening hearth]407-homesteads , where men supped heavily and slept in the light of the evening hearth , and where [women]409-women seemed to be laying up a stock of linen for the life to come . There were no lips in [Raveloe]1-raveloe from which a word could fall that would stir [Silas Marner]38-silas 's benumbed faith to a sense of pain . In the early ages of [the world]410-the world , [we]411-we know , it was believed that [each territory]412-each territory was inhabited and ruled by [its]412-each territory own divinities , so that [a man]185-a man could cross [the bordering heights]414-the bordering heights and be out of the reach of [[his]185-a man native gods , whose presence was confined to [the streams]416-the streams and [the groves]417-the groves and [the hills among which [he]185-a man had lived from [his]185-a man birth]418-the hills among which he had lived from his birth]415-his native gods , whose presence was confined to the streams and the groves and the hills among which he had lived from his birth . And poor [Silas]38-silas was vaguely conscious of something not unlike the feeling of [primitive men]419-primitive men , when [they]419-primitive men fled thus , in fear or in sullenness , from the face of [an unpropitious deity]420-an unpropitious deity . It seemed to [him]38-silas that the Power in which [he]38-silas had vainly trusted among [the streets]421-the streets and in the prayer - meetings , was very far away from [this land in which [he]38-silas had taken refuge , where [men]372-men lived in careless abundance , knowing and needing nothing of that trust , which , for [him]38-silas , had been turned to bitterness]422-this land in which he had taken refuge , where men lived in careless abundance , knowing and needing nothing of that trust , which , for him , had been turned to bitterness . The little light [he]38-silas possessed spread its beams so narrowly , that frustrated belief was a curtain broad enough to create for [him]38-silas the blackness of night . [His]38-silas first movement after the shock had been to work in [[his]38-silas loom]424-his loom ; and [he]38-silas went on with this unremittingly , never asking [himself]38-silas why , now [he]38-silas was come to [Raveloe]1-raveloe , [he]38-silas worked far on into the night to finish the tale of [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's table - linen sooner than [she]52-mrs osgood expected — without contemplating beforehand the money [she]52-mrs osgood would put into [his]38-silas hand for the work . [He]38-silas seemed to weave , like the spider , from pure impulse , without reflection . [Every man]425-every man 's work , pursued steadily , tends in this way to become an end in itself , and so to bridge over the loveless chasms of [his]425-every man life . [Silas]38-silas 's hand satisfied itself with throwing the shuttle , and [his]38-silas eye with seeing the little squares in the cloth complete themselves under [his]38-silas effort . Then there were the calls of hunger ; and [Silas]38-silas , in [his]38-silas solitude , had to provide [his]38-silas own breakfast , dinner , and supper , to fetch [his]38-silas own water from the well , and put [his]38-silas own kettle on the fire ; and all these immediate promptings helped , along with the weaving , to reduce [his]38-silas life to the unquestioning activity of a spinning insect . [He]38-silas hated the thought of the past ; there was nothing that called out [his]38-silas love and fellowship toward [the strangers [he]38-silas had come amongst]426-the strangers he had come amongst ; and the future was all dark , for there was no Unseen Love that cared for [him]38-silas . [Thought]53-thought was arrested by utter bewilderment , now [its]53-thought old narrow pathway was closed , and affection seemed to have died under the bruise that had fallen on its keenest nerves . But at last [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's table - linen was finished , and [Silas]38-silas was paid in gold . [His]38-silas earnings in [[his]38-silas native town]427-his native town , where [he]38-silas worked for [a wholesale dealer]428-a wholesale dealer , had been after a lower rate ; [he]38-silas had been paid weekly , and of [his]38-silas weekly earnings a large proportion had gone to objects of piety and charity . Now , for the first time in [his]38-silas life , [he]38-silas had five bright guineas put into [his]38-silas hand ; [no man]248-no man expected a share of them , and [he]38-silas loved [no man]248-no man that [he]38-silas should offer [him]38-silas a share . But what were the guineas to [him]38-silas who saw [no vista beyond countless days of weaving]431-no vista beyond countless days of weaving ? It was needless for [him]38-silas to ask that , for it was pleasant to [him]38-silas to feel them in [his]38-silas palm , and look at [their]432-their bright faces , which were all [his]38-silas own : it was another element of life , like the weaving and the satisfaction of hunger , subsisting quite aloof from the life of belief and love from which [he]38-silas had been cut off . [The weaver]209-the weaver 's hand had known the touch of hard - won money even before the palm had grown to its full breadth ; for twenty years , mysterious money had stood to [him]38-silas as the symbol of earthly good , and the immediate object of toil . [He]38-silas had seemed to love it little in the years when every penny had its purpose for [him]38-silas ; for [he]38-silas loved the purpose then . But now , when all purpose was gone , that habit of looking towards the money and grasping it with a sense of fulfilled effort made a loam that was deep enough for the seeds of desire ; and as [Silas]38-silas walked homeward across [the fields]303-the fields in the twilight , [he]38-silas drew out the money , and thought it was brighter in the gathering gloom . About this time an incident happened which seemed to open a possibility of some fellowship with [[his]38-silas neighbours]435-his neighbours . One day , taking a pair of shoes to be mended , [he]38-silas saw [[the cobbler]436-the cobbler 's wife]437-the cobbler 's wife seated by the fire , suffering from the terrible symptoms of heart - disease and dropsy , which [he]38-silas had witnessed as the precursors of [[his]38-silas mother]301-his mother 's death . [He]38-silas felt a rush of pity at the mingled sight and remembrance , and , recalling the relief [[his]38-silas mother]301-his mother had found from a simple preparation of foxglove , [he]38-silas promised [Sally Oates]43-sally oates to bring [her]43-sally oates something that would case [her]43-sally oates , since [the doctor]216-the doctor did [her]43-sally oates no good . In [this office of charity]441-this office of charity , [Silas]38-silas felt , for the first time since [he]38-silas had come to [Raveloe]1-raveloe , a sense of unity between [his]38-silas past and present life , which might have been the beginning of [his]38-silas rescue from the insect - like existence into which [his]38-silas nature had shrunk . But [Sally Oates]43-sally oates 's disease had raised [her]43-sally oates into a personage of much interest and importance among [the neighbours]285-the neighbours , and the fact of [her]43-sally oates having found relief from drinking [Silas Marner]38-silas 's " stuff "[38-silas] became a matter of general discourse . When [Doctor Kimble]54-kimble gave physic , it was natural that it should have an effect ; but when [a weaver]443-a weaver , who came from [nobody]444-nobody knew where , worked wonders with a bottle of brown waters , the occult character of the process was evident . Such a sort of thing had not been known since [the Wise Woman at]445-the wise woman at [Tarley]6-tarley died ; and [she]445-the wise woman at had charms as well as " stuff : "[445-the wise woman at] [everybody]446-everybody went to [her]445-the wise woman at when [[their]446-everybody children]447-their children had fits . [Silas Marner]38-silas must be [a person of the same sort]448-a person of the same sort , for how did [he]38-silas know what would bring back [Sally Oates]43-sally oates 's breath , if [he]38-silas did n't know a fine sight more than that ? [The Wise Woman]449-the wise woman had words that [she]449-the wise woman muttered to [herself]449-the wise woman , so that [you]450-you could n't hear what they were , and if [she]449-the wise woman tied a bit of red thread round [the child]451-the child 's toe the while , it would keep off the water in the head . There were [women in [Raveloe]1-raveloe]452-women in raveloe , at that present time , who had worn one of [the Wise Woman]449-the wise woman 's little bags round [their]452-women in raveloe necks , and , in consequence , had never had [an idiot child]454-an idiot child , as [Ann Coulter]55-ann coulter had . [Silas Marner]38-silas could very likely do as much , and more ; and now it was all clear how [he]38-silas should have come from unknown parts , and be so " comical - looking . "[38-silas] But [Sally Oates]43-sally oates must mind and not tell [the doctor]216-the doctor , for [he]216-the doctor would be sure to set [his]216-the doctor face against [Marner]38-silas : [he]216-the doctor was always angry about [the Wise Woman]449-the wise woman , and used to threaten those who went to [her]449-the wise woman that [they]457-they should have none of [his]216-the doctor help any more . [Silas]38-silas now found [himself]38-silas and [[his]38-silas cottage]458-his cottage suddenly beset by mothers who wanted [him]38-silas to charm away the hooping - cough , or bring back the milk , and by [men who wanted stuff against the rheumatics or the knots in the hands]459-men who wanted stuff against the rheumatics or the knots in the hands ; and , to secure [themselves]457-they against a refusal , [the applicants]460-the applicants brought silver in [their]457-they palms . [Silas]38-silas might have driven a profitable trade in charms as well as in [his]38-silas small list of drugs ; but money on this condition was no temptation to [him]38-silas : [he]38-silas had never known an impulse towards falsity , and [he]38-silas drove one after another away with growing irritation , for the news of [him]38-silas as [a wise man]461-a wise man had spread even to [Tarley]6-tarley , and it was long before [people]387-people ceased to take long walks for the sake of asking [his]38-silas aid . But the hope in [his]38-silas wisdom was at length changed into dread , for [no one]182-no one believed [him]38-silas when [he]38-silas said [he]38-silas knew no charms and could work no cures , and [every man and woman who had an accident or a new attack]464-every man and woman who had an accident or a new attack after applying to [him]38-silas , set the misfortune down to [Master Marner]42-master marner 's ill - will and irritated glances . Thus it came to pass that [his]38-silas movement of pity towards [Sally Oates]43-sally oates , which had given [him]38-silas a transient sense of brotherhood , heightened the repulsion between [him]38-silas and [[his]38-silas neighbours]435-his neighbours , and made [his]38-silas isolation more complete . Gradually the guineas , the crowns , and the half - crowns , grew to a heap , and [Marner]38-silas drew less and less for [his]38-silas own wants , trying to solve the problem of keeping [himself]38-silas strong enough to work sixteen hours a - day on as small an outlay as possible . Have not [men]372-men , shut up in solitary imprisonment , found an interest in marking the moments by straight strokes of a certain length on the wall , until the growth of the sum of straight strokes , arranged in triangles , has become a mastering purpose ? Do [we]467-we not wile away moments of inanity or fatigued waiting by repeating some trivial movement or sound , until the repetition has bred a want , which is incipient habit ? That will help [us]467-we to understand how the love of accumulating money grows an absorbing passion in [men whose imaginations]468-men whose imaginations , even in the very beginning of [their]468-men whose imaginations hoard , showed [them]468-men whose imaginations no purpose beyond it . [Marner]38-silas wanted the heaps of ten to grow into a square , and then into [a larger square]469-a larger square ; and every added guinea , while it was itself a satisfaction , bred a new desire . In [this strange world]470-this strange world , made a hopeless riddle to [him]38-silas , [he]38-silas might , if [he]38-silas had had a less intense nature , have sat weaving , weaving — looking towards the end of [his]38-silas pattern , or towards the end of [his]38-silas web , till [he]38-silas forgot the riddle , and everything else but [his]38-silas immediate sensations ; but the money had come to mark off [his]38-silas weaving into periods , and the money not only grew , but it remained with [him]38-silas . [He]38-silas began to think it was conscious of [him]38-silas , as [his]38-silas loom was , and [he]38-silas would on no account have exchanged those coins , which had become [his]38-silas familiars , for other coins with unknown faces . [He]38-silas handled them , [he]38-silas counted them , till their form and colour were like the satisfaction of a thirst to [him]38-silas ; but it was only in the night , when [his]38-silas work was done , that [he]38-silas drew [them]471-them out to enjoy [their]471-them companionship . [He]38-silas had taken up some bricks in [his]38-silas floor underneath [his]38-silas loom , and here [he]38-silas had made a hole in which [he]38-silas set the iron pot that contained [his]38-silas guineas and silver coins , covering the bricks with sand whenever [he]38-silas replaced them . Not that the idea of being robbed presented itself often or strongly to [his]38-silas mind : hoarding was common in country districts in those days ; there were [old labourers in [the parish of [Raveloe]1-raveloe]473-the parish of raveloe who were known to have [their]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds savings by [them]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds , probably inside [[their]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds flock - beds]474-their flock - beds]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds ; but [[their]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds rustic neighbours]199-their rustic neighbours , though [not all of [them]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds as honest as [[their]472-old labourers in the parish of raveloe who were known to have their savings by them , probably inside their flock - beds ancestors in the days of [King Alfred]57-king alfred]477-their ancestors in the days of king alfred]476-not all of them as honest as their ancestors in the days of king alfred , had not imaginations bold enough to lay a plan of burglary . How could [they]199-their rustic neighbours have spent the money in [[their]199-their rustic neighbours [own village]479-own village]478-their own village without betraying [themselves]199-their rustic neighbours ? [They]199-their rustic neighbours would be obliged to " run away "[199-their rustic neighbours] — a course as dark and dubious as a balloon journey . So , year after year , [Silas Marner]38-silas had lived in [this solitude]480-this solitude , [his]38-silas guineas rising in the iron pot , and [his]38-silas life narrowing and hardening itself more and more into a mere pulsation of desire and satisfaction that had no relation to any other being . [His]38-silas life had reduced itself to the mere functions of weaving and hoarding , without any contemplation of an end towards which the functions tended . The same sort of process has perhaps been undergone by [wiser men]481-wiser men , when [they]481-wiser men have been cut off from faith and love — only , instead of a loom and a heap of guineas , [they]481-wiser men have had some erudite research , some ingenious project , or some wellknit theory . [Strangely Marner]38-silas 's face and figure shrank and bent themselves into a constant mechanical relation to the objects of [his]38-silas life , so that [he]38-silas produced the same sort of impression as a handle or a crooked tube , which has no meaning standing apart . The prominent eyes that used to look trusting and dreamy , now looked as if [they]199-their rustic neighbours had been made to see only one kind of thing that was very small , like tiny grain , for which [they]199-their rustic neighbours hunted everywhere : and [he]38-silas was so withered and yellow , that , though [he]38-silas was not yet forty , [the children]482-the children always called [him]38-silas " [Old Master Marner]42-master marner . "[38-silas] Yet even in this stage of withering a little incident happened , which showed that the sap of affection was not all gone . It was one of [his]38-silas daily tasks to fetch [his]38-silas water from a well a couple of fields off , and for this purpose , ever since [he]38-silas came to [Raveloe]1-raveloe , [he]38-silas had had a brown earthenware pot , which [he]38-silas held as [his]38-silas most precious utensil , among the very few conveniences [he]38-silas had granted [himself]38-silas . [It]483-it had been [[his]38-silas companion]484-his companion for twelve years , always standing on the same spot , always lending its handle to [him]38-silas in the early morning , so that its form had an expression for [him]38-silas of willing helpfulness , and the impress of its handle on [his]38-silas palm gave a satisfaction mingled with that of having the fresh clear water . One day as [he]38-silas was returning from [the well]485-the well , [he]38-silas stumbled against the step of the stile , and [his]38-silas brown pot , falling with force against the stones that overarched [the ditch below [him]38-silas]486-the ditch below him , was broken in three pieces . [Silas]38-silas picked up the pieces and carried them [home]374-home with grief in [his]38-silas heart . The brown pot could never be of use to [him]38-silas any more , but [he]38-silas stuck the bits together and propped the ruin in [its]488-its old place for a memorial . This is the history of [Silas Marner]38-silas until the fifteenth year after [he]38-silas came to [Raveloe]1-raveloe . The livelong day [he]38-silas sat in [[his]38-silas loom]424-his loom , [his]38-silas ear filled with its monotony , [his]38-silas eyes bent close down on the slow growth of sameness in the brownish web , [his]38-silas muscles moving with such even repetition that their pause seemed almost as much a constraint as the holding of [his]38-silas breath . But at night came [his]38-silas revelry : at night [he]38-silas closed [his]38-silas shutters , and made fast [his]38-silas doors , and drew out [his]38-silas gold . Long ago the heap of coins had become too large for the iron pot to hold them , and [he]38-silas had made for [them]490-them two thick leather bags , which wasted no room in [their]490-them resting - place , but lent themselves flexibly to every corner . How the guineas shone as they came pouring out of the dark leather mouths ! The silver bore no large proportion in amount to the gold , because the long pieces of linen which formed [his]38-silas chief work were always partly paid for in gold , and out of the silver [he]38-silas supplied [his]38-silas own bodily wants , choosing always the shillings and sixpences to spend in this way . [He]38-silas loved the guineas best , but [he]38-silas would not change the silver — the crowns and half - crowns that were [his]38-silas own earnings , begotten by [his]38-silas labour ; [he]38-silas loved them all . [He]38-silas spread them out in heaps and bathed [his]38-silas hands in them ; then [he]38-silas counted them and set them up in regular piles , and felt their rounded outline between [his]38-silas thumb and fingers , and thought fondly of the guineas that were only half - earned by the work in [[his]38-silas loom]424-his loom , as if [they]492-they had been [unborn children]493-unborn children — thought of the guineas that were coming slowly through the coming years , through all [his]38-silas life , which spread far away before [him]38-silas , the end quite hidden by countless days of weaving . No wonder [his]38-silas thoughts were still with [his]38-silas loom and [his]38-silas money when [he]38-silas made [his]38-silas journeys through [the fields]303-the fields and [the lanes]168-the lanes to fetch and carry [home]374-home [his]38-silas work , so that [his]38-silas steps never wandered to the hedge - banks and [the lane - side]497-the lane - side in search of the once familiar herbs : these too belonged to the past , from which [his]38-silas life had shrunk away , like a rivulet that has sunk far down from [the grassy fringe of]498-the grassy fringe of [its]499-its old breadth into a little shivering thread , that cuts a groove for itself in the barren sand . But about the Christmas of that fifteenth year , a second great change came over [Marner]38-silas 's life , and [his]38-silas history became blent in a singular manner with the life of [[his]38-silas neighbours]435-his neighbours . [The greatest man in [Raveloe]1-raveloe]501-the greatest man in raveloe was [Squire Cass]58-squire cass , who lived in [the large red house]502-the large red house , with the handsome flight of stone steps in front and [the high stables behind [it]502-the large red house , nearly opposite [the church]322-the church]503-the high stables behind it , nearly opposite the church . [He]58-squire cass was only one among [several landed parishioners]505-several landed parishioners , but [he]58-squire cass alone was honoured with the title of [Squire]506-squire ; for though [[Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood 's family]507-mr osgood 's family was also understood to be of timeless origin — [the Raveloe]1-raveloe imagination having never ventured back to that fearful blank when there were no [Osgoods]60-osgoods — still , [he]58-squire cass merely owned [the farm [he]58-squire cass occupied]508-the farm he occupied ; whereas [Squire Cass]58-squire cass had [a tenant]509-a tenant or two , who complained of the game to [him]58-squire cass quite as if [he]58-squire cass had been [a lord]510-a lord . It was still that glorious war - time which was felt to be a peculiar favour of [Providence]61-providence towards the landed interest , and the fall of prices had not yet come to carry the race of [small squires]511-small squires and yeomen down [that road]512-that road to ruin for which extravagant habits and bad husbandry were plentifully anointing [their]511-small squires wheels . [I]0-i am speaking now in relation to [Raveloe]1-raveloe and [the parishes that resembled]513-the parishes that resembled [it]1-raveloe ; for [our]514-our old - fashioned country life had many different aspects , as all life must have when it is spread over a various surface , and breathed on variously by multitudinous currents , from the winds of heaven to the thoughts of [men]372-men , which are for ever moving and crossing each other , with incalculable results . [Raveloe]1-raveloe lay low among the bushy trees and [the rutted lanes]516-the rutted lanes , aloof from the currents of industrial energy and Puritan earnestness : [the rich]517-the rich ate and drank freely , and accepted gout and apoplexy as things that ran mysteriously in [respectable families]518-respectable families , and [the poor]519-the poor thought that [the rich]517-the rich were entirely in the right of it to lead a jolly life ; besides , [their]517-the rich feasting caused a multiplication of orts , which were the heir - looms of [the poor]519-the poor . [Betty Jay]62-betty jay scented the boiling of [Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's hams , but [her]62-betty jay longing was arrested by the unctuous liquor in which they were boiled ; and when the seasons brought round the great merrymakings , they were regarded on all hands as a fine thing for [the poor]519-the poor . For the Raveloe feasts were like the rounds of beef and the barrels of ale — they were on a large scale , and lasted a good while , especially in the winter - time . When [ladies]523-ladies had packed up [their]523-ladies best gowns and top - knots in bandboxes , and had incurred the risk of fording streams on pillions with the precious burden in rainy or snowy weather , when there was no knowing how high the water would rise , it was not to be supposed that [they]523-ladies looked forward to a brief pleasure . On this ground it was always contrived in the dark seasons , when there was little work to be done , and the hours were long , that [several neighbours]524-several neighbours should keep [open house]525-open house in succession . When [Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's standing dishes diminished in plenty and freshness , [[his]58-squire cass guests]526-his guests had nothing to do but to walk a little higher up [the village]247-the village to [[Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood 's]528-mr osgood 's , at [the Orchards]529-the orchards , and [they]526-his guests found hams and chines uncut , porkpies with the scent of the fire in them , spun butter in all its freshness — everything , in fact , that appetites at leisure could desire , in perhaps greater perfection , though not in greater abundance , than at [[Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's]530-squire cass 's . For [[the Squire]531-the squire 's wife]532-the squire 's wife had died long ago , and [the Red House]533-the red house was without that presence of [the wife]534-the wife and [mother]189-mother which is the fountain of wholesome love and fear in parlour and [kitchen]536-kitchen ; and this helped to account not only for there being more profusion than finished excellence in the holiday provisions , but also for the frequency with which [the proud Squire]537-the proud squire condescended to preside in [the parlour of [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow]538-the parlour of the rainbow rather than under the shadow of [his]537-the proud squire own dark wainscot ; perhaps , also , for the fact that [[his]58-squire cass sons]539-his sons had turned out rather ill . [Raveloe]1-raveloe was not a place where moral censure was severe , but it was thought a weakness in [the Squire]531-the squire that [he]531-the squire had kept all [[his]531-the squire sons]539-his sons at [home]374-home in idleness ; and though some licence was to be allowed to [young men whose fathers]543-young men whose fathers could afford it , [people]387-people shook [their]387-people heads at the courses of [the second son]545-the second son , [Dunstan]63-dunstan , commonly called [Dunsey Cass]64-dunsey , whose taste for swopping and betting might turn out to be a sowing of something worse than wild oats . To be sure , [the neighbours]285-the neighbours said , it was no matter what became of [Dunsey]64-dunsey — [a spiteful jeering fellow , who seemed to enjoy [his]64-dunsey drink the more when [other people]548-other people went dry]547-a spiteful jeering fellow , who seemed to enjoy his drink the more when other people went dry — always provided that [his]64-dunsey doings did not bring trouble on [a family like [Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's]549-a family like squire cass 's , with a monument in [the church]322-the church , and tankards older than [King George]65-king george . But it would be a thousand pities if [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey , [the eldest]551-the eldest , [a fine , open - faced , good - natured young man , who was to come into [the land]553-the land some day , should take to going along [the same road]554-the same road as [[his]66-godfrey brother]555-his brother , as [he]66-godfrey had seemed to do of late]552-a fine , open - faced , good - natured young man , who was to come into the land some day , should take to going along the same road as his brother , as he had seemed to do of late . If [he]66-godfrey went on in that way , [he]66-godfrey would lose [Miss Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy ; for it was well known that [she]67-nancy had looked very shyly on [him]66-godfrey ever since last [Whitsuntide twelvemonth]9-whitsuntide twelvemonth , when there was so much talk about [his]66-godfrey being away from [home]374-home days and days together . There was something wrong , more than common — that was quite clear ; for [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey did n't look half so fresh - coloured and open as [he]66-godfrey used to do . At one time [everybody]446-everybody was saying what [a handsome couple]558-a handsome couple [he]66-godfrey and [Miss Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy would make ! and if [she]67-nancy could come to be [mistress]559-mistress at [the Red House]533-the red house , there would be a fine change , for [the Lammeters]68-the lammeters had been brought up in that way , that [they]68-the lammeters never suffered a pinch of salt to be wasted , and yet [[everybody]446-everybody in [their]68-the lammeters household]562-everybody in their household had of the best , according to [his]66-godfrey place . [Such a daughter - in - law]563-such a daughter - in - law would be a saving to [the old Squire]564-the old squire , if [she]563-such a daughter - in - law never brought a penny to [her]563-such a daughter - in - law fortune , for it was to be feared that , notwithstanding [his]66-godfrey incomings , there were more holes in [his]66-godfrey pocket than the one where [he]66-godfrey put [his]66-godfrey own hand in . But if [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey did n't turn over a new leaf , [he]66-godfrey might say " Good - by "[66-godfrey] to [Miss Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy . It was [the once hopeful Godfrey who was standing , with [his]66-godfrey hands in [his]66-godfrey side - pockets and [his]66-godfrey back to the fire , in [the dark wainscoted parlour]566-the dark wainscoted parlour , one late November afternoon , in that fifteenth year of [Silas Marner]38-silas 's life at [Raveloe]1-raveloe]565-the once hopeful godfrey who was standing , with his hands in his side - pockets and his back to the fire , in the dark wainscoted parlour , one late november afternoon , in that fifteenth year of silas marner 's life at raveloe . The fading grey light fell dimly on the walls decorated with guns , whips , and [foxes]567-foxes ' brushes , on coats and hats flung on the chairs , on tankards sending forth a scent of flat ale , and on a half - choked fire , with pipes propped up in the chimney - corners : signs of a domestic life destitute of any hallowing charm , with which the look of gloomy vexation on [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's blonde face was in sad accordance . [He]66-godfrey seemed to be waiting and listening for [some one]568-some one 's approach , and presently the sound of a heavy step , with an accompanying whistle , was heard across the large empty entrance - hall . The door opened , and [a thick - set , heavy - looking young man]569-a thick - set , heavy - looking young man entered , with the flushed face and the gratuitously elated bearing which mark the first stage of intoxication . It was [Dunsey]64-dunsey , and at the sight of [him]569-a thick - set , heavy - looking young man [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's face parted with some of its gloom to take on the more active expression of hatred . [The handsome brown spaniel that lay on the hearth]570-the handsome brown spaniel that lay on the hearth retreated under the chair in the chimney - corner . " Well , [Master Godfrey]66-godfrey , what do [you]66-godfrey want with [me]64-dunsey ? "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , in a mocking tone . " [You]66-godfrey 're [[my]64-dunsey elders]2057-my elders and betters , [you]66-godfrey know ; [I]64-dunsey was obliged to come when [you]66-godfrey sent for [me]64-dunsey . "[64-dunsey] " Why , this is what [I]66-godfrey want — and just shake [yourself]66-godfrey sober and listen , will [you]66-godfrey ? "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , savagely . [He]66-godfrey had [himself]66-godfrey been drinking more than was good for [him]66-godfrey , trying to turn [his]66-godfrey gloom into uncalculating anger . " [I]66-godfrey want to tell [you]66-godfrey , [I]66-godfrey must hand over that rent of [Fowler]69-fowler 's to [the Squire]531-the squire , or else tell [him]531-the squire [I]66-godfrey gave it [you]66-godfrey ; for [he]531-the squire 's threatening to distrain for it , and it 'll all be out soon , whether [I]66-godfrey tell [him]531-the squire or not . [He]531-the squire said , just now , before [he]531-the squire went out , [he]531-the squire should send word to [Cox]70-cox to distrain , if [Fowler]69-fowler did n't come and pay up [his]531-the squire arrears this week . [The Squire]531-the squire 's short o ' cash , and in no humour to stand any nonsense ; and [you]66-godfrey know what [he]531-the squire threatened , if ever [he]531-the squire found [you]66-godfrey making away with [his]531-the squire money again . So , see and get the money , and pretty quickly , will [you]66-godfrey ? "[66-godfrey] " Oh ! "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , sneeringly , coming nearer to [[his]64-dunsey brother]555-his brother and looking in [his]555-his brother face . " Suppose , now , [you]66-godfrey get the money [yourself]66-godfrey , and save [me]64-dunsey the trouble , eh ? Since [you]66-godfrey was so kind as to hand it over to [me]64-dunsey , [you]66-godfrey 'll not refuse [me]64-dunsey the kindness to pay it back for [me]64-dunsey : it was [your]66-godfrey brotherly love made [you]66-godfrey do it , [you]66-godfrey know . "[64-dunsey] [Godfrey]66-godfrey bit [his]66-godfrey lips and clenched [his]66-godfrey fist . " Do n't come near [me]66-godfrey with that look , else [I]66-godfrey 'll knock [you]66-godfrey down . "[66-godfrey] " O no , [you]66-godfrey wo n't , "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , turning away on [his]64-dunsey heel , however . " Because [I]64-dunsey 'm such [a good - natured brother]2060-a good - natured brother , [you]66-godfrey know . [I]64-dunsey might get [you]66-godfrey turned out of [house]2061-house and [home]374-home , and cut off with a shilling any day . [I]64-dunsey might tell [the Squire]531-the squire how [[his]531-the squire handsome son]2064-his handsome son was married to [that nice young woman]2065-that nice young woman , [Molly Farren]71-molly , and was very unhappy because [he]531-the squire could n't live with [[his]531-the squire drunken wife]2066-his drunken wife , and [I]64-dunsey should slip into [[your]66-godfrey place]2067-your place as comfortable as could be . But , [you]66-godfrey see , [I]64-dunsey do n't do it — [I'm]64-dunsey so easy and good - natured . [You]66-godfrey 'll take any trouble for [me]64-dunsey . [You]66-godfrey 'll get the hundred pounds for [me]64-dunsey — [I]64-dunsey know [you]66-godfrey will . "[64-dunsey] " How can [I]66-godfrey get the money ? "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , quivering . " [I]66-godfrey have n't a shilling to bless [myself]66-godfrey with . And it 's a lie that [you]66-godfrey 'd slip into [my]66-godfrey place : [you]66-godfrey 'd get [yourself]66-godfrey turned out too , that 's all . For if [you]66-godfrey begin telling tales , [I]66-godfrey 'll follow . [Bob]72-bob 's [[my]66-godfrey father]2068-my father 's favourite — [you]66-godfrey know that very well . [He]2068-my father 'd only think [himself]2068-my father well rid of [you]66-godfrey . "[66-godfrey] " Never mind , "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , nodding [his]64-dunsey head sideways as [he]64-dunsey looked out of the window . " It ' ud be very pleasant to [me]64-dunsey to go in [your]66-godfrey company — [you're]66-godfrey such [a handsome brother]2069-a handsome brother , and [we]2070-we 've always been so fond of quarrelling with [one another]2071-one another , [I]64-dunsey should n't know what to do without [you]66-godfrey . But [you]66-godfrey 'd like better for [us]2070-we both to stay at [home]374-home together ; [I]64-dunsey know [you]66-godfrey would .
