So [you]66-godfrey 'll manage to get that little sum o ' money , and [I]64-dunsey 'll bid [you]66-godfrey good - by , though [I]64-dunsey 'm sorry to part . "[64-dunsey] [Dunstan]63-dunstan was moving off , but [Godfrey]66-godfrey rushed after [him]63-dunstan and seized [him]63-dunstan by the arm , saying , with an oath , " [I]66-godfrey tell [you]63-dunstan , [I]66-godfrey have no money : [I]66-godfrey can get no money . "[66-godfrey] " Borrow of [old Kimble]54-kimble . "[66-godfrey] " [I]66-godfrey tell [you]63-dunstan , [he]63-dunstan wo n't lend [me]66-godfrey any more , and [I]66-godfrey sha n't ask [him]63-dunstan . "[66-godfrey] " Well then , sell Wildfire . "[66-godfrey] " Yes , that 's easy talking . [I]66-godfrey must have the money directly . "[66-godfrey] " Well , [you]66-godfrey 've only got to ride [him]63-dunstan to the hunt to - morrow . There 'll be [Bryce]73-bryce and [Keating]74-keating [there]2073-there , for sure . [You]66-godfrey 'll get more bids than one . "[66-godfrey] " [I]66-godfrey daresay , and get back [home]374-home at eight o'clock , splashed up to the chin . [I]66-godfrey 'm going to [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's birthday dance . "[66-godfrey] " Oho ! "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , turning [his]64-dunsey head on one side , and trying to speak in a small mincing treble . " And there 's [sweet Miss Nancy]67-nancy coming ; and [we]2075-we shall dance with [her]67-nancy , and promise never to be naughty again , and be taken into favour , and — "[64-dunsey] " Hold [your]66-godfrey tongue about [Miss Nancy]67-nancy , [[you]66-godfrey fool]2076-you fool , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , turning red , " else [I]66-godfrey 'll throttle [you]66-godfrey . "[66-godfrey] " What for ? "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , still in an artificial tone , but taking a whip from the table and beating the butt - end of it on [his]64-dunsey palm . " [You]66-godfrey 've a very good chance . [I]64-dunsey 'd advise [you]66-godfrey to creep up [her]67-nancy sleeve again : it ' ud be saving time if [Molly]71-molly should happen to take a drop too much laudanum some day , and make [a widower of]2077-a widower of [you]66-godfrey . [Miss Nancy]67-nancy would n't mind being a second , if [she]67-nancy did n't know it . And [you]66-godfrey 've got [a good - natured brother]2060-a good - natured brother , who 'll keep [your]66-godfrey secret well , because [you]66-godfrey 'll be so very obliging to [him]2060-a good - natured brother . "[64-dunsey] " [I]66-godfrey 'll tell [you]66-godfrey what it is , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , quivering , and pale again . " [My]66-godfrey patience is pretty near at an end . If [you]66-godfrey 'd a little more sharpness in [you]66-godfrey , [you]66-godfrey might know that [you]66-godfrey may urge [a man]185-a man a bit too far , and make one leap as easy as another . [I]66-godfrey do n't know but what it is so now : [I]66-godfrey may as well tell [the Squire]531-the squire everything [myself]66-godfrey — [I]66-godfrey should get [you]66-godfrey off [my]66-godfrey back , if [I]66-godfrey got nothing else . And , after all , [he]531-the squire 'll know some time . [She]2081-she 's been threatening to come [herself]2081-she and tell [him]531-the squire . So , do n't flatter [yourself]66-godfrey that [your]66-godfrey secrecy 's worth any price [you]66-godfrey choose to ask . [You]66-godfrey drain [me]66-godfrey of money till [I]66-godfrey 've got nothing to pacify [her]2081-she with , and [she]2081-she 'll do as [she]2081-she threatens some day . It 's all one . [I]66-godfrey 'll tell [[my]66-godfrey father]2068-my father everything [myself]66-godfrey , and [you]66-godfrey may go to the devil . "[66-godfrey] [Dunsey]64-dunsey perceived that [he]64-dunsey had overshot [his]64-dunsey mark , and that there was a point at which even the hesitating [Godfrey]66-godfrey might be driven into decision . But [he]64-dunsey said , with an air of unconcern , " As [you]66-godfrey please ; but [I]64-dunsey 'll have a draught of ale first . "[64-dunsey] And ringing the bell , [he]64-dunsey threw [himself]64-dunsey across two chairs , and began to rap the window - seat with the handle of [his]64-dunsey whip . [Godfrey]66-godfrey stood , still with [his]66-godfrey back to the fire , uneasily moving [his]66-godfrey fingers among the contents of [his]66-godfrey side - pockets , and looking at the floor . That big muscular frame of [his]66-godfrey held plenty of animal courage , but helped [him]66-godfrey to no decision when the dangers to be braved were such as could neither be knocked down nor throttled . [His]66-godfrey natural irresolution and moral cowardice were exaggerated by a position in which dreaded consequences seemed to press equally on all sides , and [his]66-godfrey irritation had no sooner provoked [him]66-godfrey to defy [Dunstan]63-dunstan and anticipate all possible betrayals , than the miseries [he]66-godfrey must bring on [himself]66-godfrey by such a step seemed more unendurable to [him]66-godfrey than the present evil . The results of confession were not contingent , they were certain ; whereas betrayal was not certain . From the near vision of that certainty [he]66-godfrey fell back on suspense and vacillation with a sense of repose . [The disinherited son of [a small squire , equally disinclined to dig and to beg]573-a small squire , equally disinclined to dig and to beg]572-the disinherited son of a small squire , equally disinclined to dig and to beg , was almost as helpless as an uprooted tree , which , by the favour of earth and sky , has grown to a handsome bulk on the spot where it first shot upward . Perhaps it would have been possible to think of digging with some cheerfulness if [Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy were to be won on those terms ; but , since [he]66-godfrey must irrevocably lose [her]67-nancy as well as the inheritance , and must break every tie but the one that degraded [him]66-godfrey and left [him]66-godfrey without motive for trying to recover [his]66-godfrey better self , [he]66-godfrey could imagine no future for [himself]66-godfrey on the other side of confession but that of " ' listing for [a soldier"—the[575-casualties] most desperate step]2083-a soldier"—the most desperate step , short of suicide , in the eyes of [respectable families]518-respectable families . No ! [he]66-godfrey would rather trust to [casualties]575-casualties than to [his]66-godfrey own resolve — rather go on sitting at the feast and sipping the wine [he]66-godfrey loved , though with the sword hanging over [him]66-godfrey and terror in [his]66-godfrey heart , than rush away into the cold darkness where there was no pleasure left . The utmost concession to [Dunstan]63-dunstan about the horse began to seem easy , compared with the fulfilment of [his]63-dunstan own threat . But [his]63-dunstan pride would not let [him]63-dunstan recommence the conversation otherwise than by continuing the quarrel . [Dunstan]63-dunstan was waiting for this , and took [his]63-dunstan ale in shorter draughts than usual . " It 's just like [you]63-dunstan , "[66-godfrey] [Godfrey]66-godfrey burst out , in a bitter tone , " to talk about [my]66-godfrey selling Wildfire in that cool way — the last thing [I]66-godfrey 've got to call [my]66-godfrey own , and the best bit of horse - flesh [I]66-godfrey ever had in [my]66-godfrey life . And if [you]63-dunstan 'd got a spark of pride in [you]63-dunstan , [you]63-dunstan 'd be ashamed to see [the stables]2084-the stables emptied , and [everybody]446-everybody sneering about it . But it 's [my]66-godfrey belief [you]63-dunstan 'd sell [yourself]63-dunstan , if it was only for the pleasure of making [somebody]2086-somebody feel [he]2086-somebody 'd got a bad bargain . "[66-godfrey] " Ay , ay , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan , very placably , " [you]63-dunstan do [me]63-dunstan justice , [I]63-dunstan see . [You]63-dunstan know [I]63-dunstan 'm a jewel for ' ticing [people]387-people into bargains . For which reason [I]63-dunstan advise [you]63-dunstan to let [me]63-dunstan sell [Wildfire]75-wildfire . [I]63-dunstan 'd ride [him]75-wildfire to the hunt to - morrow for [you]63-dunstan , with pleasure . [I]63-dunstan should n't look so handsome as [you]63-dunstan in the saddle , but it 's the horse [they]387-people 'll bid for , and not [the rider]2088-the rider . "[63-dunstan] " Yes , [I]66-godfrey daresay — trust [my]66-godfrey horse to [you]63-dunstan ! "[66-godfrey] " As [you]63-dunstan please , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan , rapping the window - seat again with an air of great unconcern . " It 's [you]63-dunstan have got to pay [Fowler]69-fowler 's money ; it 's none of [my]63-dunstan business . [You]63-dunstan received the money from [him]69-fowler when [you]63-dunstan went to [Bramcote]10-bramcote , and [you]63-dunstan told [the Squire]531-the squire it was n't paid . [I]63-dunstan 'd nothing to do with that ; [you]63-dunstan chose to be so obliging as give it [me]63-dunstan , that was all . If [you]63-dunstan do n't want to pay the money , let it alone ; it 's all one to [me]63-dunstan . But [I]63-dunstan was willing to accommodate [you]63-dunstan by undertaking to sell the horse , seeing it 's not convenient to [you]63-dunstan to go so far to - morrow . "[63-dunstan] [Godfrey]66-godfrey was silent for some moments . [He]66-godfrey would have liked to spring on [Dunstan]63-dunstan , wrench the whip from [his]66-godfrey hand , and flog [him]66-godfrey to within an inch of [his]66-godfrey life ; and no bodily fear could have deterred [him]66-godfrey ; but [he]66-godfrey was mastered by another sort of fear , which was fed by feelings stronger even than [his]66-godfrey resentment . When [he]66-godfrey spoke again , it was in a half - conciliatory tone . " Well , [you]63-dunstan mean no nonsense about the horse , eh ? [You]63-dunstan 'll sell [him]2090-him all fair , and hand over the money ? If [you]63-dunstan do n't , [you]63-dunstan know , everything 'll go to smash , for [I]66-godfrey 've got nothing else to trust to . And [you]63-dunstan 'll have less pleasure in pulling [the house]334-the house over [my]66-godfrey head , when [your]63-dunstan own skull 's to be broken too . "[66-godfrey] " Ay , ay , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan , rising , " all right . [I]63-dunstan thought [you]63-dunstan 'd come round . [I]63-dunstan 'm [the fellow]2092-the fellow to bring [old Bryce]73-bryce up to the scratch . [I]63-dunstan 'll get [you]63-dunstan a hundred and twenty for [him]2090-him , if [I]63-dunstan get [you]63-dunstan a penny . "[63-dunstan] " But it 'll perhaps rain cats and dogs to - morrow , as it did yesterday , and then [you]63-dunstan ca n't go , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , hardly knowing whether [he]66-godfrey wished for that obstacle or not . " Not it , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan . " [I]63-dunstan 'm always lucky in [my]63-dunstan weather . It might rain if [you]63-dunstan wanted to go [yourself]63-dunstan . [You]63-dunstan never hold trumps , [you]63-dunstan know — [I]63-dunstan always do . [You]63-dunstan 've got the beauty , [you]63-dunstan see , and [I]63-dunstan 've got the luck , so [you]63-dunstan must keep [me]63-dunstan by [you]63-dunstan for [your]63-dunstan crooked sixpence ; [you]63-dunstan 'll ne -ver get along without [me]63-dunstan . "[63-dunstan] " Confound [you]63-dunstan , hold [your]63-dunstan tongue , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , impetuously . " And take care to keep sober to - morrow , else [you]63-dunstan 'll get pitched on [your]63-dunstan head coming [home]374-home , and Wildfire might be the worse for it . "[66-godfrey] " Make [your]66-godfrey tender heart easy , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan , opening the door . " [You]66-godfrey never knew [me]63-dunstan see double when [I]63-dunstan 'd got a bargain to make ; it ' ud spoil the fun . Besides , whenever [I]63-dunstan fall , [I]63-dunstan 'm warranted to fall on [my]63-dunstan legs . "[63-dunstan] With that , [Dunstan]63-dunstan slammed the door behind [him]63-dunstan , and left [Godfrey]66-godfrey to that bitter rumination on [his]66-godfrey personal circumstances which was now unbroken from day to day save by the excitement of sporting , drinking , card - playing , or the rarer and less oblivious pleasure of seeing [Miss Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy . The subtle and varied pains springing from the higher sensibility that accompanies higher culture , are perhaps less pitiable than that dreary absence of impersonal enjoyment and consolation which leaves ruder minds to the perpetual urgent companionship of [their]576-their own griefs and discontents . The lives of [those rural forefathers , whom [we]578-we are apt to think very prosaic figures]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures — men whose only work was to ride round [[their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures land]579-their land , getting heavier and heavier in [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures saddles , and who passed the rest of [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures days in the half - listless gratification of senses dulled by monotony — had a certain pathos in [them]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures nevertheless . Calamities came to [them]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures too , and [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures early errors carried hard consequences : perhaps the love of [some sweet maiden]580-some sweet maiden , the image of purity , order , and calm , had opened [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures eyes to the vision of a life in which the days would not seem too long , even without rioting ; but [the maiden]581-the maiden was lost , and the vision passed away , and then what was left to [them]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures , especially when [they]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures had become too heavy for the hunt , or for carrying a gun over the furrows , but to drink and get merry , or to drink and get angry , so that [they]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures might be independent of variety , and say over again with eager emphasis the things [they]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures had said already any time that twelvemonth ? Assuredly , among [these flushed and dull - eyed men]582-these flushed and dull - eyed men there were some whom — thanks to [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures native human - kindness — even riot could never drive into brutality ; [men who , when [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures cheeks were fresh , had felt the keen point of sorrow or remorse , had been pierced by the reeds [they]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures leaned on , or had lightly put [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures limbs in fetters from which no struggle could loose them]583-men who , when their cheeks were fresh , had felt the keen point of sorrow or remorse , had been pierced by the reeds they leaned on , or had lightly put their limbs in fetters from which no struggle could loose them ; and under these sad circumstances , common to [us]584-us all , [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures thoughts could find no resting - place outside the ever - trodden round of [their]577-those rural forefathers , whom we are apt to think very prosaic figures own petty history . That , at least , was the condition of [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey in this six - and - twentieth year of [his]66-godfrey life . A movement of compunction , helped by those small indefinable influences which every personal relation exerts on a pliant nature , had urged [him]66-godfrey into a secret marriage , which was a blight on [his]66-godfrey life . It was an ugly story of low passion , delusion , and waking from delusion , which needs not to be dragged from the privacy of [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's bitter memory . [He]66-godfrey had long known that the delusion was partly due to a trap laid for [him]66-godfrey by [Dunstan]63-dunstan , who saw in [[his]63-dunstan brother]555-his brother 's degrading marriage the means of gratifying at once [his]63-dunstan jealous hate and [his]63-dunstan cupidity . And if [Godfrey]66-godfrey could have felt [himself]66-godfrey simply [a victim]586-a victim , the iron bit that destiny had put into [his]66-godfrey mouth would have chafed [him]66-godfrey less intolerably . If the curses [he]66-godfrey muttered half aloud when [he]66-godfrey was alone had had no other object than [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's diabolical cunning , [he]66-godfrey might have shrunk less from the consequences of avowal . But [he]66-godfrey had something else to curse — [his]66-godfrey own vicious folly , which now seemed as mad and unaccountable to [him]66-godfrey as almost all [our]587-our follies and vices do when [their]588-their promptings have long passed away . For four years [he]66-godfrey had thought of [Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy , and wooed [her]67-nancy with tacit patient worship , as [the woman who made [him]66-godfrey think of the future with joy]589-the woman who made him think of the future with joy : [she]67-nancy would be [[his]66-godfrey wife]223-his wife , and would make [home]374-home lovely to [him]66-godfrey , as [[[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father 's [home]374-home]593-his father 's home had never been ; and it would be easy , when [she]67-nancy was always near , to shake off those foolish habits that were no pleasures , but only a feverish way of annulling vacancy . [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's was an essentially domestic nature , bred up in [a home where the hearth had no smiles]595-a home where the hearth had no smiles , and where the daily habits were not chastised by the presence of household order ; [his]66-godfrey easy disposition made [him]66-godfrey fall in unresistingly with the family courses , but the need of some tender permanent affection , the longing for some influence that would make the good [he]66-godfrey preferred easy to pursue , caused the neatness , purity , and liberal orderliness of [the Lammeter household]596-the lammeter household , sunned by the smile of [Nancy]67-nancy , to seem like those fresh bright hours of the morning , when temptations go to sleep , and leave the ear open to the voice of [the good angel]597-the good angel , inviting to industry , sobriety , and peace . And yet the hope of [this paradise]598-this paradise had not been enough to save [him]66-godfrey from a course which shut [him]66-godfrey out of it for ever . Instead of keeping fast hold of the strong silken rope by which [Nancy]67-nancy would have drawn [him]66-godfrey safe to [the green banks]599-the green banks , where it was easy to step firmly , [he]66-godfrey had let [himself]66-godfrey be dragged back into mud and slime , in which it was useless to struggle . [He]66-godfrey had made ties for [himself]66-godfrey which robbed [him]66-godfrey of all wholesome motive , and were a constant exasperation . Still , there was one position worse than the present : it was the position [he]66-godfrey would be in when the ugly secret was disclosed ; and the desire that continually triumphed over every other was that of warding off the evil day , when [he]66-godfrey would have to bear the consequences of [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father 's violent resentment for the wound inflicted on [[his]66-godfrey family]601-his family pride — would have , perhaps , to turn [his]66-godfrey back on that hereditary ease and dignity which , after all , was a sort of reason for living , and would carry with [him]66-godfrey the certainty that [he]66-godfrey was banished for ever from the sight and esteem of [Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy . The longer the interval , the more chance there was of deliverance from some , at least , of the hateful consequences to which [he]66-godfrey had sold [himself]66-godfrey — the more opportunities remained for [him]66-godfrey to snatch the strange gratification of seeing [Nancy]67-nancy , and gathering some faint indications of [her]67-nancy lingering regard . Towards this gratification [he]66-godfrey was impelled , fitfully , every now and then , after having passed weeks in which [he]66-godfrey had avoided [her]67-nancy as [the far - off , bright - winged prize]602-the far - off , bright - winged prize , that only made [him]66-godfrey spring forward , and find [his]66-godfrey chain all the more galling . One of those fits of yearning was on [him]66-godfrey now , and it would have been strong enough to have persuaded [him]66-godfrey to trust [Wildfire]75-wildfire to [Dunstan]63-dunstan rather than disappoint the yearning , even if [he]66-godfrey had not had another reason for [his]66-godfrey disinclination towards the morrow 's hunt . That other reason was the fact that the morning 's meet was near [Batherley]11-batherley , [the market - town where [the unhappy woman]604-the unhappy woman lived , whose image became more odious to [him]66-godfrey every day]603-the market - town where the unhappy woman lived , whose image became more odious to him every day ; and to [his]66-godfrey thought the whole vicinage was haunted by [her]67-nancy . The yoke [a man]185-a man creates for [himself]185-a man by wrong - doing will breed hate in the kindliest nature ; and [the good - humoured , affectionate - hearted Godfrey Cass]606-the good - humoured , affectionate - hearted godfrey cass , was fast becoming [a bitter man , visited by cruel wishes , that seemed to enter , and depart , and enter again]607-a bitter man , visited by cruel wishes , that seemed to enter , and depart , and enter again , like demons who had found in [him]66-godfrey a ready - garnished [home]374-home . What was [he]66-godfrey to do this evening to pass the time ? [He]66-godfrey might as well go to [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow , and hear the talk about the cock - fighting : [everybody]446-everybody was there , and what else was there to be done ? Though , for [his]66-godfrey own part , [he]66-godfrey did not care a button for cock - fighting . [Snuff]76-snuff , [the brown spaniel , who had placed [herself]76-snuff in front of [him]66-godfrey , and had been watching [him]66-godfrey for some time]610-the brown spaniel , who had placed herself in front of him , and had been watching him for some time , now jumped up in impatience for the expected caress . But [Godfrey]66-godfrey thrust [her]67-nancy away without looking at [her]67-nancy , and left [the room]611-the room , followed humbly by [the unresenting Snuff]612-the unresenting snuff — perhaps because [she]67-nancy saw no other career open to [her]67-nancy . [Dunstan Cass]63-dunstan , setting off in the raw morning , at the judiciously quiet pace of [a man who is obliged to ride to cover on [[his]613-a man who is obliged to ride to cover on his hunter hunter]614-his hunter]613-a man who is obliged to ride to cover on his hunter , had to take [his]613-a man who is obliged to ride to cover on his hunter way along [the lane]615-the lane , which , at [its]615-the lane farther extremity , passed by the piece of unenclosed ground called [the Stonepit]12-the stonepit , where stood [the cottage]616-the cottage , [once [a stone - cutter]618-a stone - cutter 's shed]617-once a stone - cutter 's shed , now for fifteen years inhabited by [Silas Marner]38-silas . [The spot]619-the spot looked very dreary at this season , with the moist trodden clay about it , and the red , muddy water high up in [the deserted quarry]620-the deserted quarry . That was [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's first thought as [he]63-dunstan approached [it]619-the spot ; the second was , that [the old fool of [a weaver , whose loom [he]63-dunstan heard rattling already]622-a weaver , whose loom he heard rattling already , had a great deal of money hidden somewhere]621-the old fool of a weaver , whose loom he heard rattling already , had a great deal of money hidden somewhere . How was it that [he]63-dunstan , [Dunstan Cass]63-dunstan , who had often heard talk of [Marner]38-silas 's miserliness , had never thought of suggesting to [Godfrey]66-godfrey that [he]63-dunstan should frighten or persuade [the old fellow]623-the old fellow into lending the money on the excellent security of [the young Squire]624-the young squire 's prospects ? The resource occurred to [him]63-dunstan now as so easy and agreeable , especially as [Marner]38-silas 's hoard was likely to be large enough to leave [Godfrey]66-godfrey a handsome surplus beyond [his]66-godfrey immediate needs , and enable [him]66-godfrey to accommodate [[his]66-godfrey faithful brother]625-his faithful brother , that [he]66-godfrey had almost turned the horse 's head towards [home]374-home again . [Godfrey]66-godfrey would be ready enough to accept the suggestion : [he]66-godfrey would snatch eagerly at a plan that might save [him]66-godfrey from parting with Wildfire . But when [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's meditation reached this point , the inclination to go on grew strong and prevailed . [He]63-dunstan did n't want to give [Godfrey]66-godfrey that pleasure : [he]63-dunstan preferred that [Master Godfrey]66-godfrey should be vexed . Moreover , [Dunstan]63-dunstan enjoyed the self - important consciousness of having a horse to sell , and the opportunity of driving a bargain , swaggering , and , possibly , taking [somebody]2086-somebody in . [He]63-dunstan might have all the satisfaction attendant on selling [[his]63-dunstan brother]555-his brother 's horse , and not the less have the further satisfaction of setting [Godfrey]66-godfrey to borrow [Marner]38-silas 's money . So [he]63-dunstan rode on to cover . [Bryce]73-bryce and [Keating]74-keating were there , as [Dunstan]63-dunstan was quite sure [they]629-they would be — [he]63-dunstan was such [a lucky fellow]630-a lucky fellow . " Hey - day , "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce , who had long had [his]73-bryce eye on [Wildfire]75-wildfire , " [you]63-dunstan 're on [[your]63-dunstan brother]2094-your brother 's horse to - day : how 's that ? "[73-bryce] " O , [I]63-dunstan 've swopped with [him]75-wildfire , "[63-dunstan] said [Dunstan]63-dunstan , whose delight in lying , grandly independent of utility , was not to be diminished by the likelihood that [[his]63-dunstan hearer]631-his hearer would not believe [him]63-dunstan — " [Wildfire]75-wildfire 's mine now . "[73-bryce] " What ! has [he]75-wildfire swopped with [you]63-dunstan for [that big - boned hack of [yours]63-dunstan]2095-that big - boned hack of yours ? "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce , quite aware that [he]73-bryce should get another lie in answer . " O , there was a little account between [us]2096-us , "[64-dunsey] said [Dunsey]64-dunsey , carelessly , " and [Wildfire]75-wildfire made it even . [I]64-dunsey accommodated [him]75-wildfire by taking the horse , though it was against [my]64-dunsey will , for [I]64-dunsey 'd got an itch for a mare o ' Jortin's — as rare a bit o ' blood as ever [you]63-dunstan threw [your]63-dunstan leg across . But [I]64-dunsey shall keep [Wildfire]75-wildfire , now [I]64-dunsey 've got [him]75-wildfire ; though [I]64-dunsey 'd a bid of a hundred and fifty for [him]75-wildfire the other day , from [a man over at [Flitton]13-flitton]2097-a man over at flitton — [he]75-wildfire 's buying for [Lord Cromleck]77-lord cromleck — [a fellow with a cast in [his]75-wildfire eye]2098-a fellow with a cast in his eye , and a green waistcoat . But [I]64-dunsey mean to stick to [Wildfire]75-wildfire : [I]64-dunsey sha n't get a better at a fence in a hurry . [The mare]2099-the mare 's got more blood , but [she]2099-the mare 's a bit too weak in the hind - quarters . "[64-dunsey] [Bryce]73-bryce of course divined that [Dunstan]63-dunstan wanted to sell the horse , and [Dunstan]63-dunstan knew that [he]73-bryce divined it ( horse - dealing is only one of many human transactions carried on in this ingenious manner ) ; and [they]632-they both considered that the bargain was in its first stage , when [Bryce]73-bryce replied ironically — " [I]73-bryce wonder at that now ; [I]73-bryce wonder [you]63-dunstan mean to keep [him]75-wildfire ; for [I]73-bryce never heard of [a man who did n't want to sell [his]2100-a man who did n't want to sell his horse horse]2100-a man who did n't want to sell his horse getting a bid of half as much again as the horse was worth . [You]63-dunstan 'll be lucky if [you]63-dunstan get a hundred . "[73-bryce] [Keating]74-keating rode up now , and the transaction became more complicated . It ended in the purchase of the horse by [Bryce]73-bryce for a hundred and twenty , to be paid on the delivery of [Wildfire]75-wildfire , safe and sound , at [the Batherley stables]633-the batherley stables . It did occur to [Dunsey]64-dunsey that it might be wise for [him]64-dunsey to give up the day 's hunting , proceed at once to [Batherley]11-batherley , and , having waited for [Bryce]73-bryce 's return , hire a horse to carry [him]64-dunsey [home]374-home with the money in [his]64-dunsey pocket . But the inclination for a run , encouraged by confidence in [his]64-dunsey luck , and by a draught of brandy from [his]64-dunsey pocket - pistol at the conclusion of the bargain , was not easy to overcome , especially with a horse under [him]64-dunsey that would take the fences to the admiration of [the field]635-the field . [Dunstan]63-dunstan , however , took one fence too many , and " staked "[63-dunstan] [his]63-dunstan horse . [[His]63-dunstan own ill - favoured person]636-his own ill - favoured person , which was quite unmarketable , escaped without injury , but poor [Wildfire]75-wildfire , unconscious of [his]75-wildfire price , turned on [his]75-wildfire flank , and painfully panted [his]75-wildfire last . It happened that [Dunstan]63-dunstan , a short time before , having had to get down to arrange [his]63-dunstan stirrup , had muttered a good many curses at this interruption , which had thrown [him]63-dunstan in the rear of the hunt near the moment of glory , and under this exasperation had taken the fences more blindly . [He]63-dunstan would soon have been up with the hounds again , when the fatal accident happened ; and hence [he]63-dunstan was between [eager riders in advance , not troubling [themselves]637-eager riders in advance , not troubling themselves about what happened behind them , and far - off stragglers , who were as likely as not to pass quite aloof from the line of road in which wildfire had fallen about what happened behind [them]637-eager riders in advance , not troubling themselves about what happened behind them , and far - off stragglers , who were as likely as not to pass quite aloof from the line of road in which wildfire had fallen , and [far - off stragglers , who were as likely as not to pass quite aloof from the line of road in which [Wildfire]75-wildfire had fallen]638-far - off stragglers , who were as likely as not to pass quite aloof from the line of road in which wildfire had fallen]637-eager riders in advance , not troubling themselves about what happened behind them , and far - off stragglers , who were as likely as not to pass quite aloof from the line of road in which wildfire had fallen . [Dunstan]63-dunstan , whose nature it was to care more for immediate annoyances than for remote consequences , no sooner recovered [his]63-dunstan legs , and saw that it was all over with Wildfire , than [he]63-dunstan felt a satisfaction at the absence of [witnesses]639-witnesses to a position which no swaggering could make enviable . Reinforcing [himself]63-dunstan , after [his]63-dunstan shake , with a little brandy and much swearing , [he]63-dunstan walked as fast as [he]63-dunstan could to a coppice on [his]63-dunstan right hand , through which it occurred to [him]63-dunstan that [he]63-dunstan could make [his]63-dunstan way to [Batherley]11-batherley without danger of encountering [any member of the hunt]640-any member of the hunt . [His]63-dunstan first intention was to hire a horse there and ride [home]374-home forthwith , for to walk many miles without a gun in [his]63-dunstan hand , and along [an ordinary road]642-an ordinary road , was as much out of the question to [him]63-dunstan as to [other spirited young men of [his]63-dunstan kind]643-other spirited young men of his kind . [He]63-dunstan did not much mind about taking the bad news to [Godfrey]66-godfrey , for [he]63-dunstan had to offer [him]66-godfrey at the same time the resource of [Marner]38-silas 's money ; and if [Godfrey]66-godfrey kicked , as [he]66-godfrey always did , at the notion of making a fresh debt , from which [he]66-godfrey [himself]66-godfrey got the smallest share of advantage , why , [he]66-godfrey would n't kick long : [Dunstan]63-dunstan felt sure [he]63-dunstan could worry [Godfrey]66-godfrey into anything . The idea of [Marner]38-silas 's money kept growing in vividness , now the want of it had become immediate ; the prospect of having to make [his]63-dunstan appearance with the muddy boots of [a pedestrian at [Batherley]11-batherley]644-a pedestrian at batherley , and encounter the grinning queries of [stablemen]645-stablemen , stood unpleasantly in the way of [his]63-dunstan impatience to be back at [Raveloe]1-raveloe and carry out [his]63-dunstan felicitous plan ; and a casual visitation of [his]63-dunstan waistcoat - pocket , as [he]63-dunstan was ruminating , awakened [his]63-dunstan memory to the fact the two or three small coins [his]63-dunstan fore - finger encountered there were of too pale a colour to cover that small debt , without payment of which [Jennings]78-jennings had declared [he]78-jennings would never do any more business with [Dunsey Cass]64-dunsey . After all , according to the direction in which the run had brought [him]63-dunstan , [he]63-dunstan was not so very much farther from [home]374-home than [he]63-dunstan was from [Batherley]11-batherley ; but [Dunsey]64-dunsey , not being remarkable for clearness of head , was only led to this conclusion by the gradual perception that there were other reasons for choosing the unprecedented course of walking [home]374-home . It was now nearly four o'clock , and a mist was gathering : the sooner [he]63-dunstan got into [the road]648-the road the better . [He]63-dunstan remembered having crossed [the road]648-the road and seen the finger - post only a little while before Wildfire broke down ; so , buttoning [his]63-dunstan coat , twisting the lash of [his]63-dunstan hunting - whip compactly round the handle , and rapping the tops of [his]63-dunstan boots with a self - possessed air , as if to assure [himself]63-dunstan that [he]63-dunstan was not at all taken by surprise , [he]63-dunstan set off with the sense that [he]63-dunstan was undertaking a remarkable feat of bodily exertion , which somehow , and at some time , [he]63-dunstan should be able to dress up and magnify to the admiration of a select circle at the Rainbow . When [a young gentleman]650-a young gentleman like [Dunsey]64-dunsey is reduced to so exceptional a mode of locomotion as walking , a whip in [his]63-dunstan hand is a desirable corrective to a too bewildering dreamy sense of unwontedness in [his]63-dunstan position ; and [Dunstan]63-dunstan , as [he]63-dunstan went along through the gathering mist , was always rapping [his]63-dunstan whip somewhere . It was [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's whip , which [he]63-dunstan had chosen to take without leave because it had a gold handle ; of course [no one]182-no one could see , when [Dunstan]63-dunstan held it , that the name [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey was cut in deep letters on that gold handle — [they]652-they could only see that it was a very handsome whip . [Dunsey]64-dunsey was not without fear that [he]64-dunsey might meet some acquaintance in whose eyes [he]64-dunsey would cut [a pitiable figure]653-a pitiable figure , for mist is no screen when [people]387-people get close to [each other]655-each other ; but when [he]64-dunsey at last found [himself]64-dunsey in [the well - known [Raveloe]1-raveloe lanes]656-the well - known raveloe lanes without having met [a soul]657-a soul , [he]64-dunsey silently remarked that that was part of [his]64-dunsey usual good - luck . But now the mist , helped by the evening darkness , was more of a screen than [he]64-dunsey desired , for it hid the ruts into which [his]64-dunsey feet were liable to slip — hid everything , so that [he]64-dunsey had to guide [his]64-dunsey steps by dragging [his]64-dunsey whip along the low bushes in advance of the hedgerow . [He]64-dunsey must soon , [he]64-dunsey thought , be getting near the opening at [the Stone - pits]658-the stone - pits : [he]64-dunsey should find it out by the break in the hedgerow . [He]64-dunsey found it out , however , by another circumstance which [he]64-dunsey had not expected — namely , by certain gleams of light , which [he]64-dunsey presently guessed to proceed from [[Silas Marner]38-silas 's cottage]659-silas marner 's cottage . [That cottage]660-that cottage and the money hidden within [it]660-that cottage had been in [his]64-dunsey mind continually during [his]64-dunsey walk , and [he]64-dunsey had been imagining ways of cajoling and tempting [the weaver]209-the weaver to part with the immediate possession of [his]64-dunsey money for the sake of receiving interest . [Dunstan]63-dunstan felt as if there must be a little frightening added to the cajolery , for [his]63-dunstan own arithmetical convictions were not clear enough to afford [him]63-dunstan any forcible demonstration as to the advantages of interest ; and as for security , [he]63-dunstan regarded it vaguely as a means of cheating [a man]185-a man , by making [him]185-a man believe that [he]185-a man would be paid . Altogether , the operation on [the miser]663-the miser 's mind was a task that [Godfrey]66-godfrey would be sure to hand over to [[his]66-godfrey more daring and cunning brother]664-his more daring and cunning brother : [Dunstan]63-dunstan had made up [his]63-dunstan mind to that ; and by the time [he]63-dunstan saw the light gleaming through the chinks of [Marner]38-silas 's shutters , the idea of a dialogue with [the weaver]209-the weaver had become so familiar to [him]63-dunstan , that it occurred to [him]63-dunstan as quite a natural thing to make the acquaintance forthwith . There might be several conveniences attending this course : [the weaver]209-the weaver had possibly got a lantern , and [Dunstan]63-dunstan was tired of feeling [his]63-dunstan way . [He]63-dunstan was still nearly three - quarters of a mile from [home]374-home , and [the lane]615-the lane was becoming unpleasantly slippery , for the mist was passing into rain . [He]63-dunstan turned up the bank , not without some fear lest [he]63-dunstan might miss the right way , since [he]63-dunstan was not certain whether the light were in front or on the side of [the cottage]616-the cottage . But [he]63-dunstan felt the ground before [him]63-dunstan cautiously with [his]63-dunstan whip - handle , and at last arrived safely at the door . [He]63-dunstan knocked loudly , rather enjoying the idea that [the old fellow]623-the old fellow would be frightened at the sudden noise . [He]63-dunstan heard no movement in reply : all was silence in [the cottage]616-the cottage . Was [the weaver]209-the weaver gone to bed , then ? If so , why had [he]209-the weaver left a light ? That was a strange forgetfulness in [a miser]673-a miser . [Dunstan]63-dunstan knocked still more loudly , and , without pausing for a reply , pushed [his]63-dunstan fingers through the latch - hole , intending to shake the door and pull the latch - string up and down , not doubting that the door was fastened . But , to [his]63-dunstan surprise , at this double motion the door opened , and [he]63-dunstan found [himself]63-dunstan in front of a bright fire , which lit up every corner of [the cottage]616-the cottage — the bed , the loom , the three chairs , and the table — and showed [him]63-dunstan that [Marner]38-silas was not [there]2073-there . Nothing at that moment could be much more inviting to [Dunsey]64-dunsey than the bright fire on the brick hearth : [he]63-dunstan walked in and seated [himself]63-dunstan by [it]676-it at once . There was something in front of the fire , too , that would have been inviting to [a hungry man]677-a hungry man , if it had been in a different stage of cooking . It was a small bit of pork suspended from the kettle - hanger by a string passed through a large door - key , in a way known to [primitive housekeepers unpossessed of jacks]678-primitive housekeepers unpossessed of jacks . But the pork had been hung at the farthest extremity of the hanger , apparently to prevent the roasting from proceeding too rapidly during [the owner]679-the owner 's absence . [The old staring simpleton]680-the old staring simpleton had hot meat for [his]680-the old staring simpleton supper , then ? thought [Dunstan]63-dunstan . [People]387-people had always said [he]680-the old staring simpleton lived on mouldy bread , on purpose to check [his]680-the old staring simpleton appetite . But where could [he]680-the old staring simpleton be at this time , and on such an evening , leaving [his]680-the old staring simpleton supper in this stage of preparation , and [his]680-the old staring simpleton door unfastened ? [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's own recent difficulty in making [his]63-dunstan way suggested to [him]63-dunstan that [the weaver]209-the weaver had perhaps gone outside [[his]63-dunstan cottage]458-his cottage to fetch in fuel , or for some such brief purpose , and had slipped into [the Stone - pit]684-the stone - pit . That was an interesting idea to [Dunstan]63-dunstan , carrying consequences of entire novelty . If [the weaver]209-the weaver was dead , who had a right to [his]209-the weaver money ? Who would know where [his]209-the weaver money was hidden ? Who would know that [anybody]263-anybody had come to take it away ? [He]63-dunstan went no farther into the subtleties of evidence : the pressing question , " Where is the money ? "[63-dunstan] now took such entire possession of [him]63-dunstan as to make [him]63-dunstan quite forget that [the weaver]209-the weaver 's death was not a certainty . A dull mind , once arriving at an inference that flatters a desire , is rarely able to retain the impression that the notion from which the inference started was purely problematic . And [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's mind was as dull as the mind of [a possible felon]688-a possible felon usually is . There were only three hiding - places where [he]63-dunstan had ever heard of [cottagers]689-cottagers ' hoards being found : the thatch , the bed , and a hole in the floor . [[Marner]38-silas 's cottage]690-marner 's cottage had no thatch ; and [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's first act , after a train of thought made rapid by the stimulus of cupidity , was to go up to the bed ; but while [he]63-dunstan did so , [his]63-dunstan eyes travelled eagerly over the floor , where the bricks , distinct in the fire - light , were discernible under the sprinkling of sand . But not everywhere ; for there was one spot , and one only , which was quite covered with sand , and sand showing the marks of fingers which had apparently been careful to spread it over a given space . It was near the treddles of [the loom]691-the loom . In an instant [Dunstan]63-dunstan darted to [that spot]692-that spot , swept away the sand with [his]63-dunstan whip , and , inserting the thin end of the hook between the bricks , found that they were loose . In haste [he]63-dunstan lifted up two bricks , and saw what [he]63-dunstan had no doubt was the object of [his]63-dunstan search ; for what could there be but money in those two leathern bags ? And , from their weight , they must be filled with guineas . [Dunstan]63-dunstan felt round the hole , to be certain that it held no more ; then hastily replaced the bricks , and spread the sand over them . Hardly more than five minutes had passed since [he]63-dunstan entered [the cottage]616-the cottage , but it seemed to [Dunstan]63-dunstan like a long while ; and though [he]63-dunstan was without any distinct recognition of the possibility that [Marner]38-silas might be alive , and might re - enter [the cottage]616-the cottage at any moment , [he]63-dunstan felt an undefinable dread laying hold on [him]63-dunstan , as [he]63-dunstan rose to [his]63-dunstan feet with the bags in [his]63-dunstan hand . [He]63-dunstan would hasten out into the darkness , and then consider what [he]63-dunstan should do with the bags . [He]63-dunstan closed the door behind [him]63-dunstan immediately , that [he]63-dunstan might shut in the stream of light : a few steps would be enough to carry [him]63-dunstan beyond betrayal by the gleams from the shutter - chinks and the latch - hole . The rain and darkness had got thicker , and [he]63-dunstan was glad of it ; though it was awkward walking with both hands filled , so that it was as much as [he]63-dunstan could do to grasp [his]63-dunstan whip along with one of the bags . But when [he]63-dunstan had gone a yard or two , [he]63-dunstan might take [his]63-dunstan time . So [he]63-dunstan stepped forward into the darkness . When [Dunstan Cass]63-dunstan turned [his]63-dunstan back on [the cottage]616-the cottage , [Silas Marner]38-silas was not more than a hundred yards away from [it]616-the cottage , plodding along from [the village]247-the village with a sack thrown round [his]38-silas shoulders as an over - coat , and with a horn lantern in [his]38-silas hand . [His]38-silas legs were weary , but [his]38-silas mind was at ease , free from the presentiment of change . The sense of security more frequently springs from habit than from conviction , and for this reason it often subsists after such a change in the conditions as might have been expected to suggest alarm . The lapse of time during which a given event has not happened , is , in this logic of habit , constantly alleged as a reason why the event should never happen , even when the lapse of time is precisely the added condition which makes the event imminent . [A man]185-a man will tell [you]698-you that [he]185-a man has worked in [a mine]699-a mine for forty years unhurt by an accident , as a reason why [he]185-a man should apprehend no danger , though the roof is beginning to sink ; and it is often observable , that the older [a man]185-a man gets , the more difficult it is to [him]185-a man to retain a believing conception of [his]185-a man own death . This influence of habit was necessarily strong in [a man whose life was so monotonous as [Marner's]79-marner's — who saw [no new people and heard of no new events]702-no new people and heard of no new events to keep alive in [him]38-silas the idea of the unexpected and the changeful]701-a man whose life was so monotonous as marner's — who saw no new people and heard of no new events to keep alive in him the idea of the unexpected and the changeful ; and it explains , simply enough , why [his]38-silas mind could be at ease , though [he]38-silas had left [[his]38-silas house]703-his house and [[his]38-silas treasure]704-his treasure more defenceless than usual . [Silas]38-silas was thinking with double complacency of [his]38-silas supper : first , because it would be hot and savoury ; and , secondly , because it would cost [him]38-silas nothing . For the little bit of pork was a present from [that excellent housewife]705-that excellent housewife , [Miss Priscilla Lammeter]80-priscilla , to whom [he]38-silas had this day carried [home]374-home a handsome piece of linen ; and it was only on occasion of a present like this , that [Silas]38-silas indulged [himself]38-silas with roast - meat . Supper was [his]38-silas favourite meal , because it came at [his]38-silas time of revelry , when [his]38-silas heart warmed over [his]38-silas gold ; whenever [he]38-silas had roast - meat , [he]38-silas always chose to have it for supper . But this evening , [he]38-silas had no sooner ingeniously knotted [his]38-silas string fast round [his]38-silas bit of pork , twisted the string according to rule over [his]38-silas door - key , passed it through the handle , and made it fast on the hanger , than [he]38-silas remembered that a piece of very fine twine was indispensable to [his]38-silas " setting up "[81-mr lammeter] a new piece of work in [[his]38-silas loom]424-his loom early in the morning . It had slipped [his]38-silas memory , because , in coming from [[Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter 's]708-mr lammeter 's , [he]38-silas had not had to pass through [the village]247-the village ; but to lose time by going on errands in the morning was out of the question . It was a nasty fog to turn out into , but there were things [Silas]38-silas loved better than [his]38-silas own comfort ; so , drawing [his]38-silas pork to the extremity of the hanger , and arming [himself]38-silas with [his]38-silas lantern and [his]38-silas old sack , [he]38-silas set out on what , in ordinary weather , would have been a twenty minutes ' errand . [He]38-silas could not have locked [his]38-silas door without undoing [his]38-silas well - knotted string and retarding [his]38-silas supper ; it was not worth [his]38-silas while to make that sacrifice . What thief would find [his]38-silas way to [the Stone - pits]658-the stone - pits on such a night as this ? and why should [he]38-silas come on this particular night , when [he]38-silas had never come through all the twelve years before ? These questions were not distinctly present in [Silas]38-silas 's mind ; they merely serve to represent the vaguely - felt foundation of [his]38-silas freedom from anxiety . [He]38-silas reached [his]38-silas door in much satisfaction that [his]38-silas errand was done : [he]38-silas opened it , and to [his]38-silas short - sighted eyes everything remained as [he]38-silas had left [it]711-it , except that the fire sent out a welcome increase of heat . [He]38-silas trod about the floor while putting by [his]38-silas lantern and throwing aside [his]38-silas hat and sack , so as to merge the marks of [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's feet on the sand in the marks of [his]38-silas own nailed boots . Then [he]38-silas moved [his]38-silas pork nearer to the fire , and sat down to the agreeable business of tending the meat and warming [himself]38-silas at the same time . Any one who had looked at [him]38-silas as the red light shone upon [his]38-silas pale face , strange straining eyes , and meagre form , would perhaps have understood the mixture of contemptuous pity , dread , and suspicion with which [he]38-silas was regarded by [[his]38-silas neighbours]435-his neighbours in [Raveloe]1-raveloe . Yet [few men]713-few men could be more harmless than poor [Marner]38-silas . In [his]38-silas truthful simple soul , not even the growing greed and worship of gold could beget any vice directly injurious to [others]297-others . The light of [his]38-silas faith quite put out , and [his]38-silas affections made desolate , [he]38-silas had clung with all the force of [his]38-silas nature to [his]38-silas work and [his]38-silas money ; and like all objects to which [a man]185-a man devotes [himself]185-a man , [they]716-they had fashioned [him]185-a man into correspondence with [themselves]716-they . [His]38-silas loom , as [he]38-silas wrought in it without ceasing , had in its turn wrought on [him]38-silas , and confirmed more and more the monotonous craving for its monotonous response . [His]38-silas gold , as [he]38-silas hung over it and saw it grow , gathered [his]38-silas power of loving together into a hard isolation like its own . As soon as [he]38-silas was warm [he]38-silas began to think it would be a long while to wait till after supper before [he]38-silas drew out [his]38-silas guineas , and it would be pleasant to see them on the table before [him]38-silas as [he]38-silas ate [his]38-silas unwonted feast . For joy is the best of wine , and [Silas]38-silas 's guineas were a golden wine of that sort . [He]38-silas rose and placed [his]38-silas candle unsuspectingly on the floor near [his]38-silas loom , swept away the sand without noticing any change , and removed the bricks . The sight of the empty hole made [his]38-silas heart leap violently , but the belief that [his]38-silas gold was gone could not come at once — only terror , and the eager effort to put an end to the terror . [He]38-silas passed [his]38-silas trembling hand all about the hole , trying to think it possible that [his]38-silas eyes had deceived [him]38-silas ; then [he]38-silas held the candle in the hole and examined it curiously , trembling more and more . At last [he]38-silas shook so violently that [he]38-silas let fall the candle , and lifted [his]38-silas hands to [his]38-silas head , trying to steady [himself]38-silas , that [he]38-silas might think . Had [he]38-silas put [his]38-silas gold somewhere else , by a sudden resolution last night , and then forgotten it ? [A man falling into dark water]717-a man falling into dark water seeks a momentary footing even on sliding stones ; and [Silas]38-silas , by acting as if [he]38-silas believed in false hopes , warded off the moment of despair . [He]38-silas searched in every corner , [he]38-silas turned [his]38-silas bed over , and shook it , and kneaded it ; [he]38-silas looked in [[his]38-silas brick oven]718-his brick oven where [he]38-silas laid [his]38-silas sticks . When there was no other place to be searched , [he]38-silas kneeled down again and felt once more all round the hole . There was no untried refuge left for a moment 's shelter from the terrible truth . Yes , there was a sort of refuge which always comes with the prostration of thought under an overpowering passion : it was that expectation of impossibilities , that belief in contradictory images , which is still distinct from madness , because it is capable of being dissipated by the external fact . [Silas]38-silas got up from [his]38-silas knees trembling , and looked round at the table : did n't the gold lie there after all ? The table was bare . Then [he]38-silas turned and looked behind [him]38-silas — looked all round [[his]38-silas dwelling]719-his dwelling , seeming to strain [his]38-silas brown eyes after some possible appearance of the bags where [he]38-silas had already sought them in vain . [He]38-silas could see every object in [[his]38-silas cottage]458-his cottage — and [his]38-silas gold was not there . Again [he]38-silas put [his]38-silas trembling hands to [his]38-silas head , and gave a wild ringing scream , the cry of desolation . For a few moments after , [he]38-silas stood motionless ; but the cry had relieved [him]38-silas from the first maddening pressure of the truth . [He]38-silas turned , and tottered towards [his]38-silas loom , and got into the seat where [he]38-silas worked , instinctively seeking this as the strongest assurance of reality . And now that all the false hopes had vanished , and the first shock of certainty was past , the idea of [a thief]721-a thief began to present itself , and [he]38-silas entertained it eagerly , because [a thief]721-a thief might be caught and made to restore the gold . The thought brought some new strength with it , and [he]38-silas started from [his]38-silas loom to the door . As [he]38-silas opened it the rain beat in upon [him]38-silas , for it was falling more and more heavily . There were no footsteps to be tracked on such a night — footsteps ? When had [the thief]2049-the thief come ? During [Silas]38-silas 's absence in the daytime the door had been locked , and there had been no marks of any inroad on [his]38-silas return by daylight . And in the evening , too , [he]38-silas said to [himself]38-silas , everything was the same as when [he]38-silas had left [it]724-it . The sand and bricks looked as if they had not been moved . Was it [a thief who had taken the bags]725-a thief who had taken the bags ? or was it a cruel power that no hands could reach , which had delighted in making [him]38-silas a second time desolate ? [He]38-silas shrank from this vaguer dread , and fixed [his]38-silas mind with struggling effort on [the robber with hands , who could be reached by hands]726-the robber with hands , who could be reached by hands . [His]38-silas thoughts glanced at all [the neighbours who had made any remarks]727-the neighbours who had made any remarks , or asked any questions which [he]38-silas might now regard as a ground of suspicion . There was [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney , [a known poacher]728-a known poacher , and otherwise disreputable : [he]40-jem rodney had often met [Marner]38-silas in [his]40-jem rodney journeys across [the fields]303-the fields , and had said something jestingly about [the weaver]209-the weaver 's money ; nay , [he]40-jem rodney had once irritated [Marner]38-silas , by lingering at the fire when [he]40-jem rodney called to light [his]40-jem rodney pipe , instead of going about [his]40-jem rodney business . [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney was [the man]731-the man — there was ease in the thought . [Jem]40-jem rodney could be found and made to restore the money : [Marner]38-silas did not want to punish [him]40-jem rodney , but only to get back [his]40-jem rodney gold which had gone from [him]40-jem rodney , and left [his]40-jem rodney soul like [a forlorn traveller on [an unknown desert]733-an unknown desert]732-a forlorn traveller on an unknown desert . [The robber]734-the robber must be laid hold of . [Marner]38-silas 's ideas of legal authority were confused , but [he]38-silas felt that [he]38-silas must go and proclaim [his]38-silas loss ; and [the great people in [the village]247-the village]735-the great people in the village — [the clergyman]737-the clergyman , [the constable]738-the constable , and [Squire Cass]58-squire cass — would make [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney , or [somebody else]739-somebody else , deliver up the stolen money . [He]38-silas rushed out in the rain , under the stimulus of this hope , forgetting to cover [his]38-silas head , not caring to fasten [his]38-silas door ; for [he]38-silas felt as if [he]38-silas had nothing left to lose . [He]38-silas ran swiftly till want of breath compelled [him]38-silas to slacken [his]38-silas pace as [he]38-silas was entering [the village]247-the village at the turning close to [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow . [The Rainbow]741-the rainbow , in [Marner]38-silas 's view , was [a place of luxurious resort for [rich and stout husbands]743-rich and stout husbands , whose wives had [superfluous stores of linen]744-superfluous stores of linen]742-a place of luxurious resort for rich and stout husbands , whose wives had superfluous stores of linen ; it was [the place where [he]38-silas was likely to find the powers and dignities of [Raveloe]1-raveloe , and where [he]38-silas could most speedily make [his]38-silas loss public]745-the place where he was likely to find the powers and dignities of raveloe , and where he could most speedily make his loss public . [He]38-silas lifted the latch , and turned into the bright bar or [kitchen]536-kitchen on the right hand , where [the less lofty customers of [the house]334-the house]747-the less lofty customers of the house were in the habit of assembling , [the parlour on the left]749-the parlour on the left being reserved for the more select society in which [Squire Cass]58-squire cass frequently enjoyed the double pleasure of conviviality and condescension . But [the parlour]750-the parlour was dark to - night , [the chief personages who ornamented [its]750-the parlour circle]751-the chief personages who ornamented its circle being all at [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's birthday dance , as [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey was . And in consequence of this , the party on the high - screened seats in [the kitchen]752-the kitchen was more numerous than usual ; [several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour and enlarged the opportunity of hectoring and condescension for [their]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour betters , being content this evening to vary [their]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour enjoyment by taking [their]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour spirits - and - water where [they]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour could [themselves]753-several personages , who would otherwise have been admitted into the parlour hector and condescend in company that called for beer . The conversation , which was at a high pitch of animation when [Silas]38-silas approached the door of [the Rainbow]741-the rainbow , had , as usual , been slow and intermittent when [the company]755-the company first assembled . The pipes began to be puffed in a silence which had an air of severity ; [the more important customers]756-the more important customers , who drank spirits and sat nearest the fire , staring at [each other as if a bet]757-each other as if a bet were depending on [the first man who winked]758-the first man who winked ; while [the beer - drinkers]759-the beer - drinkers , [chiefly men in fustian jackets and smock - frocks]760-chiefly men in fustian jackets and smock - frocks , kept [their]759-the beer - drinkers eyelids down and rubbed [their]759-the beer - drinkers hands across [their]759-the beer - drinkers mouths , as if [their]759-the beer - drinkers draughts of beer were a funereal duty attended with embarrassing sadness . At last , [Mr Snell]82-mr snell , [the landlord]761-the landlord , [a man of a neutral disposition]762-a man of a neutral disposition , accustomed to stand aloof from human differences as those of [beings who were all alike in need of liquor]763-beings who were all alike in need of liquor , broke silence , by saying in a doubtful tone to [[his]761-the landlord cousin]764-his cousin [the butcher]765-the butcher , — " [Some folks]2101-some folks ' ud say that was a fine beast [you]761-the landlord druv in yesterday , [Bob]72-bob ? "[765-the butcher] [The butcher]765-the butcher , [a jolly , smiling , red - haired man]767-a jolly , smiling , red - haired man , was not disposed to answer rashly . [He]765-the butcher gave a few puffs before [he]765-the butcher spat and replied , " And [they]2102-they would n't be fur wrong , [John]83-john . "[765-the butcher] After this feeble delusive thaw , the silence set in as severely as before . " Was it [a red Durham]2103-a red durham ? "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier , taking up the thread of discourse after the lapse of a few minutes . [The farrier]768-the farrier looked at [the landlord]761-the landlord , and [the landlord]761-the landlord looked at [the butcher]765-the butcher , as [the person who must take the responsibility of answering]773-the person who must take the responsibility of answering . And [she]2105-she 'd a white star on [her]2105-she brow , [I]768-the farrier 'll bet a penny ? " Well ; yes — [she]2105-she might , "[765-the butcher] said [the butcher]765-the butcher , slowly , considering that [he]765-the butcher was giving a decided affirmative . " [I]765-the butcher do n't say contrairy . "[765-the butcher] " [I]768-the farrier knew that very well , "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier , throwing [himself]768-the farrier backward again , and speaking defiantly ; " if [I]768-the farrier do n't know [Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter 's cows , [I]768-the farrier should like to know who does — that 's all . And as for the cow [you]765-the butcher 've bought , bargain or no bargain , [I]768-the farrier 've been at the drenching of [her]2105-she — contradick [me]768-the farrier who will . "[768-the farrier] [The farrier]768-the farrier looked fierce , and [the mild butcher]780-the mild butcher 's conversational spirit was roused a little . " [I]768-the farrier 'm not for contradicking [no man]248-no man , "[768-the farrier] [he]768-the farrier said ; " [I]768-the farrier 'm for peace and quietness . And for the matter o ' that , if the talk is to be o ' [the Lammeters]68-the lammeters , [you]765-the butcher know the most upo ' that head , eh , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? "[761-the landlord] [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , [tailor]786-tailor and [parish - clerk]787-parish - clerk , the latter of which functions rheumatism had of late obliged [him]41-mr macey to share with [a small - featured young man who sat opposite [him]41-mr macey , held [his]788-a small - featured young man who sat opposite him , held his white head on one side , and twirled his thumbs with an air of complacency , slightly seasoned with criticism white head on one side , and twirled [his]788-a small - featured young man who sat opposite him , held his white head on one side , and twirled his thumbs with an air of complacency , slightly seasoned with criticism thumbs with an air of complacency , slightly seasoned with criticism]788-a small - featured young man who sat opposite him , held his white head on one side , and twirled his thumbs with an air of complacency , slightly seasoned with criticism . [He]41-mr macey smiled pityingly , in answer to [the landlord]761-the landlord 's appeal , and said — " Ay , ay ; [I]41-mr macey know , [I]41-mr macey know ; but [I]41-mr macey let [other folks]2119-other folks talk . [Mr Tookey]84-tookey , [the deputy - clerk]790-the deputy - clerk , who shared the unpopularity common to [deputies]796-deputies , turned very red , but replied , with careful moderation — " [Mr Winthrop]85-mr winthrop , if [you]85-mr winthrop 'll bring [me]790-the deputy - clerk any proof as [I]790-the deputy - clerk 'm in the wrong , [I]790-the deputy - clerk 'm not [the man to say [I]790-the deputy - clerk wo n't alter]2124-the man to say i wo n't alter . "[87-ben winthrop] This kind of unflinching frankness was the most piquant form of joke to [the company at [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow]797-the company at the rainbow , and [Ben Winthrop]87-ben winthrop 's insult was felt by [everybody]446-everybody to have capped [Mr Macey]41-mr macey 's epigram . " [I]84-tookey see what it is plain enough , "[84-tookey] said [Mr Tookey]84-tookey , unable to keep cool any longer . "[87-ben winthrop] " Come , come , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , who felt that paying [people]387-people for [their]387-people absence was a principle dangerous to [society]801-society ; " a joke 's a joke . [We]2139-we 're [all good friends]2142-all good friends [here]2143-here , [I]761-the landlord hope . [We]2139-we must give and take . [You]84-tookey 're both right and [you]84-tookey 're both wrong , as [I]761-the landlord say .
