[Tookey]84-tookey 's right and [Winthrop]87-ben winthrop 's right , and [they]2145-they 've only got to split the difference and make [themselves]2145-they even . "[761-the landlord] [The farrier]768-the farrier was puffing [his]768-the farrier pipe rather fiercely , in some contempt at this trivial discussion . [He]768-the farrier had no ear for music [himself]768-the farrier , and never went to [church]363-church , as being of the medical profession , and likely to be in requisition for delicate cows . But [the butcher]765-the butcher , having music in [his]765-the butcher soul , had listened with a divided desire for [Tookey]84-tookey 's defeat , and for the preservation of the peace . " To be sure , "[765-the butcher] [he]765-the butcher said , following up [the landlord]761-the landlord 's conciliatory view , " [we]2146-we 're fond of [[our]2146-we old clerk]2147-our old clerk ; it 's [nat'ral]90-nat'ral , and [him]2147-our old clerk used to be such [a singer]2148-a singer , and got [a brother]2149-a brother as is known for [the first fiddler in [this country - side]2104-this country - side . Eh , it 's a pity but what [Solomon]91-solomon lived in [[our]2146-we village]2152-our village]2150-the first fiddler in this country - side . eh , it 's a pity but what solomon lived in our village , and could give [us]2146-we a tune when [we]2146-we liked ; eh , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? [I]765-the butcher 'd keep [him]2147-our old clerk in liver and lights for nothing — that [I]765-the butcher would . "[765-the butcher] " Ay , ay , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , in the height of complacency ; " [[our]2146-we family]2153-our family 's been known for [musicianers]2154-musicianers as far back as [anybody]263-anybody can tell . But [them]2153-our family things are dying out , as [I]41-mr macey tell [Solomon]91-solomon every time [he]2147-our old clerk comes round ; there 's no voices like what there used to be , and there 's [nobody]444-nobody remembers what [we]2146-we remember , if it is n't [the old crows]2157-the old crows . "[41-mr macey] " Ay , [you]765-the butcher remember when [first [Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter 's father]2116-first mr lammeter 's father came into [these parts]2117-these parts , do n't [you]765-the butcher , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord . " [I]330-the old man should think [I]330-the old man did , "[330-the old man] said [the old man]330-the old man , who had now gone through that complimentary process necessary to bring [him]330-the old man up to the point of narration ; " and [a fine old gentleman]2160-a fine old gentleman [he]2160-a fine old gentleman was — as fine , and finer nor [the Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter as now is . [He]2160-a fine old gentleman came from a bit [north'ard]3-north'ard , so far as [I]330-the old man could ever make out . But there 's [nobody]444-nobody rightly knows about [those parts]2162-those parts : only it could n't be [far north'ard]2163-far north'ard , nor much different from [this country]2164-this country , for [he]2160-a fine old gentleman brought a fine breed o ' sheep with [him]2160-a fine old gentleman , so there must be [pastures]2165-pastures [there]2073-there , and everything reasonable . [We]2167-we heared tell as [he]2160-a fine old gentleman 'd sold [his]2160-a fine old gentleman own land to come and take [the Warrens]2118-the warrens , and that seemed odd for [a man]185-a man as had land of [his]2160-a fine old gentleman own , to come and rent [a farm]2170-a farm in [a strange place]2171-a strange place . But [they]2172-they said it was along of [[his]2160-a fine old gentleman wife]223-his wife 's dying ; though there 's reasons in things as [nobody]444-nobody knows on — that 's pretty much what [I]330-the old man 've made out ; though [some folks]2101-some folks are so wise , [they]2101-some folks 'll find [you]2176-you fifty reasons straight off , and all the while the real reason 's winking at ['em]2177-'em in the corner , and [they]2101-some folks niver see't . [Howsomever]92-howsomever , it was soon seen as [we]2167-we 'd got [a new parish'ner]2178-a new parish'ner as know'd the rights and customs o ' things , and kep [a good house]2179-a good house , and was well looked on by [everybody]446-everybody . And [the young man]2181-the young man — that 's [the Mr Lammeter]2182-the mr lammeter as now is , for [he]2181-the young man 'd niver [a sister]2183-a sister — soon begun to court [Miss Osgood]52-mrs osgood , that 's [the sister o ' [the Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood]2184-the sister o ' the mr osgood as now is , and [a fine handsome lass]2185-a fine handsome lass [she]2185-a fine handsome lass was — eh , [you]2176-you ca n't think — [they]2101-some folks pretend [this young lass]2186-this young lass is like [her]2185-a fine handsome lass , but that 's the way [wi ' people]2187-wi ' people as do n't know what come before ['em]2188-'em . [I]330-the old man should know , for [I]330-the old man helped [the old rector]2189-the old rector , [Mr Drumlow]93-mr drumlow as was , [I]330-the old man helped [him]93-mr drumlow marry ['em]2188-'em . "[330-the old man] Here [Mr Macey]41-mr macey paused ; [he]41-mr macey always gave [his]41-mr macey narrative in instalments , expecting to be questioned according to precedent . " Ay , and a partic'lar thing happened , did n't it , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , so as [you]41-mr macey were likely to remember that marriage ? "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , in a congratulatory tone . " [I]41-mr macey should think there did — a very partic'lar thing , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , nodding sideways . " For [Mr Drumlow]93-mr drumlow — [poor old gentleman]2190-poor old gentleman , [I]41-mr macey was fond on [him]93-mr drumlow , though [he]93-mr drumlow 'd got a bit confused in [his]93-mr drumlow head , what wi ' age and wi ' taking a drop o ' summat warm when the service come of a cold morning . And [young Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter , [he]93-mr drumlow 'd have no way but [he]93-mr drumlow must be married in Janiwary , which , to be sure , 's a unreasonable time to be married in , for it is n't like a christening or a burying , as [you]41-mr macey ca n't help ; and so [Mr Drumlow]93-mr drumlow — [poor old gentleman]2190-poor old gentleman , [I]41-mr macey was fond on [him]93-mr drumlow — but when [he]93-mr drumlow come to put the questions , [he]93-mr drumlow put ['em]2192-'em by the rule o ' contrairy , like , and [he]93-mr drumlow says , ' Wilt [thou]2193-thou have [this man]2194-this man to [[thy]2193-thou wedded wife]2195-thy wedded wife ? ' says [he]93-mr drumlow , and then [he]93-mr drumlow says , ' Wilt [thou]2193-thou have [this woman]2196-this woman to [[thy]2193-thou wedded husband]2197-thy wedded husband ? ' says [he]93-mr drumlow . But the partic'larest thing of all is , as [nobody]444-nobody took any notice on it but [me]41-mr macey , and [they]444-nobody answered straight off ' yes , ' like as if it had been [me]41-mr macey saying ' Amen ' [i]41-mr macey ' the right place , without listening to what went before . "[41-mr macey] " But [you]41-mr macey knew what was going on well enough , did n't [you]41-mr macey , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? [You]41-mr macey were live enough , eh ? "[765-the butcher] said [the butcher]765-the butcher . " Lor bless [you]41-mr macey ! "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , pausing , and smiling in pity at the impotence of [[his]41-mr macey hearers]810-his hearers ' imagination—"why , [I]41-mr macey was all of a tremble : it was as if [I]41-mr macey 'd been a coat pulled by the two tails , like ; for [I]41-mr macey could n't stop [the parson]273-the parson , [I]41-mr macey could n't take upon [me]41-mr macey to do that ; and yet [I]41-mr macey said to [myself]41-mr macey , [I]41-mr macey says , ' Suppose [they]810-his hearers should n't be fast married , 'cause the words are contrairy ? ' and [my]41-mr macey head went working like a mill , for [I]41-mr macey was allays uncommon for turning things over and seeing all round ['em]2200-'em ; and [I]41-mr macey says to [myself]41-mr macey , ' Is't the meanin ' or the words as makes [folks]214-folks fast [i]41-mr macey ' wedlock ? ' For [the parson]273-the parson meant right , and [the bride]2203-the bride and [bridegroom]2204-bridegroom meant right . But then , when [I]41-mr macey come to think on it , meanin ' goes but a little way [i]41-mr macey ' most things , for [you]2205-you may mean to stick things together and [your]2205-you glue may be bad , and then where are [you]2205-you ? And so [I]41-mr macey says to [mysen]41-mr macey , ' It is n't the meanin ' , it 's the glue . ' And [I]41-mr macey was worreted as if [I]41-mr macey 'd got three bells to pull at once , when [we]2206-we got into [the vestry]339-the vestry , and [they]339-the vestry begun to sign [their]339-the vestry names . But where 's the o ' talking ? — [you]2205-you ca n't think what goes on in [a ' cute man]2208-a ' cute man 's inside . "[41-mr macey] " But [you]41-mr macey held in for all that , did n't [you]41-mr macey , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord . " Ay , [I]761-the landlord held in tight till [I]761-the landlord was by [mysen]761-the landlord wi ' [Mr Drumlow]93-mr drumlow , and then [I]761-the landlord out wi ' everything , but respectful , as [I]761-the landlord allays did . And [he]93-mr drumlow made light on it , and [he]93-mr drumlow says , ' Pooh , pooh , [Macey]41-mr macey , make [yourself]41-mr macey easy , ' [he]93-mr drumlow says , ' it 's neither the meaning nor the words — it 's [the regester]2209-the regester does it — that 's the glue . ' So [you]2205-you see [he]93-mr drumlow settled it easy ; for [parsons]2210-parsons and [doctors]2211-doctors know everything by heart , like , so as [they]814-the listeners are n't worreted wi ' thinking what 's the rights and wrongs o ' things , as [I'n]761-the landlord been many and many 's the time . And sure enough the wedding turned out all right , [on'y poor [Mrs Lammeter]52-mrs osgood — that 's [Miss Osgood]52-mrs osgood as was]52-mrs osgood — died afore [the lasses]2212-the lasses were growed up ; but for prosperity and everything respectable , there 's [no family]2213-no family more looked on . "[761-the landlord] [Every one of [[Mr Macey]41-mr macey 's audience]813-mr macey 's audience]812-every one of mr macey 's audience had heard this story many times , but it was listened to as if it had been a favourite tune , and at certain points the puffing of the pipes was momentarily suspended , that [the listeners]814-the listeners might give [their]814-the listeners whole minds to the expected words . But there was more to come ; and [Mr Snell]82-mr snell , [the landlord]761-the landlord , duly put the leading question . " Why , [old Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter had a pretty fortin , did n't [they]2214-they say , when [he]81-mr lammeter come into [these parts]2117-these parts ? "[82-mr snell] " Well , yes , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ; " but [I]41-mr macey daresay it 's as much as this [Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter 's done to keep it whole . For there was allays a talk as [nobody]444-nobody could get rich on [the Warrens]17-the warrens : though [he]81-mr lammeter holds it cheap , for it 's what [they]2214-they call [Charity Land]16-charity land . "[41-mr macey] " Ay , and there 's [few folks]2217-few folks know so well as [you]41-mr macey how it come to be [Charity Land]16-charity land , eh , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? "[765-the butcher] said [the butcher]765-the butcher . " How should [they]2214-they ? "[817-the old clerk] said [the old clerk]817-the old clerk , with some contempt . " Why , [[my]817-the old clerk grandfather]2218-my grandfather made [the grooms]2219-the grooms ' livery for that [Mr Cliff]95-cliff as came and built [the big stables]2220-the big stables at [the Warrens]17-the warrens . Why , [they]2220-the big stables 're [stables]2221-stables four times as big as [Squire Cass]58-squire cass 's , for [he]81-mr lammeter thought o ' nothing but hosses and hunting , [Cliff]95-cliff didn't — [a Lunnon tailor]2222-a lunnon tailor , [some folks]2101-some folks said , as had gone mad wi ' cheating . For [he]81-mr lammeter could n't ride ; lor bless [you]41-mr macey ! [they]2214-they said [he]81-mr lammeter 'd got no more grip o ' the hoss than if [his]81-mr lammeter legs had been cross sticks : [[my]817-the old clerk grandfather]2218-my grandfather heared [old Squire Cass]58-squire cass say so many and many a time . But ride [he]81-mr lammeter would , as if [old Harry]96-old harry had been a - driving [him]81-mr lammeter ; and [he]81-mr lammeter 'd [a son]2225-a son , [a lad o ' sixteen]2226-a lad o ' sixteen ; and nothing would [[his]81-mr lammeter father]592-his father have [him]81-mr lammeter do , but [he]81-mr lammeter must ride and ride — though [the lad]2228-the lad was frighted , [they]2214-they said . And it was a common saying as [the father]2229-the father wanted to ride [the tailor]2230-the tailor out o ' [the lad]2228-the lad , and make [a gentleman]2232-a gentleman on [him]2228-the lad — not but what [I]817-the old clerk 'm [a tailor]2233-a tailor [myself]817-the old clerk , but in respect as [God]48-god made [me]817-the old clerk such , [I]817-the old clerk 'm proud on it , for ' [Macey]41-mr macey , [tailor]786-tailor , ' 's been wrote up over [our]2235-our door since afore [the Queen]2236-the queen 's heads went out on the shillings . But [Cliff]95-cliff , [he]95-cliff was ashamed o ' being called [a tailor]2233-a tailor , and [he]95-cliff was sore vexed as [his]95-cliff riding was laughed at , and [nobody o ' the gentlefolks]2238-nobody o ' the gentlefolks hereabout could abide [him]95-cliff . [Howsomever]92-howsomever , [the poor lad]2239-the poor lad got sickly and died , and [the father]2229-the father did n't live long after [him]2239-the poor lad , for [he]95-cliff got queerer nor ever , and [they]2241-they said [he]95-cliff used to go out [i]817-the old clerk ' the dead o ' the night , wi ' a lantern in [his]95-cliff hand , to [the stables]2084-the stables , and set a lot o ' lights burning , for [he]95-cliff got as [he]95-cliff could n't sleep ; and there [he]95-cliff 'd stand , cracking [his]95-cliff whip and looking at [his]95-cliff hosses ; and [they]2241-they said it was a mercy as [the stables]2084-the stables did n't get burnt down wi ' [the poor dumb creaturs]2244-the poor dumb creaturs in ['em]2245-'em . But at last [he]95-cliff died raving , and [they]2241-they found as [he]95-cliff 'd left all [[his]95-cliff property]2246-his property , [Warrens]17-the warrens and all , to a [Lunnon Charity]19-lunnon charity , and that 's how [the Warrens]17-the warrens come to be [[Charity]20-charity land]2247-charity land ; though , as for [the stables]2084-the stables , [Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter never uses 'em — they're out o ' all charicter — lor bless [you]2249-you ! if [you]2249-you was to set the doors a - banging in 'em , it ' ud sound like thunder half o'er [the parish]262-the parish . "[817-the old clerk] " Ay , but there 's more going on in [the stables]2084-the stables than what [folks]214-folks see by daylight , eh , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ? "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord . " Ay , ay ; go that way of a dark night , that 's all , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , winking mysteriously , " and then make believe , if [you]2249-you like , as [you]2249-you did n't see lights [i]41-mr macey ' [the stables]2084-the stables , nor hear the stamping o ' the hosses , nor the cracking o ' the whips , and howling , too , if it 's tow'rt daybreak . ' [Cliff]95-cliff 's Holiday ' has been the name of it ever sin ' [I]41-mr macey were [a boy]2254-a boy ; that 's to say , [some]260-some said as it was the holiday [Old Harry]96-old harry gev [him]41-mr macey from roasting , like . That 's what [[my]41-mr macey father]2068-my father told [me]41-mr macey , and [he]2068-my father was [a reasonable man]2257-a reasonable man , though there 's [folks]214-folks nowadays know what happened afore [they]214-folks were born better nor [they]214-folks know [their]214-folks own business . "[41-mr macey] " What do [you]97-dowlas say to that , eh , [Dowlas]97-dowlas ? "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , turning to [the farrier]768-the farrier , who was swelling with impatience for [his]768-the farrier cue . " There 's a nut for [you]97-dowlas to crack . "[768-the farrier] [Mr Dowlas]97-dowlas was the negative spirit in [the company]755-the company , and was proud of [his]97-dowlas position . " Say ? [I]97-dowlas say what [a man]185-a man should say as does n't shut [his]185-a man eyes to look at a finger - post . [I]97-dowlas say , as [I]97-dowlas 'm ready to wager [any man]2260-any man ten pound , if [he]185-a man 'll stand out wi ' [me]97-dowlas any dry night in [the pasture before [the Warren stables]2262-the warren stables]2261-the pasture before the warren stables , as [we]2263-we shall neither see lights nor hear noises , if it is n't the blowing of [our]2263-we own noses . That 's what [I]97-dowlas say , and [I]97-dowlas 've said it many a time ; but there 's [nobody ' ull ventur]2264-nobody ' ull ventur a ten - pun ' note on [their]2264-nobody ' ull ventur ghos'es as [they]2264-nobody ' ull ventur make so sure of . "[97-dowlas] " Why , [Dowlas]97-dowlas , that 's easy betting , that is , "[87-ben winthrop] said [Ben Winthrop]87-ben winthrop . " [You]97-dowlas might as well bet [a man]185-a man as [he]185-a man would n't catch the rheumatise if [he]185-a man stood up to 's neck in the pool of a frosty night . It ' ud be fine fun for [a man]185-a man to win [his]185-a man bet as [he]185-a man 'd catch the rheumatise . [Folks]214-folks as believe in [[Cliff]95-cliff 's Holiday]2268-cliff 's holiday are n't agoing to ventur near [it]2268-cliff 's holiday for a matter o ' ten pound . "[87-ben winthrop] " If [Master Dowlas]97-dowlas wants to know the truth on it , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , with a sarcastic smile , tapping [his]41-mr macey thumbs together , " [he]97-dowlas 's no call to lay any bet — let [him]97-dowlas go and [stan]2269-stan ' by [himself]97-dowlas — there 's [nobody]444-nobody ' ull hinder [him]97-dowlas ; and then [he]97-dowlas can let [the parish'ners]2271-the parish'ners know if [they]2271-the parish'ners 're wrong . "[41-mr macey] " Thank [you]97-dowlas ! [I]768-the farrier 'm obliged to [you]97-dowlas , "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier , with a snort of scorn . " If [folks]214-folks are [fools]2273-fools , it 's no business o ' [mine]768-the farrier . [I]768-the farrier do n't want to make out the truth about ghos'es : [I]768-the farrier know it a'ready . But [I]768-the farrier 'm not against a bet — everything fair and open . Let [any man]2260-any man bet [me]768-the farrier ten pound as [I]768-the farrier shall see [Cliff 's Holiday]21-cliff 's holiday , and [I]768-the farrier 'll go and stand by [myself]768-the farrier . [I]768-the farrier want [no company]2275-no company . [I]768-the farrier 'd as lief do it as [I]768-the farrier 'd fill this pipe . "[768-the farrier] " Ah , but who 's to watch [you]97-dowlas , [Dowlas]97-dowlas , and see [you]97-dowlas do it ? That 's no fair bet , "[765-the butcher] said [the butcher]765-the butcher . " No fair bet ? "[97-dowlas] replied [Mr Dowlas]97-dowlas , angrily . " [I]97-dowlas should like to hear [any man]2260-any man stand up and say [I]97-dowlas want to bet unfair . Come now , [Master Lundy]98-master lundy , [I]97-dowlas should like to hear [you]97-dowlas say it . "[97-dowlas] " Very like [you]97-dowlas would , "[765-the butcher] said [the butcher]765-the butcher . " But it 's no business o ' [mine]97-dowlas . [You]97-dowlas 're none o ' [my]765-the butcher bargains , and [I]765-the butcher are n't a - going to try and ' bate [your]97-dowlas price . If [anybody]263-anybody 'll bid for [you]97-dowlas at [[your]97-dowlas own vallying]2278-your own vallying , let [him]263-anybody . "[765-the butcher] " Yes , that 's what [every yapping cur]2279-every yapping cur is , when [you]97-dowlas hold a stick up at [him]2279-every yapping cur , "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier . " But [I]768-the farrier 'm afraid [o]2280-o ' [neither man nor ghost]2281-neither man nor ghost , and [I]768-the farrier 'm ready to lay a fair bet — [I]768-the farrier are n't [a turn - tail cur]2282-a turn - tail cur . "[768-the farrier] " Ay , but there 's this in it , [Dowlas]97-dowlas , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , speaking in a tone of much candour and tolerance . " There 's [folks]214-folks , [i]761-the landlord ' [my]761-the landlord opinion , [they]214-folks ca n't see ghos'es , not if [they]214-folks stood as plain as a pike - staff before 'em . And there 's reason [i]761-the landlord ' that . For there 's [[my]761-the landlord wife]2284-my wife , now , ca n't smell , not if [she]2284-my wife 'd the strongest o ' cheese under [her]2284-my wife nose . [I]761-the landlord never see'd [a ghost]2285-a ghost [myself]761-the landlord , but then [I]761-the landlord says to [myself]761-the landlord , ' Very like [I]761-the landlord have n't got the smell for 'em . ' [I]761-the landlord mean , putting a ghost for a smell , or else contrairiways . And so , [I]761-the landlord 'm for holding with both sides ; for , as [I]761-the landlord say , the truth lies between 'em . And if [Dowlas]97-dowlas was to go and stand , and say [he]97-dowlas 'd never seen a wink o ' [Cliff 's Holiday]21-cliff 's holiday all the night through , [I]761-the landlord 'd back [him]97-dowlas ; and if [anybody]263-anybody said as [Cliff]95-cliff 's Holiday was certain sure , for all that , [I]761-the landlord 'd back [him]97-dowlas too . For the smell 's what [I]761-the landlord go by . "[761-the landlord] [The landlord]761-the landlord 's analogical argument was not well received by [the farrier]768-the farrier — [a man intensely opposed to compromise]829-a man intensely opposed to compromise . " Tut , tut , "[768-the farrier] [he]768-the farrier said , setting down [his]768-the farrier glass with refreshed irritation ; " what 's the smell got to do with it ? Did ever [a ghost]2285-a ghost give [a man]185-a man a black eye ? That 's what [I]768-the farrier should like to know . If ghos'es want [me]768-the farrier to believe in 'em , let ['em]2289-'em leave off skulking [i]768-the farrier ' the dark and [i]768-the farrier ' lone places — let 'em come where there 's [company]2290-company and candles . "[768-the farrier] " As if ghos'es ' ud want to be believed in by [anybody so ignirant]2291-anybody so ignirant ! "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , in deep disgust at [the farrier]768-the farrier 's crass incompetence to apprehend the conditions of ghostly phenomena . Yet the next moment there seemed to be some evidence that ghosts had a more condescending disposition than [Mr Macey]41-mr macey attributed to [them]831-them ; for the pale thin figure of [Silas Marner]38-silas was suddenly seen standing in the warm light , uttering no word , but looking round at [the company]755-the company with [his]38-silas strange unearthly eyes . The long pipes gave a simultaneous movement , like the antennæ of startled insects , and [every man present]833-every man present , not excepting even [the sceptical farrier]834-the sceptical farrier , had an impression that [he]768-the farrier saw , not [Silas Marner]38-silas in the flesh , but an apparition ; for the door by which [Silas]38-silas had entered was hidden by the high - screened seats , and [no one]182-no one had noticed [his]38-silas approach . [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , sitting a long way off [the ghost]836-the ghost , might be supposed to have felt an argumentative triumph , which would tend to neutralise [his]41-mr macey share of the general alarm . Had [he]41-mr macey not always said that when [Silas Marner]38-silas was in that strange trance of [his]41-mr macey , [his]38-silas soul went loose from [his]38-silas body ? Here was the demonstration : nevertheless , on the whole , [he]41-mr macey would have been as well contented without it . For a few moments there was a dead silence , [Marner]38-silas 's want of breath and agitation not allowing [him]38-silas to speak . [The landlord]761-the landlord , under the habitual sense that [he]761-the landlord was bound to keep [[his]761-the landlord house]703-his house open to all company , and confident in the protection of [his]761-the landlord unbroken neutrality , at last took on [himself]761-the landlord the task of adjuring [the ghost]836-the ghost . " [Master Marner]42-master marner , "[761-the landlord] [he]761-the landlord said , in a conciliatory tone , " what 's lacking to [you]42-master marner ? What 's [your]42-master marner business here ? "[761-the landlord] " Robbed ! "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , gaspingly . " [I]38-silas 've been robbed ! [I]38-silas want [the constable]738-the constable — and [the Justice]2293-the justice — and [Squire Cass]58-squire cass — and [Mr Crackenthorp]86-mr crackenthorp . "[38-silas] " Lay hold on [him]40-jem rodney , [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , the idea of a ghost subsiding ; " [he]40-jem rodney 's off [his]40-jem rodney head , [I]761-the landlord doubt . [He]40-jem rodney 's wet through . "[761-the landlord] [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney was [the outermost man]841-the outermost man , and sat conveniently near [Marner]38-silas 's standing - place ; but [he]40-jem rodney declined to give [his]40-jem rodney services . " Come and lay hold on [him]40-jem rodney [yourself]38-silas , [Mr Snell]82-mr snell , if [you]38-silas 've a mind , "[40-jem rodney] said [Jem]40-jem rodney , rather sullenly . " [He]40-jem rodney 's been robbed , and murdered too , for what [I]40-jem rodney know , "[40-jem rodney] [he]40-jem rodney added , in a muttering tone . " [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney ! "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , turning and fixing [his]38-silas strange eyes on [the suspected man]842-the suspected man . " Ay , [Master Marner]42-master marner , what do [you]42-master marner want wi ' [me]40-jem rodney ? "[40-jem rodney] said [Jem]40-jem rodney , trembling a little , and seizing [his]40-jem rodney drinking - can as a defensive weapon . " If it was [you]42-master marner stole [my]38-silas money , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , clasping [his]38-silas hands entreatingly , and raising [his]38-silas voice to a cry , " give it [me]38-silas back,—and [I]38-silas wo n't meddle with [you]42-master marner . [I]38-silas wo n't set [the constable]738-the constable on [you]42-master marner . Give it [me]38-silas back , and [I]38-silas 'll let [you]42-master marner — [I'll]38-silas let [you]42-master marner have a guinea . " [I]40-jem rodney 'll pitch this can at [your]761-the landlord eye if [you]761-the landlord talk o ' [my]40-jem rodney stealing [your]761-the landlord money . "[40-jem rodney] " Come , come , [Master Marner]42-master marner , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , now rising resolutely , and seizing [Marner]38-silas by the shoulder , " if [you]42-master marner 've got any information to lay , speak it out sensible , and show as [you]42-master marner 're in [your]42-master marner right mind , if [you]42-master marner expect [anybody]263-anybody to listen to [you]42-master marner . [You]42-master marner 're as wet as a drownded rat . Sit down and dry [yourself]42-master marner , and speak straight forrard . "[761-the landlord] " Ah , to be sure , [man]361-man , "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier , who began to feel that [he]768-the farrier had not been quite on a par with [himself]768-the farrier and the occasion . " Let 's have no more staring and screaming , else [we]2297-we 'll have [you]42-master marner strapped for [a madman]2298-a madman . That was why [I]768-the farrier did n't speak at the first — thinks [I]768-the farrier , [the man]731-the man 's run mad . "[768-the farrier] " Ay , ay , make [him]731-the man sit down , "[761-the landlord] said several voices at once , well pleased that the reality of ghosts remained still an open question . [The landlord]761-the landlord forced [Marner]38-silas to take off [his]38-silas coat , and then to sit down on a chair aloof from every one else , in the centre of the circle , and in the direct rays of the fire . [The weaver]209-the weaver , too feeble to have any distinct purpose beyond that of getting help to recover [his]209-the weaver money , submitted unresistingly . The transient fears of [the company]755-the company were now forgotten in [their]755-the company strong curiosity , and all faces were turned towards [Silas]38-silas , when [the landlord]761-the landlord , having seated [himself]761-the landlord again , said — " Now then , [Master Marner]42-master marner , what 's this [you]42-master marner 've got to say , as [you]42-master marner 've been robbed ? speak out . "[761-the landlord] " [He]731-the man 'd better not say again as it was [me]40-jem rodney robbed [him]731-the man , "[40-jem rodney] cried [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney , hastily . " What could [I]40-jem rodney ha ' done with [his]731-the man money ? [I]40-jem rodney could as easy steal [the parson]273-the parson 's surplice , and wear it . "[40-jem rodney] " Hold [your]40-jem rodney tongue , [Jem]40-jem rodney , and let 's hear what [he]731-the man 's got to say , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord . " Now then , [Master Marner]42-master marner . "[761-the landlord] [Silas]38-silas now told [his]38-silas story under frequent questioning , as the mysterious character of the robbery became evident . This strangely novel situation of opening [his]38-silas trouble to [[his]38-silas Raveloe neighbours]850-his raveloe neighbours , of sitting in the warmth of [a hearth not [his]38-silas own]851-a hearth not his own , and feeling the presence of faces and voices which were [his]38-silas nearest promise of help , had doubtless its influence on [Marner]38-silas , in spite of [his]38-silas passionate preoccupation with [his]38-silas loss . [Our]852-us consciousness rarely registers the beginning of a growth within [us]852-us any more than without [us]852-us : there have been many circulations of the sap before [we]852-us detect the smallest sign of the bud . The slight suspicion with which [[his]38-silas hearers]810-his hearers at first listened to [him]38-silas , gradually melted away before the convincing simplicity of [his]38-silas distress : it was impossible for [the neighbours]285-the neighbours to doubt that [Marner]38-silas was telling the truth , not because [they]285-the neighbours were capable of arguing at once from the nature of [his]38-silas statements to the absence of any motive for making them falsely , but because , as [Mr Macey]41-mr macey observed , " [Folks]214-folks as had the devil to back ['em]2302-'em were not likely to be so mushed "[41-mr macey] as poor [Silas]38-silas was . Rather , from the strange fact that [the robber]734-the robber had left no traces , and had happened to know the nick of time , utterly incalculable by [mortal agents]856-mortal agents , when [Silas]38-silas would go away from [home]374-home without locking [his]38-silas door , the more probable conclusion seemed to be , that [his]38-silas disreputable intimacy in [that quarter]858-that quarter , if it ever existed , had been broken up , and that , in consequence , this ill turn had been done to [Marner]38-silas by somebody it was quite in vain to set [the constable]738-the constable after . Why [this preternatural felon]860-this preternatural felon should be obliged to wait till the door was left unlocked , was a question which did not present itself . " It is n't [Jem Rodney]40-jem rodney as has done this work , [Master Marner]42-master marner , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord . " [You]42-master marner must n't be a - casting [your]42-master marner eye at [poor Jem]40-jem rodney . There may be a bit of a reckoning against [Jem]40-jem rodney for the matter of a hare or so , if [anybody]263-anybody was bound to keep [their]263-anybody eyes staring open , and niver to wink — but [Jem]40-jem rodney 's been asitting here drinking [his]40-jem rodney can , like [the decentest man [i]761-the landlord ' [the parish]262-the parish]2304-the decentest man i ' the parish , since before [you]42-master marner left [[your]42-master marner house]2306-your house , [Master Marner]42-master marner , by [your]42-master marner own account . "[761-the landlord] " Ay , ay , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey ; " let 's have no accusing o ' [the innicent]2307-the innicent . That is n't the law . "[41-mr macey] [Memory]99-memory was not so utterly torpid in [Silas]38-silas that it could not be wakened by these words . " [I]41-mr macey was wrong , "[41-mr macey] [he]41-mr macey said—"yes , yes — [I]41-mr macey ought to have thought . There 's nothing to witness against [you]40-jem rodney , [Jem]40-jem rodney . "[41-mr macey] " Ay , ay , [they]2314-they 're gone where it 's hot enough to melt ['em]2315-'em , [I]41-mr macey doubt , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey . " Tchuh ! "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier . And then [he]768-the farrier asked , with a cross - examining air , " How much money might there be in the bags , [Master Marner]42-master marner ? "[768-the farrier] " Two hundred and seventy - two pounds , twelve and sixpence , last night when [I]38-silas counted it , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , seating [himself]38-silas again , with a groan . " Pooh ! why , [they]2314-they 'd be none so heavy to carry . [Some tramp]2316-some tramp 's been in , that 's all ; and as for the no footmarks , and the bricks and the sand being all right — why , [your]42-master marner eyes are pretty much like a insect 's , [Master Marner]42-master marner ; [they]2314-they 're obliged to look so close , [you]42-master marner ca n't see much at a time . It 's [my]38-silas opinion as , if [I]38-silas 'd been [you]42-master marner , or [you]42-master marner 'd been [me]38-silas — for it comes to the same thing — [you]42-master marner would n't have thought [you]42-master marner 'd found everything as [you]42-master marner left it . "[38-silas] By this pregnant speech [the farrier]768-the farrier had reestablished [his]768-the farrier self - complacency , and waited with confidence to hear [himself]768-the farrier named as [one of [the superlatively sensible men]865-the superlatively sensible men]864-one of the superlatively sensible men . " Let [us]2325-us see how the night is , though , "[761-the landlord] said [the landlord]761-the landlord , who also considered [himself]761-the landlord personally concerned in this proposition . "[768-the farrier] [The landlord]761-the landlord agreed with this view , and after taking the sense of [the company]755-the company , and duly rehearsing a small ceremony known in high ecclesiastical life as the nolo episcopari , [he]761-the landlord consented to take on [himself]761-the landlord the chill dignity of going to [Kench]100-kench 's . But to [the farrier]768-the farrier 's strong disgust , [Mr Macey]41-mr macey now started an objection to [his]768-the farrier proposing [himself]768-the farrier as [a deputy - constable]871-a deputy - constable ; for [that oracular old gentleman , claiming to know the law]872-that oracular old gentleman , claiming to know the law , stated , as a fact delivered to [him]768-the farrier by [[his]768-the farrier father]592-his father , that [no doctor]874-no doctor could be [a constable]875-a constable . " And [you]768-the farrier 're [a doctor]2329-a doctor , [I]41-mr macey reckon , though [you]768-the farrier 're only [a cow - doctor]2330-a cow - doctor — for a fly 's a fly , though it may be a hoss - fly , "[41-mr macey] concluded [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , wondering a little at [his]768-the farrier own " ' cuteness . "[768-the farrier] There was a hot debate upon this , [the farrier]768-the farrier being of course indisposed to renounce the quality of [doctor]877-doctor , but contending that [a doctor]2329-a doctor could be [a constable]875-a constable if [he]2329-a doctor liked — the law meant , [he]2329-a doctor need n't be one if [he]2329-a doctor did n't like . [Mr Macey]41-mr macey thought this was nonsense , since the law was not likely to be fonder of [doctors]2211-doctors than of [other folks]2119-other folks . Moreover , if it was in the nature of [doctors]2211-doctors more than of [other men]883-other men not to like being [constables]884-constables , how came [Mr Dowlas]97-dowlas to be so eager to act in that capacity ? " [I]768-the farrier do n't want to act [the constable]738-the constable , "[768-the farrier] said [the farrier]768-the farrier , driven into a corner by this merciless reasoning ; " and there 's [no man]248-no man can say it of [me]768-the farrier , if [he]248-no man 'd tell the truth . But if there 's to be any jealousy and envying about going to [Kench]100-kench 's in the rain , let [them]888-his two companions go as like it — [you]2333-you wo n't get [me]768-the farrier to go , [I]768-the farrier can tell [you]2333-you . "[768-the farrier] By [the landlord]761-the landlord 's intervention , however , the dispute was accommodated . [Mr Dowlas]97-dowlas consented to go as [a second person disinclined to act officially]887-a second person disinclined to act officially ; and so poor [Silas]38-silas , furnished with some old coverings , turned out with [[his]38-silas two companions]888-his two companions into the rain again , thinking of the long night - hours before [him]38-silas , not as those do who long to rest , but as [those who expect to " watch for the morning]2334-those who expect to " watch for the morning . "[2334-those who expect to " watch for the morning] When [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey returned from [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's party at midnight , [he]66-godfrey was not much surprised to learn that [Dunsey]64-dunsey had not come [home]374-home . Perhaps [he]66-godfrey had not sold Wildfire , and was waiting for another chance — perhaps , on that foggy afternoon , [he]66-godfrey had preferred housing [himself]66-godfrey at [the Red Lion]22-the red lion at [Batherley]11-batherley for the night , if the run had kept [him]66-godfrey in [that neighbourhood]890-that neighbourhood ; for [he]66-godfrey was not likely to feel much concern about leaving [[his]66-godfrey brother]555-his brother in suspense . [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's mind was too full of [Nancy Lammeter]67-nancy 's looks and behaviour , too full of the exasperation against [himself]66-godfrey and [his]66-godfrey lot , which the sight of [her]67-nancy always produced in [him]66-godfrey , for [him]66-godfrey to give much thought to [Wildfire]75-wildfire or to the probabilities of [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's conduct . The next morning [the whole village]892-the whole village was excited by the story of the robbery , and [Godfrey]66-godfrey , like [every one else]893-every one else , was occupied in gathering and discussing news about it , and in visiting [the Stone - pits]658-the stone - pits . The rain had washed away all possibility of distinguishing foot - marks , but a close investigation of [the spot]619-the spot had disclosed , in the direction opposite to [the village]247-the village , a tinder - box , with a flint and steel , half sunk in the mud . It was not [Silas]38-silas 's tinder - box , for the only one [he]38-silas had ever had was still standing on [his]38-silas shelf ; and the inference generally accepted was , that the tinder - box in [the ditch]897-the ditch was somehow connected with the robbery . [A small minority]898-a small minority shook [their]898-a small minority heads , and intimated [their]898-a small minority opinion that it was not a robbery to have much light thrown on it by [tinder - boxes]899-tinder - boxes , that [Master Marner]42-master marner 's tale had a queer look with it , and that such things had been known as [a man]185-a man 's doing [himself]185-a man a mischief , and then setting [the justice]2293-the justice to look for [the doer]902-the doer . But when questioned closely as to [their]898-a small minority grounds for this opinion , and what [Master Marner]42-master marner had to gain by such false pretences , [they]898-a small minority only shook [their]898-a small minority heads as before , and observed that there was no knowing what [some folks]2101-some folks counted gain ; moreover , that [everybody]446-everybody had a right to [their]446-everybody own opinions , grounds or no grounds , and that [the weaver]209-the weaver , as [everybody]446-everybody knew , was partly crazy . [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , though [he]41-mr macey joined in the defence of [Marner]38-silas against all suspicions of deceit , also poohpoohed the tinder - box ; indeed , repudiated it as a rather impious suggestion , tending to imply that everything must be done by human hands , and that there was no power which could make away with the guineas without moving the bricks . Nevertheless , [he]41-mr macey turned round rather sharply on [Mr Tookey]84-tookey , when [the zealous deputy]907-the zealous deputy , feeling that this was a view of the case peculiarly suited to [a parish - clerk]908-a parish - clerk , carried it still farther , and doubted whether it was right to inquire into a robbery at all when the circumstances were so mysterious . " As if , "[2335-mr tookey—"as] concluded [Mr Tookey—"as]2335-mr tookey—"as if there was nothing but what could be made out by [justices]2336-justices and [constables]884-constables . "[2335-mr tookey—"as] " Now , do n't [you]84-tookey be for overshooting the mark , [Tookey]84-tookey , "[41-mr macey] said [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , nodding [his]41-mr macey head aside , admonishingly . " That 's what [you]84-tookey 're allays at ; if [I]41-mr macey throw a stone and hit , [you]84-tookey think there 's summat better than hitting , and [you]84-tookey try to throw a stone beyond . What [I]41-mr macey said was against the tinder - box : [I]41-mr macey said nothing against [justices]2336-justices and [constables]884-constables , for [they]2340-they 're o ' [King George]65-king george 's making , and it ' ud be ill - becoming [a man in [a parish office]2342-a parish office]2341-a man in a parish office to fly out again ' [King George]65-king george . "[41-mr macey] While these discussions were going on amongst [the group outside [the Rainbow]741-the rainbow]909-the group outside the rainbow , a higher consultation was being carried on within , under the presidency of [Mr Crackenthorp]86-mr crackenthorp . [the rector]911-the rector , assisted by [Squire Cass]58-squire cass and [other substantial parishioners]912-other substantial parishioners . It had just occurred to [Mr Snell]82-mr snell , [the landlord]761-the landlord — [he]82-mr snell being , as [he]82-mr snell observed , [a man accustomed to put two and two together]914-a man accustomed to put two and two together — to connect with the tinder - box which , as [deputy - constable]915-deputy - constable , [he]82-mr snell [himself]82-mr snell had had the honourable distinction of finding , certain recollections of [a pedlar who had called to drink at [the house]334-the house about a month before , and had actually stated that [he]916-a pedlar who had called to drink at the house about a month before , and had actually stated that he carried a tinder - box about with him to light his pipe carried a tinder - box about with [him]916-a pedlar who had called to drink at the house about a month before , and had actually stated that he carried a tinder - box about with him to light his pipe to light [his]916-a pedlar who had called to drink at the house about a month before , and had actually stated that he carried a tinder - box about with him to light his pipe pipe]916-a pedlar who had called to drink at the house about a month before , and had actually stated that he carried a tinder - box about with him to light his pipe . Here , surely , was a clue to be followed out . And as memory , when duly impregnated with ascertained facts , is sometimes surprisingly fertile , [Mr Snell]82-mr snell gradually recovered a vivid impression of the effect produced on [him]82-mr snell by [the pedlar]180-the pedlar 's countenance and conversation . [He]82-mr snell had a " look with [his]82-mr snell eye "[82-mr snell] which fell unpleasantly on [Mr Snell]82-mr snell 's sensitive organism . To be sure , [he]82-mr snell did n't say anything particular — no , except that about the tinder - box — but it is n't what [a man]185-a man says , it 's the way [he]185-a man says it . Moreover , [he]82-mr snell had a swarthy foreignness of complexion which boded little honesty . " Did [he]82-mr snell wear ear - rings ? "[86-mr crackenthorp] [Mr Crackenthorp]86-mr crackenthorp wished to know , having some acquaintance with foreign customs . " Well — stay — let [me]82-mr snell see , "[82-mr snell] said [Mr Snell]82-mr snell , like [a docile clairvoyante , who would really not make a mistake]920-a docile clairvoyante , who would really not make a mistake if [she]920-a docile clairvoyante , who would really not make a mistake could help it . After stretching the corners of [his]82-mr snell mouth and contracting [his]82-mr snell eyes , as if [he]82-mr snell were trying to see the ear - rings , [he]82-mr snell appeared to give up the effort , and said , " Well , [he]82-mr snell 'd got ear - rings in [his]82-mr snell box to sell , so it 's nat'ral to suppose [he]82-mr snell might wear 'em . But [he]82-mr snell called at [every house]2343-every house , a'most , in [the village]247-the village : there 's [somebody else]739-somebody else , mayhap , saw 'em in [his]82-mr snell ears , though [I]82-mr snell ca n't take upon [me]82-mr snell rightly to say . "[82-mr snell] [Mr Snell]82-mr snell was correct in [his]82-mr snell surmise , that [somebody else]739-somebody else would remember [the pedlar]180-the pedlar 's ear - rings . For , on the spread of inquiry among [the villagers]923-the villagers , it was stated with gathering emphasis , that [the parson]273-the parson had wanted to know whether [the pedlar]180-the pedlar wore ear - rings in [his]180-the pedlar ears , and an impression was created that a great deal depended on the eliciting of this fact . Of course [every one who heard the question]926-every one who heard the question , not having any distinct image of [the pedlar as without ear - rings]927-the pedlar as without ear - rings , immediately had an image of [him]180-the pedlar with ear - rings , larger or smaller , as the case might be ; and the image was presently taken for a vivid recollection , so that [[the glazier]928-the glazier 's wife]929-the glazier 's wife , [a well - intentioned woman]930-a well - intentioned woman , not given to lying , and whose house was among the cleanest in [the village]247-the village , was ready to declare , as sure as ever [she]929-the glazier 's wife meant to take the sacrament , the very next Christmas that was ever coming , that [she]929-the glazier 's wife had seen big ear - rings , in the shape of the young moon , in [the pedlar]180-the pedlar 's two ears ; while [Jinny Oates]102-jinny oates , [[the cobbler]436-the cobbler 's daughter]934-the cobbler 's daughter , being [a more imaginative person]935-a more imaginative person , stated not only that [she]102-jinny oates had seen them too , but that [they]936-they had made [her]102-jinny oates blood creep , as it did at that very moment while there [she]102-jinny oates stood . Also , by way of throwing further light on this clue of the tinder - box , a collection was made of all the articles purchased from [the pedlar]180-the pedlar at [various houses]938-various houses , and carried to the Rainbow to be exhibited [there]2073-there . In fact , there was a general feeling in [the village]247-the village , that for the clearing - up of this robbery there must be a great deal done at [the Rainbow]741-the rainbow , and that [no man]248-no man need offer [[his]248-no man wife]223-his wife an excuse for going [there]2073-there while it was the scene of severe public duties . Some disappointment was felt , and perhaps a little indignation also , when it became known that [Silas Marner]38-silas , on being questioned by [the Squire]531-the squire and [the parson]273-the parson , had retained no other recollection of [the pedlar]180-the pedlar than that [he]38-silas had called at [his]38-silas door , but had not entered [[his]38-silas house]703-his house , having turned away at once when [Silas]38-silas , holding the door ajar , had said that [he]38-silas wanted nothing . This had been [Silas]38-silas 's testimony , though [he]38-silas clutched strongly at the idea of [the pedlar]180-the pedlar 's being [the culprit]353-the culprit , if only because it gave [him]38-silas a definite image of a whereabout for [his]38-silas gold , after it had been taken away from its hiding - place : [he]38-silas could see it now in [[the pedlar]180-the pedlar 's box]952-the pedlar 's box . But it was observed with some irritation in [the village]247-the village , that [anybody but a " blind creatur "[38-silas] like [Marner]38-silas]954-anybody but a " blind creatur " like marner would have seen [the man]731-the man prowling about , for how came [he]38-silas to leave [his]38-silas tinder - box in the ditch close by , if [he]38-silas had n't been lingering [there]2073-there ? Doubtless , [he]38-silas had made [his]38-silas observations when [he]38-silas saw [Marner]38-silas at the door . [Anybody]263-anybody might know — and only look at [him]38-silas — that [the weaver]209-the weaver was [a half - crazy miser]959-a half - crazy miser . It was a wonder [the pedlar]180-the pedlar had n't murdered [him]38-silas ; [men of that sort]961-men of that sort , with rings in [their]961-men of that sort ears , had been known for [murderers]962-murderers often and often ; there had been one tried at [the ' sizes]963-the ' sizes , not so long ago but what there were [people living who remembered it]964-people living who remembered it . [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey , indeed , entering [the Rainbow]4-the rainbow during one of [Mr Snell]82-mr snell 's frequently repeated recitals of [his]66-godfrey testimony , had treated it lightly , stating that [he]66-godfrey [himself]66-godfrey had bought a pen - knife of [the pedlar]180-the pedlar , and thought [him]180-the pedlar [a merry grinning fellow]966-a merry grinning fellow enough ; it was all nonsense , [he]66-godfrey said , about [the man]731-the man 's evil looks . But this was spoken of in [the village]247-the village as the random talk of youth , " as if it was only [Mr Snell]82-mr snell who had seen something odd about [the pedlar]180-the pedlar ! "[66-godfrey] On the contrary , there were at least half - a - dozen who were ready to go before [Justice Malam]101-justice malam , and give in much more striking testimony than any [the landlord]761-the landlord could furnish . It was to be hoped [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey would not go to [Tarley]6-tarley and throw cold water on what [Mr Snell]82-mr snell said there , and so prevent [the justice]2293-the justice from drawing up a warrant . [He]66-godfrey was suspected of intending this , when , after mid - day , [he]66-godfrey was seen setting off on horseback in [the direction of [Tarley]6-tarley]971-the direction of tarley . But by this time [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's interest in the robbery had faded before [his]66-godfrey growing anxiety about [Dunstan]63-dunstan and Wildfire , and [he]66-godfrey was going , not to [Tarley]6-tarley , but to [Batherley]11-batherley , unable to rest in uncertainty about [them]972-them any longer . The possibility that [Dunstan]63-dunstan had played [him]66-godfrey the ugly trick of riding away with Wildfire , to return at the end of a month , when [he]66-godfrey had gambled away or otherwise squandered the price of the horse , was a fear that urged itself upon [him]66-godfrey more , even , than the thought of an accidental injury ; and now that the dance at [Mrs Osgood]52-mrs osgood 's was past , [he]66-godfrey was irritated with [himself]66-godfrey that [he]66-godfrey had trusted [his]66-godfrey horse to [Dunstan]63-dunstan . Instead of trying to still [his]66-godfrey fears , [he]66-godfrey encouraged [them]972-them , with that superstitious impression which clings to [us]973-us all , that if [we]973-us expect evil very strongly it is the less likely to come ; and when [he]66-godfrey heard a horse approaching at a trot , and saw a hat rising above a hedge beyond an angle of [the lane]615-the lane , [he]66-godfrey felt as if [his]66-godfrey conjuration had succeeded . But no sooner did the horse come within sight , than [his]66-godfrey heart sank again . It was not Wildfire ; and in a few moments more [he]66-godfrey discerned that [the rider]2088-the rider was not [Dunstan]63-dunstan , but [Bryce]73-bryce , who pulled up to speak , with a face that implied something disagreeable . " Well , [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey , that 's [a lucky brother of yours]2347-a lucky brother of yours , that [Master Dunsey]104-dunsey , is n't [he]104-dunsey ? "[73-bryce] " What do [you]66-godfrey mean ? "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , hastily . " Why , has n't [he]104-dunsey been [home]374-home yet ? "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce . " [Home]374-home ? no . What has happened ? Be quick . What has [he]104-dunsey done with [my]73-bryce horse ? "[73-bryce] " Ah , [I]73-bryce thought it was [yours]66-godfrey , though [he]104-dunsey pretended [you]66-godfrey had parted with it to [him]104-dunsey . "[73-bryce] " Has [he]104-dunsey thrown [him]104-dunsey down and broken [his]104-dunsey knees ? "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , flushed with exasperation . " Worse than that , "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce . " [You]66-godfrey see , [I]73-bryce 'd made a bargain with [him]104-dunsey to buy the horse for a hundred and twenty — a swinging price , but [I]73-bryce always liked the horse . And what does [he]104-dunsey do but go and stake [him]104-dunsey — fly at a hedge with stakes in it , atop of a bank with a ditch before it . The horse had been dead a pretty good while when [he]104-dunsey was found . So [he]104-dunsey has n't been [home]374-home since , has [he]104-dunsey ? "[73-bryce] " [Home]374-home ? no , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , " and [he]104-dunsey 'd better keep away . Confound [me]66-godfrey for [a fool]2352-a fool ! [I]66-godfrey might have known this would be the end of it . "[66-godfrey] " Well , to tell [you]66-godfrey the truth , "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce , " after [I]73-bryce 'd bargained for the horse , it did come into [my]73-bryce head that [he]104-dunsey might be riding and selling the horse without [your]66-godfrey knowledge , for [I]73-bryce did n't believe it was [his]104-dunsey own . [I]73-bryce knew [Master Dunsey]104-dunsey was up to [his]104-dunsey tricks sometimes . But where can [he]104-dunsey be gone ? [He]104-dunsey 's never been seen at [Batherley]11-batherley . [He]104-dunsey could n't have been hurt , for [he]104-dunsey must have walked off . "[73-bryce] " Hurt ? "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , bitterly . " [He]104-dunsey 'll never be hurt — [he]104-dunsey 's made to hurt [other people]548-other people . "[66-godfrey] " And so [you]66-godfrey did give [him]104-dunsey leave to sell the horse , eh ? "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce . " Yes ; [I]66-godfrey wanted to part with the horse — [he]104-dunsey was always a little too hard in the mouth for [me]66-godfrey , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey ; [his]66-godfrey pride making [him]66-godfrey wince under the idea that [Bryce]73-bryce guessed the sale to be a matter of necessity . " [I]66-godfrey was going to see after [him]104-dunsey — [I]66-godfrey thought some mischief had happened . [I]66-godfrey 'll go back now , "[66-godfrey] [he]66-godfrey added , turning the horse 's head , and wishing [he]66-godfrey could get rid of [Bryce]73-bryce ; for [he]66-godfrey felt that the long - dreaded crisis in [his]73-bryce life was close upon [him]73-bryce . " [You]66-godfrey 're coming on to [Raveloe]1-raveloe , are n't [you]66-godfrey ? "[66-godfrey] " Well , no , not now , "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce . " [I]73-bryce was coming round there , for [I]73-bryce had to go to [Flitton]13-flitton , and [I]73-bryce thought [I]73-bryce might as well take [you]66-godfrey in [my]73-bryce way , and just let [you]66-godfrey know all [I]73-bryce knew [myself]73-bryce about the horse . [I]73-bryce suppose [Master Dunsey]104-dunsey did n't like to show [himself]104-dunsey till the ill news had blown over a bit . [He]104-dunsey 's perhaps gone to pay a visit at [the Three Crowns]2354-the three crowns , by [Whitbridge]105-whitbridge — [I]73-bryce know [he]104-dunsey 's fond of [the house]334-the house . "[73-bryce] " Perhaps [he]104-dunsey is , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , rather absently . Then rousing [himself]66-godfrey , [he]66-godfrey said , with an effort at carelessness , " [We]2356-we shall hear of [him]104-dunsey soon enough , [I]66-godfrey 'll be bound . "[66-godfrey] " Well , here 's [my]73-bryce turning , "[73-bryce] said [Bryce]73-bryce , not surprised to perceive that [Godfrey]66-godfrey was rather ' down ; ' " so [I]73-bryce 'll bid [you]66-godfrey good - day , and wish [I]73-bryce may bring [you]66-godfrey better news another time . "[73-bryce] [Godfrey]66-godfrey rode along slowly , representing to [himself]66-godfrey the scene of confession to [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father from which [he]66-godfrey felt that there was now no longer any escape . The revelation about the money must be made the very next morning ; and if [he]66-godfrey withheld the rest , [Dunstan]63-dunstan would be sure to come back shortly , and finding that [he]63-dunstan must bear the brunt of [[his]63-dunstan father]592-his father 's anger , would tell the whole story out of spite , even though [he]63-dunstan had nothing to gain by it . There was one step , perhaps , by which [he]66-godfrey might still win [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's silence and put off the evil day : [he]66-godfrey might tell [[his]63-dunstan father]592-his father that [he]66-godfrey had [himself]66-godfrey spent the money paid to [him]63-dunstan by [Fowler]69-fowler ; and as [he]66-godfrey had never been guilty of such an offence before , the affair would blow over after a little storming . But [Godfrey]66-godfrey could not bend [himself]66-godfrey to this . [He]66-godfrey felt that in letting [Dunstan]63-dunstan have the money , [he]66-godfrey had already been guilty of a breach of trust hardly less culpable than that of spending the money directly for [his]66-godfrey own behoof ; and yet there was a distinction between the two acts which made [him]66-godfrey feel that the one was so much more blackening than the other as to be intolerable to [him]66-godfrey . " [I]66-godfrey do n't pretend to be [a good fellow]2357-a good fellow , "[66-godfrey] [he]66-godfrey said to [himself]66-godfrey ; " but [I]66-godfrey 'm not [a scoundrel]2358-a scoundrel — at least , [I]66-godfrey 'll stop short somewhere . [I]66-godfrey 'll bear the consequences of what [I]66-godfrey have done sooner than make believe [I]66-godfrey 've done what [I]66-godfrey never would have done . [I]66-godfrey 'd never have spent the money for [my]66-godfrey own pleasure — [I]66-godfrey was tortured into it . "[66-godfrey] Through the remainder of this day [Godfrey]66-godfrey , with only occasional fluctuations , kept [his]66-godfrey will bent in the direction of a complete avowal to [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father , and [he]66-godfrey withheld the story of [Wildfire]75-wildfire 's loss till the next morning , that it might serve [him]66-godfrey as an introduction to heavier matter . [The old Squire]564-the old squire was accustomed to [[his]564-the old squire son]981-his son 's frequent absence from [home]374-home , and thought neither [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's nor [Wildfire]75-wildfire 's non - appearance a matter calling for remark . [Godfrey]66-godfrey said to [himself]66-godfrey again and again , that if [he]66-godfrey let slip this one opportunity of confession , [he]66-godfrey might never have another ; the revelation might be made even in a more odious way than by [Dunstan]63-dunstan 's malignity : [she]983-she might come , as [she]983-she had threatened to do . And then [he]66-godfrey tried to make the scene easier to [himself]66-godfrey by rehearsal : [he]66-godfrey made up [his]66-godfrey mind how [he]66-godfrey would pass from the admission of [his]66-godfrey weakness in letting [Dunstan]63-dunstan have the money to the fact that [Dunstan]63-dunstan had a hold on [him]63-dunstan which [he]63-dunstan had been unable to shake off , and how [he]66-godfrey would work up [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father to expect something very bad before [he]66-godfrey told [him]66-godfrey the fact . [The old Squire]564-the old squire was [an implacable man]986-an implacable man : [he]564-the old squire made resolutions in violent anger , but [he]564-the old squire was not to be moved from [them]987-them after [his]564-the old squire anger had subsided — as fiery volcanic matters cool and harden into rock . Like [many violent and implacable men]988-many violent and implacable men , [he]564-the old squire allowed evils to grow under favour of [his]564-the old squire own heedlessness , till [they]987-them pressed upon [him]564-the old squire with exasperating force , and then [he]564-the old squire turned round with fierce severity and became unrelentingly hard . This was [his]564-the old squire system with [[his]564-the old squire tenants]989-his tenants : [he]564-the old squire allowed [them]989-his tenants to get into arrears , neglect [their]989-his tenants fences , reduce [their]989-his tenants stock , sell [their]989-his tenants straw , and otherwise go the wrong way,—and then , when [he]564-the old squire became short of money in consequence of this indulgence , [he]564-the old squire took the hardest measures and would listen to no appeal . [Godfrey]66-godfrey knew all this , and felt it with the greater force because [he]66-godfrey had constantly suffered annoyance from witnessing [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father 's sudden fits of unrelentingness , for which [his]66-godfrey own habitual irresolution deprived [him]66-godfrey of all sympathy . ( [He]66-godfrey was not critical on the faulty indulgence which preceded these fits ; that seemed to [him]66-godfrey natural enough . ) Still there was just the chance , [Godfrey]66-godfrey thought , that [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father 's pride might see this marriage in a light that would induce [him]592-his father to hush it up , rather than turn [[his]592-his father son]981-his son out and make [the family]993-the family the talk of [the country]198-the country for ten miles round . This was the view of the case that [Godfrey]66-godfrey managed to keep before [him]66-godfrey pretty closely till midnight , and [he]66-godfrey went to sleep thinking that [he]66-godfrey had done with inward debating . But when [he]66-godfrey awoke in the still morning darkness [he]66-godfrey found it impossible to reawaken [his]66-godfrey evening thoughts ; it was as if [they]995-their had been tired out and were not to be roused to further work . Instead of arguments for confession , [he]66-godfrey could now feel the presence of nothing but its evil consequences : the old dread of disgrace came back — the old shrinking from the thought of raising a hopeless barrier between [himself]66-godfrey and [Nancy]67-nancy — the old disposition to rely on chances which might be favourable to [him]66-godfrey , and save [him]66-godfrey from betrayal . Why , after all , should [he]66-godfrey cut off the hope of [them]995-their by [his]66-godfrey own act ? [He]66-godfrey had seen the matter in a wrong light yesterday . [He]66-godfrey had been in a rage with [Dunstan]63-dunstan , and had thought of nothing but a thorough break - up of [their]995-their mutual understanding ; but what it would be really wisest for [him]66-godfrey to do , was to try and soften [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father 's anger against [Dunsey]104-dunsey , and keep things as nearly as possible in [their]995-their old condition . If [Dunsey]104-dunsey did not come back for a few days ( and [Godfrey]66-godfrey did not know but that [the rascal]997-the rascal had enough money in [his]997-the rascal pocket to enable [him]997-the rascal to keep away still longer ) , everything might blow over . [Godfrey]66-godfrey rose and took [his]66-godfrey own breakfast earlier than usual , but lingered in [the wainscoted parlour]998-the wainscoted parlour till [[his]66-godfrey younger brothers]999-his younger brothers had finished [their]999-his younger brothers meal and gone out , awaiting [[his]66-godfrey father]592-his father , who always went out and had a walk with [[his]592-his father managing - man]1001-his managing - man before breakfast . [Every one]365-every one breakfasted at a different hour in [the Red House]533-the red house , and [the Squire]531-the squire was always the latest , giving a long chance to a rather feeble morning appetite before [he]531-the squire tried it . The table had been spread with substantial estables nearly two hours before [he]531-the squire presented [himself]531-the squire — [a tall , stout man of sixty , with a face in which the knit brow and rather hard glance seemed contradicted by the slack and feeble mouth]1005-a tall , stout man of sixty , with a face in which the knit brow and rather hard glance seemed contradicted by the slack and feeble mouth . [[His]531-the squire person]1006-his person showed marks of habitual neglect , [his]531-the squire dress was slovenly ; and yet there was something in the presence of [the old Squire]564-the old squire distinguishable from that of [the ordinary farmers in [the parish]262-the parish]1008-the ordinary farmers in the parish , who were perhaps every whit as refined as [he]531-the squire , but , having slouched [their]1008-the ordinary farmers in the parish way through life with a consciousness of being in the vicinity of [[their]1008-the ordinary farmers in the parish " betters]2359-their " betters , "[531-the squire] wanted that self - possession and authoritativeness of voice and carriage which belonged to [a man who thought of [superiors]1011-superiors as remote existences , with whom [he]531-the squire had personally little more to do than with [America]23-america or the stars]1010-a man who thought of superiors as remote existences , with whom he had personally little more to do than with america or the stars . [The Squire]531-the squire had been used to parish homage all [his]531-the squire life , used to the presupposition that [[his]531-the squire family]601-his family , [his]531-the squire tankards , and everything that was [his]531-the squire , were the oldest and best ; and as [he]531-the squire never associated with [any gentry higher than [himself]531-the squire]1014-any gentry higher than himself , [his]531-the squire opinion was not disturbed by comparison . [He]531-the squire glanced at [[his]531-the squire son]981-his son as [he]531-the squire entered [the room]611-the room , and said , " What , [sir]2360-sir ! have n't [you]981-his son had [your]981-his son breakfast yet ? "[531-the squire] but there was no pleasant morning greeting between [them]1017-them ; not because of any unfriendliness , but because the sweet flower of courtesy is not a growth of [such homes as [the Red House]24-the red house]1018-such homes as the red house . " Yes , [sir]2360-sir , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey , " [I]66-godfrey 've had [my]66-godfrey breakfast , but [I]66-godfrey was waiting to speak to [you]2360-sir . "[66-godfrey] " Ah ! well , "[531-the squire] said [the Squire]531-the squire , throwing [himself]531-the squire indifferently into [his]531-the squire chair , and speaking in a ponderous coughing fashion , which was felt in [Raveloe]1-raveloe to be a sort of privilege of [his]531-the squire rank , while [he]531-the squire cut a piece of beef , and held it up before the deer - hound that had come in with [him]531-the squire , " Ring the bell for [my]531-the squire ale , will [you]2360-sir ? [[You]2360-sir youngsters]2362-you youngsters ' business is [your]2360-sir own pleasure , mostly . There 's no hurry about it for [anybody]263-anybody but [yourselves]2360-sir . "[531-the squire] [The Squire]531-the squire 's life was quite as idle as [[his]531-the squire sons]539-his sons ' , but it was a fiction kept up by [himself]531-the squire and [[his]531-the squire contemporaries]1022-his contemporaries in [Raveloe]1-raveloe that youth was exclusively the period of folly , and that [their]1023-their aged wisdom was constantly in a state of endurance mitigated by sarcasm . [Godfrey]66-godfrey waited , before [he]66-godfrey spoke again , until the ale had been brought and the door closed — an interval during which [Fleet]106-fleet , [the deer - hound]1024-the deer - hound , had consumed enough bits of beef to make [a poor man]1025-a poor man 's holiday dinner . " There 's been a cursed piece of ill - luck with Wildfire , "[66-godfrey] [he]66-godfrey began ; " happened the day before yesterday . "[66-godfrey] " What ! broke [his]531-the squire knees ? "[531-the squire] said [the Squire]531-the squire , after taking a draught of ale . " [I]531-the squire thought [you]66-godfrey knew how to ride better than that , [sir]2360-sir . [I]531-the squire never threw a horse down in [my]531-the squire life . If [I]531-the squire had , [I]531-the squire might ha ' whistled for another , for [[my]531-the squire father]2068-my father was n't quite so ready to unstring as [some other fathers]2366-some other fathers [I]531-the squire know of . But [they]2366-some other fathers must turn over a new leaf — [they]2366-some other fathers must . What with mortgages and arrears , [I]531-the squire 'm as short o ' cash as [a roadside pauper]2367-a roadside pauper . And [that fool]2368-that fool [Kimble]54-kimble says the newspaper 's talking about peace . Why , [the country]198-the country would n't have a leg to stand on . [Prices]107-prices ' ud run down like a jack , and [I]531-the squire should never get [my]531-the squire arrears , not if [I]531-the squire sold [all the fellows]2370-all the fellows up . And there 's [that damned Fowler]2371-that damned fowler , [I]531-the squire wo n't put up with [him]2371-that damned fowler any longer ; [I]531-the squire 've told [Winthrop]87-ben winthrop to go to [Cox]70-cox this very day . [The lying scoundrel]2372-the lying scoundrel told [me]531-the squire [he]2372-the lying scoundrel 'd be sure to pay [me]531-the squire a hundred last month . [He]2371-that damned fowler takes advantage because [he]2371-that damned fowler 's on [that outlying farm]2373-that outlying farm , and thinks [I]531-the squire shall forget [him]2371-that damned fowler . "[531-the squire] [The Squire]531-the squire had delivered this speech in a coughing and interrupted manner , but with no pause long enough for [Godfrey]66-godfrey to make it a pretext for taking up the word again . [He]531-the squire felt that [[his]531-the squire father]592-his father meant to ward off any request for money on the ground of the misfortune with Wildfire , and that the emphasis [he]531-the squire had thus been led to lay on [his]531-the squire shortness of cash and [his]531-the squire arrears was likely to produce an attitude of mind the most unfavourable for [his]531-the squire own disclosure . But [he]531-the squire must go on , now [he]531-the squire had begun . " It 's worse than breaking the horse 's knees — [he]2371-that damned fowler 's been staked and killed , "[531-the squire] [he]531-the squire said , as soon as [[his]531-the squire father]592-his father was silent , and had begun to cut [his]592-his father meat . " But [I]531-the squire was n't thinking of asking [you]592-his father to buy [me]531-the squire another horse ; [I]531-the squire was only thinking [I]531-the squire 'd lost the means of paying [you]592-his father with the price of Wildfire , as [I]531-the squire 'd meant to do . [Dunsey]104-dunsey took [him]2371-that damned fowler to the hunt to sell [him]2371-that damned fowler for [me]531-the squire the other day , and after [he]104-dunsey 'd made a bargain for a hundred and twenty with [Bryce]73-bryce , [he]104-dunsey went after the hounds , and took some fool 's leap or other , that did for the horse at once . If it had n't been for that , [I]531-the squire should have paid [you]592-his father a hundred pounds this morning . "[531-the squire] [The Squire]531-the squire had laid down [his]531-the squire knife and fork , and was staring at [[his]531-the squire son]981-his son in amazement , not being sufficiently quick of brain to form a probable guess as to what could have caused so strange an inversion of the paternal and filial relations as this proposition of [[his]531-the squire son]981-his son to pay [him]531-the squire a hundred pounds . " The truth is , [sir]2360-sir — [I'm]66-godfrey very sorry — [I]66-godfrey was quite to blame , "[66-godfrey] said [Godfrey]66-godfrey . " [Fowler]69-fowler did pay that hundred pounds . [He]69-fowler paid it to [me]66-godfrey , when [I]66-godfrey was over [there]2073-there one day last month . And [Dunsey]104-dunsey bothered [me]66-godfrey for the money , and [I]66-godfrey let [him]104-dunsey have it , because [I]66-godfrey hoped [I]66-godfrey should be able to pay it [you]981-his son before this . "[66-godfrey] [The Squire]531-the squire was purple with anger before [[his]531-the squire son]981-his son had done speaking , and found utterance difficult . " [You]2360-sir let [Dunsey]104-dunsey have it , [sir]2360-sir ? And how long have [you]2360-sir been so thick with [Dunsey]104-dunsey that [you]2360-sir must collogue with [him]104-dunsey to embezzle [my]531-the squire money ? Are [you]2360-sir turning out [a scamp]2377-a scamp ? [I]531-the squire tell [you]981-his son , [I]531-the squire wo n't have it . [I]531-the squire 'll turn [the whole pack of [you]981-his son]2378-the whole pack of you out of [the house]334-the house together , and marry again . [I]531-the squire 'd have [you]981-his son to remember , [sir]2360-sir , [[my]531-the squire property]2381-my property 's got no entail on it;—since [[my]531-the squire grandfather]2218-my grandfather 's time [the Casses]2383-the casses can do as [they]2383-the casses like with [[their]2383-the casses land]579-their land . " [I]66-godfrey would n't have spent the money [myself]66-godfrey , but [Dunsey]104-dunsey bothered [me]66-godfrey , and [I]66-godfrey was [a fool]2352-a fool and let [him]104-dunsey have it . [I]66-godfrey never meant to embezzle money , and [I]66-godfrey 'm not [the man]731-the man to do it . [You]2360-sir never knew [me]66-godfrey do a dishonest trick , [sir]2360-sir .
