[I]0-i can not say that [he]1668-one person , as you will believe , who watched with keener though more hidden interest than any other , the prosperous growth of eppie under the weaver 's care was . [The child]451-the child was being taken care of , and would very likely be happy , as [people in humble stations]1679-people in humble stations often were — happier , perhaps , than [those who are brought up in luxury]1680-those who are brought up in luxury . That famous ring that pricked [its owner]1681-its owner when [he]1668-one person , as you will believe , who watched with keener though more hidden interest than any other , the prosperous growth of eppie under the weaver 's care forgot duty and followed desire — [I]0-i wonder if it pricked very hard when [he]1668-one person , as you will believe , who watched with keener though more hidden interest than any other , the prosperous growth of eppie under the weaver 's care set out on the chase , or whether it pricked but lightly then , and only pierced to the quick when the chase had long been ended , and hope , folding [her]1682-her wings , looked backward and became regret ? [Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey 's cheek and eye were brighter than ever now . [He]66-godfrey was so undivided in [his]66-godfrey aims , that [he]66-godfrey seemed like [a man of firmness]1683-a man of firmness . [No Dunsey]104-dunsey had come back : [people]387-people had made up [their]387-people minds that [he]1668-one person , as you will believe , who watched with keener though more hidden interest than any other , the prosperous growth of eppie under the weaver 's care was gone for [a soldier]1685-a soldier , or gone " out of [the country]198-the country , "[387-people] and [no one]182-no one cared to be specific in [their]387-people inquiries on a subject delicate to [a respectable family]1687-a respectable family . [Godfrey]66-godfrey had ceased to see the shadow of [Dunsey]104-dunsey across [his]66-godfrey path ; and the path now lay straight forward to the accomplishment of [his]66-godfrey best , longest - cherished wishes . [Everybody]446-everybody said [Mr Godfrey]66-godfrey had taken the right turn ; and it was pretty clear what would be the end of things , for there were not many days in the week that [he]66-godfrey was not seen riding to [the Warrens]17-the warrens . [Godfrey]66-godfrey [himself]66-godfrey , when [he]66-godfrey was asked [jocosely]150-jocosely if the day had been fixed , smiled with the pleasant consciousness of [a lover who could say " yes , "[1689-a lover who could say " yes , " if he liked] if [he]66-godfrey liked]1689-a lover who could say " yes , " if he liked . [He]66-godfrey felt [a reformed man]1690-a reformed man , delivered from temptation ; and the vision of [his]66-godfrey future life seemed to [him]66-godfrey as [a promised land for which [he]66-godfrey had no cause to fight]1691-a promised land for which he had no cause to fight . [He]66-godfrey saw [himself]66-godfrey with all [his]66-godfrey happiness centred on [his]66-godfrey own hearth , where [Nancy]67-nancy would smile on [him]66-godfrey as [he]66-godfrey played with [the children]482-the children . And [that other child]1693-that other child — not on the hearth — [he]66-godfrey would not forget it ; [he]66-godfrey would see that it was well provided for . That was a [father]2569-father 's duty . It was a bright autumn Sunday , sixteen years after [Silas Marner]38-silas had found [his]38-silas new treasure on the hearth . The bells of [the old Raveloe church]1695-the old raveloe church were ringing the cheerful peal which told that the morning service was ended ; and out of the arched doorway in [the tower]1696-the tower came slowly , retarded by friendly greetings and questions , the richer [parishioners who had chosen this bright Sunday morning as eligible for church]1697-parishioners who had chosen this bright sunday morning as eligible for church - going . It was the rural fashion of that time for [the more important members of [the congregation]1699-the congregation]1698-the more important members of the congregation to depart first , while [[their]1698-the more important members of the congregation humbler neighbours]1700-their humbler neighbours waited and looked on , stroking [their]1700-their humbler neighbours bent heads or dropping [their]1700-their humbler neighbours curtsies to [any large rate - payer who turned to notice [them]1698-the more important members of the congregation]1701-any large rate - payer who turned to notice them . Foremost among [these advancing groups of well - clad people]1702-these advancing groups of well - clad people , there are [some whom [we]1704-we shall recognise , in spite of Time , who has laid [his]38-silas hand on [them]1702-these advancing groups of well - clad people all]1703-some whom we shall recognise , in spite of time , who has laid his hand on them all . [The tall blonde man of forty]1705-the tall blonde man of forty is not much changed in feature from [the Godfrey Cass of six - and - twenty]1706-the godfrey cass of six - and - twenty : [he]1705-the tall blonde man of forty is only fuller in flesh , and has only lost the indefinable look of youth — a loss which is marked even when the eye is undulled and the wrinkles are not yet come . Perhaps [the pretty woman]1707-the pretty woman , not much younger than [he]1705-the tall blonde man of forty , who is leaning on [his]1705-the tall blonde man of forty arm , is more changed than [[her]1707-the pretty woman husband]2414-her husband : the lovely bloom that used to be always on [her]1707-the pretty woman cheek now comes but fitfully , with the fresh morning air or with some strong surprise ; yet to all who love human faces best for what [they]1709-they tell of human experience , [Nancy]67-nancy 's beauty has a heightened interest . Often the soul is ripened into fuller goodness while age has spread an ugly film , so that mere glances can never divine the preciousness of the fruit . But the years have not been so cruel to [Nancy]67-nancy . The firm yet placid mouth , the clear veracious glance of the brown eyes , speak now of a nature that has been tested and has kept its highest qualities ; and even the costume , with its dainty neatness and purity , has more significance now [the coquetries of youth]1710-the coquetries of youth can have nothing to do with it . [Mr]1711-mr and [Mrs Godfrey Cass]151-mrs godfrey cass ( any higher title has died away from [Raveloe]1-raveloe lips since [the old Squire]564-the old squire was gathered to [[his]564-the old squire fathers]1713-his fathers , and [his]564-the old squire inheritance was divided ) have turned round to look for [the tall aged man]1714-the tall aged man and [the plainly - dressed woman who are a little behind]1715-the plainly - dressed woman who are a little behind — [Nancy]67-nancy having observed that [they]1716-they must wait for " [father]2569-father and [Priscilla"—and]152-priscilla"—and[67-nancy] now [they]1716-they all turn into a narrower path leading across [the churchyard]1717-the churchyard to a small gate opposite [the Red House]533-the red house . [We]1719-we will not follow [them]1716-they now ; for may there not be [some others in this departing congregation whom [we]1719-we should like to see again — some of [those who are not likely to be handsomely clad]1721-those who are not likely to be handsomely clad , and whom [we]1719-we may not recognise so easily as [the master and mistress of [the Red House]533-the red house]1722-the master and mistress of the red house]1720-some others in this departing congregation whom we should like to see again — some of those who are not likely to be handsomely clad , and whom we may not recognise so easily as the master and mistress of the red house ? But it is impossible to mistake [Silas Marner]38-silas . [His]38-silas large brown eyes seem to have gathered a longer vision , as is the way with eyes that have been short - sighted in early life , and they have a less vague , a more answering look ; but in everything else one sees signs of a frame much enfeebled by the lapse of the sixteen years . [The weaver]209-the weaver 's bent shoulders and white hair give [him]38-silas almost the look of advanced age , though [he]38-silas is not more than five - and - fifty ; but there is the freshest blossom of youth close by [his]38-silas side — [a blonde dimpled girl of eighteen , who has vainly tried to chastise [her]1725-a blonde dimpled girl of eighteen , who has vainly tried to chastise her curly auburn hair into smoothness under her brown bonnet curly auburn hair into smoothness under [her]1725-a blonde dimpled girl of eighteen , who has vainly tried to chastise her curly auburn hair into smoothness under her brown bonnet brown bonnet]1725-a blonde dimpled girl of eighteen , who has vainly tried to chastise her curly auburn hair into smoothness under her brown bonnet : the hair ripples as obstinately as a brooklet under the March breeze , and the little ringlets burst away from the restraining comb behind and show themselves below the bonnet - crown . [Eppie]146-eppie can not help being rather vexed about [her]146-eppie hair , for there is [no other girl in [Raveloe]1-raveloe]1726-no other girl in raveloe who has hair at all like it , and [she]146-eppie thinks hair ought to be smooth . [She]146-eppie does not like to be blameworthy even in small things : [you]1727-you see how neatly [her]146-eppie prayer - book is folded in [her]146-eppie spotted handkerchief . [That good - looking young fellow]1728-that good - looking young fellow , in a new fustian suit , who walks behind [her]146-eppie , is not quite sure upon the question of hair in the abstract , when [Eppie]146-eppie puts it to [him]1728-that good - looking young fellow , and thinks that perhaps straight hair is the best in general , but [he]1728-that good - looking young fellow does n't want [Eppie]146-eppie 's hair to be different . [She]146-eppie surely divines that there is some one behind [her]146-eppie who is thinking about [her]146-eppie very particualrly , and mustering courage to come to [her]146-eppie side as soon as [they]1729-they are out in [the lane]615-the lane , else why should [she]146-eppie look rather shy , and take care not to turn away [her]146-eppie head from [[her]146-eppie father]1190-her father [Silas]38-silas , to whom [she]146-eppie keeps murmuring little sentences as to who was at [church]363-church and who was not at [church]363-church , and how pretty the red mountain - ash is over the Rectory wall ? " [I]146-eppie wish [we]1729-they had [a little garden]2802-a little garden , [father]2569-father , with double daisies in , like [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop 's , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , when [they]1729-they were out in [the lane]615-the lane ; " only [they]1729-they say it ' ud take a deal of digging and bringing fresh soil — and [you]2569-father could n't do that , could [you]2569-father , [father]2569-father ? Anyhow , [I]146-eppie should n't like [you]2569-father to do it , for it ' ud be too hard work for [you]2569-father . "[146-eppie] " Yes , [I]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities could do it , [child]2550-child , if [you]2550-child want a bit o ' [garden]2806-garden : these long evenings , [I]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities could work at taking in a little bit o ' the waste , just enough for a root or two o ' flowers for [you]2550-child ; and again , [i]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities ' the morning , [I]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities could have a turn wi ' the spade before [I]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities sat down to the loom . Why did n't [you]2569-father tell [me]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities before as [you]2550-child wanted a bit o ' garden ? "[1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities] " [I]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities can dig it for [you]2550-child , [Master Marner]42-master marner , "[1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities] said [the young man in fustian , who was now by [Eppie]146-eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities]1735-the young man in fustian , who was now by eppie 's side , entering into the conversation without the trouble of formalities . " It 'll be play to [me]146-eppie after [I]146-eppie 've done [my]146-eppie day 's work , or any odd bits o ' time when the work 's slack . And [I]146-eppie 'll bring [you]2550-child some soil from [[Mr Cass]66-godfrey 's garden]2807-mr cass 's garden — [he'll]66-godfrey let [me]146-eppie , and willing . "[146-eppie] " Eh , [Aaron]89-aaron , [[my]38-silas lad]2808-my lad , are [you]2550-child there ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas ; " [I]38-silas was n't aware of [you]2550-child ; for when [Eppie]146-eppie 's talking o ' things , [I]38-silas see nothing but what [she]146-eppie 's a - saying . Well , if [you]2550-child could help [me]38-silas with the digging , [we]2809-we might get [her]146-eppie a bit o ' [garden]2806-garden all the sooner . "[38-silas] " Then , if [you]2550-child think well and good , "[89-aaron] said [Aaron]89-aaron , " [I]89-aaron 'll come to [the Stone - pits]658-the stone - pits this afternoon , and [we]2809-we 'll settle what land 's to be taken in , and [I]89-aaron 'll get up an hour earlier [i]89-aaron ' the morning , and begin on it . "[89-aaron] " But not if [you]2550-child do n't promise [me]146-eppie not to work at the hard digging , [father]2569-father , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie . " For [I]146-eppie should n't ha ' said anything about it , "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie added , half - bashfully half - roguishly , " only [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop said as [Aaron]89-aaron ' ud be so good , and — "[146-eppie] " And [you]2550-child might ha ' known it without [mother]189-mother telling [you]2550-child , "[89-aaron] said [Aaron]89-aaron . " And [Master Marner]42-master marner knows too , [I]89-aaron hope , as [I]89-aaron 'm able and willing to do a turn o ' work for [him]42-master marner , and [he]42-master marner wo n't do [me]89-aaron the unkindness to anyways take it out o ' [my]89-aaron hands . "[89-aaron] " There , now , [father]2569-father , [you]2569-father wo n't work in it till it 's all easy , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , " and [you]2569-father and [me]146-eppie can mark out the beds , and make holes and plant the roots . It 'll be a deal livelier at [the Stone - pits]658-the stone - pits when [we]2816-us 've got some flowers , for [I]146-eppie always think the flowers can see [us]2816-us and know what [we]2816-us 're talking about . And [I]146-eppie 'll have a bit o ' rosemary , and bergamot , and thyme , because they 're so sweet - smelling ; but there 's no lavender only in [[the gentlefolks]2817-the gentlefolks ' gardens]2818-the gentlefolks ' gardens , [I]146-eppie think . "[146-eppie] " That 's no reason why [you]2569-father should n't have some , "[89-aaron] said [Aaron]89-aaron , " for [I]89-aaron can bring [you]2569-father slips of anything ; [I]89-aaron 'm forced to cut no end of 'em when [I]89-aaron 'm gardening , and throw 'em away mostly . There 's a big bed o ' lavender at [the Red House]533-the red house : [the missis]2820-the missis is very fond of it . "[89-aaron] " Well , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , gravely , " so as [you]89-aaron do n't make free for [us]2816-us , or ask for anything as is worth much at [the Red House]533-the red house : for [Mr Cass]66-godfrey 's been so good to [us]2816-us , and built [us]2816-us up the new end o ' [the cottage]616-the cottage , and given [us]2816-us beds and things , as [I]38-silas could n't abide to be imposin ' for garden - stuff or anything else . "[38-silas] " No , no , there 's no imposin ' , "[89-aaron] said [Aaron]89-aaron ; " there 's never [a garden]2823-a garden in all [the parish]262-the parish but what there 's endless waste in [it]2823-a garden for want o ' [somebody]2086-somebody as could use everything up . It 's what [I]89-aaron think to [myself]89-aaron sometimes , as there need [nobody]444-nobody run short o ' victuals if [the land]553-the land was made the most on , and there was never a morsel but what could find its way to a mouth . It sets one thinking o ' that — gardening does . But [I]89-aaron must go back now , else [mother]189-mother ' ull be in trouble as [I]89-aaron are n't [there]2073-there . "[89-aaron] " Bring [her]189-mother with [you]89-aaron this afternoon , [Aaron]89-aaron , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie ; " [I]146-eppie should n't like to fix about [the garden]2830-the garden , and [her]189-mother not know everything from the first — should [you]89-aaron , [father]2569-father ? "[146-eppie] " Ay , bring [her]189-mother if [you]89-aaron can , [Aaron]89-aaron , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas ; " [she]189-mother 's sure to have a word to say as'll help [us]1738-us to set things on [their]2832-their right end . "[38-silas] [Aaron]89-aaron turned back up [the village]247-the village , while [Silas]38-silas and [Eppie]146-eppie went on up [the lonely sheltered lane]1737-the lonely sheltered lane . " O [daddy]2833-daddy ! "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie began , when [they]1738-us were in [privacy]1739-privacy , clasping and squeezing [Silas]38-silas 's arm , and skipping round to give [him]38-silas an energetic kiss . " [[My]146-eppie little old daddy]2834-my little old daddy ! [I]146-eppie 'm so glad . [I]146-eppie do n't think [I]146-eppie shall want anything else when [we]1738-us 've got [a little garden]2802-a little garden ; and [I]146-eppie knew [Aaron]89-aaron would dig [it]2802-a little garden for [us]1738-us , "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie went on with roguish triumph — " [I]146-eppie knew that very well . "[146-eppie] " [You]89-aaron 're [a deep little puss]2836-a deep little puss , [you]89-aaron are , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , with the mild passive happiness of love - crowned age in [his]38-silas face ; " but [you]89-aaron 'll make [yourself]89-aaron fine and beholden to [Aaron]89-aaron . "[38-silas] " O no , [I]146-eppie sha n't , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , laughing and frisking ; " [he]38-silas likes it . "[146-eppie] " Come , come , let [me]38-silas carry [your]89-aaron prayer - book , else [you]89-aaron 'll be dropping it , jumping [i]38-silas ' that way . "[38-silas] [Eppie]146-eppie was now aware that [her]146-eppie behaviour was under observation , but it was only the observation of a friendly donkey , browsing with a log fastened to [his]38-silas foot — a meek donkey , not scornfully critical of human trivialities , but thankful to share in them , if possible , by getting [his]38-silas nose scratched ; and [Eppie]146-eppie did not fail to gratify [him]38-silas with [her]146-eppie usual notice , though it was attended with the inconvenience of [his]38-silas following [them]1740-them , painfully , up to the very door of [[their]1740-them home]1741-their home . But the sound of a sharp bark inside , as [Eppie]146-eppie put the key in the door , modified [the donkey]1742-the donkey 's views , and [he]1742-the donkey limped away again without bidding . The sharp bark was the sign of an excited welcome that was awaiting [them]1740-them from a knowing brown terrier , who , after dancing at [their]1740-them legs in a hysterical manner , rushed with a worrying noise at a tortoise - shell kitten under the loom , and then rushed back with a sharp bark again , as much as to say , " [I]1743-the lady - mother of the kitten have done [my]1743-the lady - mother of the kitten duty by this feeble creature , [you]146-eppie perceive ; "[1743-the lady - mother of the kitten] while [the lady - mother of the kitten]1743-the lady - mother of the kitten sat sunning [her]1743-the lady - mother of the kitten white bosom in the window , and looked round with a sleepy air of expecting caresses , though [she]1743-the lady - mother of the kitten was not going to take any trouble for [them]1740-them . The presence of this happy animal life was not the only change which had come over [this interior of [the stone cottage]208-the stone cottage]1744-this interior of the stone cottage . There was no bed now in [the living - room]1746-the living - room , and [the small space]1747-the small space was well filled with decent furniture , all bright and clean enough to satisfy [Dolly Winthrop]113-dolly 's eye . The oaken table and three - cornered oaken chair were hardly what was likely to be seen in [so poor a cottage]1748-so poor a cottage : [they]1740-them had come , with the beds and other things , from [the Red House]533-the red house ; for [Mr Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey , as [every one]365-every one said in [the village]247-the village , did very kindly by [the weaver]209-the weaver ; and it was nothing but right [a man]185-a man should be looked on and helped by [those who could afford it]1754-those who could afford it , when [he]185-a man had brought up [an orphan child]1755-an orphan child , and been [father]2569-father and [mother]189-mother to [her]1755-an orphan child — and had lost [his]185-a man money too , so as [he]185-a man had nothing but what [he]185-a man worked for week by week , and when the weaving was going down too — for there was less and less flax spun — and [Master Marner]42-master marner was none so young . [Nobody]444-nobody was jealous of [the weaver]209-the weaver , for [he]209-the weaver was regarded as [an exceptional person , whose claims on neighbourly help]1760-an exceptional person , whose claims on neighbourly help were not to be matched in [Raveloe]1-raveloe . Any superstition that remained concerning [him]209-the weaver had taken an entirely new colour ; and [Mr Macey]41-mr macey , now [a very feeble old man of fourscore and six]1761-a very feeble old man of fourscore and six , never seen except in [his]41-mr macey chimney - corner or sitting in the sunshine at [his]41-mr macey door - sill , was of opinion that when [a man]185-a man had done what [Silas]38-silas had done by [an orphan child]1755-an orphan child , it was a sign that [his]38-silas money would come to light again , or leastwise that [the robber]734-the robber would be made to answer for it — for , as [Mr Macey]41-mr macey observed of [himself]41-mr macey , [his]41-mr macey faculties were as strong as ever . [Silas]38-silas sat down now and watched [Eppie]146-eppie with a satisfied gaze as [she]146-eppie spread the clean cloth , and set on it the potato - pie , warmed up slowly in a safe Sunday fashion , by being put into a dry pot over a slowly - dying fire , as the best substitute for an oven . For [Silas]38-silas would not consent to have a grate and oven added to [his]38-silas conveniences : [he]38-silas loved the old brick hearth as [he]38-silas had loved [his]38-silas brown pot — and was it not there when [he]38-silas had found [Eppie]146-eppie ? The gods of the hearth exist for [us]1765-us still ; and let all new faith be tolerant of that fetishism , lest it bruise its own roots . [Silas]38-silas ate [his]38-silas dinner more silently than usual , soon laying down [his]38-silas knife and fork , and watching half - abstractedly [Eppie]146-eppie 's play with Snap and the cat , by which [her]146-eppie own dining was made rather a lengthy business . Yet it was a sight that might well arrest wandering thoughts : [Eppie]146-eppie , with the rippling radiance of [her]146-eppie hair and the whiteness of [her]146-eppie rounded chin and throat set off by the dark - blue cotton gown , laughing merrily as the kitten held on with [her]146-eppie four claws to one shoulder , like a design for a jug - handle , while [Snap]153-snap on the right hand and [Puss]154-puss on the other put up [their]1766-them paws towards a morsel which [she]146-eppie held out of the reach of both — [Snap]153-snap occasionally desisting in order to remonstrate with the cat by a cogent worrying growl on the greediness and futility of [her]146-eppie conduct ; till [Eppie]146-eppie relented , caressed [them]1766-them both , and divided the morsel between [them]1766-them . But at last [Eppie]146-eppie , glancing at the clock , checked the play , and said , " O daddy , [you]38-silas 're wanting to go into the sunshine to smoke [your]38-silas pipe . But [I]146-eppie must clear away first , so as [the house]334-the house may be tidy when [godmother]2838-godmother comes . [I]146-eppie 'll make haste — [I]146-eppie wo n't be long . "[146-eppie] [Silas]38-silas had taken to smoking a pipe daily during the last two years , having been strongly urged to it by [the sages of [Raveloe]1-raveloe]1767-the sages of raveloe , as a practice " good for the fits ; "[146-eppie] and this advice was sanctioned by [Dr Kimble]155-dr kimble , on the ground that it was as well to try what could do no harm — a principle which was made to answer for a great deal of work in [that gentleman]1768-that gentleman 's medical practice . [Silas]38-silas did not highly enjoy smoking , and often wondered how [[his]38-silas neighbours]435-his neighbours could be so fond of it ; but a humble sort of acquiescence in what was held to be good , had become a strong habit of that new self which had been developed in [him]38-silas since [he]38-silas had found [Eppie]146-eppie on [his]38-silas hearth : it had been the only clue [his]38-silas bewildered mind could hold by in cherishing this young life that had been sent to [him]38-silas out of the darkness into which [his]38-silas gold had departed . By seeking what was needful for [Eppie]146-eppie , by sharing the effect that everything produced on [her]146-eppie , [he]38-silas had [himself]38-silas come to appropriate the forms of custom and belief which were the mould of [Raveloe]1-raveloe life ; and as , with reawakening sensibilities , memory also reawakened , [he]38-silas had begun to ponder over the elements of [his]38-silas old faith , and blend them with [his]38-silas new impressions , till [he]38-silas recovered a consciousness of unity between [his]38-silas past and present . The sense of presiding goodness and the human trust which come with all pure peace and joy , had given [him]38-silas a dim impression that there had been some error , some mistake , which had thrown that dark shadow over the days of [his]38-silas best years ; and as it grew more and more easy to [him]38-silas to open [his]38-silas mind to [Dolly Winthrop]113-dolly , [he]38-silas gradually communicated to [her]113-dolly all [he]38-silas could describe of [his]38-silas early life . The communication was necessarily a slow and difficult process , for [Silas]38-silas 's meagre power of explanation was not aided by any readiness of interpretation in [Dolly]113-dolly , whose narrow outward experience gave [her]113-dolly no key to strange customes , and made every novelty a source of wonder that arrested [them]1770-them at every step of the narrative . It was only by fragments , and at intervals which left [Dolly]113-dolly time to revolve what [she]113-dolly had heard till it acquired some familiarity for [her]113-dolly , that [Silas]38-silas at last arrived at the climax of the sad story — the drawing of lots , and its false testimony concerning [him]38-silas ; and this had to be repeated in several interviews , under new questions on [her]113-dolly part as to the nature of this plan for detecting [the guilty]1771-the guilty and clearing [the innocent]1772-the innocent . " And yourn 's the same Bible , [you]113-dolly 're sure o ' that , [Master Marner]42-master marner — the Bible as [you]113-dolly brought wi ' [you]113-dolly from [that country]2839-that country — it 's the same as what [they]1770-them 've got at [church]363-church , and what [Eppie]146-eppie 's a - learning to read in ? "[113-dolly] " Yes , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , " every bit the same ; and there 's drawing o ' lots in the Bible , mind [you]113-dolly , "[38-silas] [he]38-silas added , in a lower tone . " O dear , [dear]2767-dear , "[113-dolly] said [Dolly]113-dolly , in a grieved voice , as if [she]113-dolly were hearing an unfavourable report of [a sick man]1143-a sick man 's case . [She]113-dolly was silent for some minutes ; at last [she]113-dolly said — " There 's [wise folks]2842-wise folks , happen , as know how it all is ; [the parson]273-the parson knows , [I]113-dolly 'll be bound ; but it takes big words to tell [them]2842-wise folks things , and such as [poor folks]2844-poor folks ca n't make much out on . [I]113-dolly can never rightly know the meaning o ' what [I]113-dolly hear at [church]363-church , only a bit here and there , but [I]113-dolly know it 's good words — [I]113-dolly do . But what lies upo ' [your]113-dolly mind — it 's this , [Master Marner]42-master marner : as , if [Them]2846-them above had done the right thing by [you]113-dolly , [They]2846-them 'd never ha ' let [you]113-dolly be turned out for [a wicked thief]2847-a wicked thief when [you]113-dolly was innicent . "[113-dolly] " Ah ! "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , who had now come to understand [Dolly]113-dolly 's phraseology , " that was what fell on [me]38-silas like as if it had been red - hot iron ; because , [you]113-dolly see , there was [nobody as cared for [me]38-silas or clave to [me]38-silas above nor below]2848-nobody as cared for me or clave to me above nor below . And [him]2849-him as [I]38-silas 'd gone out and in wi ' for ten year and more , since when [we]2850-we was [lads]2851-lads and went halves — [[mine]38-silas own famil'ar friend]2852-mine own famil'ar friend , in whom [I]38-silas trusted , had lifted up [his]2852-mine own famil'ar friend heel again ' [me]38-silas , and worked to ruin [me]38-silas . "[38-silas] " Eh , but [he]2849-him was [a bad un]2551-a bad un — [I]113-dolly ca n't think as there 's another such , "[113-dolly] said [Dolly]113-dolly . " But [I]113-dolly 'm o'ercome , [Master Marner]42-master marner ; [I]113-dolly 'm like as if [I]113-dolly 'd waked and did n't know whether it was night or morning . [I]113-dolly feel somehow as sure as [I]113-dolly do when [I]113-dolly 've laid something up though [I]113-dolly ca n't justly put [my]113-dolly hand on it , as there was a right in what happened to [you]2854-you , if one could but make it out ; and [you]2854-you 'd no call to lose heart as [you]2854-you did . But [we]2855-we 'll talk on it again ; for sometimes things come into [my]113-dolly head when [I]113-dolly 'm leeching or poulticing , or such , as [I]113-dolly could never think on when [I]113-dolly was sitting still . "[113-dolly] [Dolly]113-dolly was too useful [a woman]2412-a woman not to have many opportunities of illumination of the kind [she]113-dolly alluded to , and [she]113-dolly was not long before [she]113-dolly recurred to the subject . " [Master Marner]42-master marner , "[113-dolly] [she]113-dolly said , one day that [she]113-dolly came to bring [home]374-home [Eppie]146-eppie 's washing , " [I]113-dolly 've been sore puzzled for a good bit wi ' that trouble o ' [yourn]2856-yourn and the drawing o ' lots ; and it got twisted back'ards and for'ards , as [I]113-dolly did n't know which end to lay hold on . But it come to [me]113-dolly all clear like , that night when [I]113-dolly was sitting up wi ' [poor Bessy Fawkes]156-poor bessy fawkes , as is dead and left [[her]156-poor bessy fawkes children]2857-her children behind , God help 'em — it come to [me]113-dolly as clear as daylight ; but whether [I]113-dolly 've got hold on it now , or can any - ways bring it to [my]113-dolly tongue 's end , that [I]113-dolly do n't know . For [I]113-dolly 've often a deal inside [me]113-dolly as 'll niver come out ; and for what [you]2858-you talk o ' [[your]2858-you folks]2859-your folks in [[your]2858-you old country]2860-your old country niver saying prayers by heart nor saying 'em out of a book , [they]2859-your folks must be wonderful cliver ; for if [I]113-dolly did n't know ' [[Our]2861-our Father]2862-our father , ' and little bits o ' good words as [I]113-dolly can carry out o ' church wi'me , [I]113-dolly might down o ' [my]113-dolly knees every night , but nothing could [I]113-dolly say . "[113-dolly] " But [you]2858-you can mostly say something as [I]38-silas can make sense on , [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas . " Well , then , [Master Marner]42-master marner , it come to [me]38-silas summat like this : [I]38-silas can make nothing o ' the drawing o ' lots and the answer coming wrong ; it ' ud mayhap take [the parson]273-the parson to tell that , and [he]273-the parson could only tell [us]2861-our [i]38-silas ' big words . But what come to [me]38-silas as clear as the daylight , it was when [I]38-silas was troubling over [poor Bessy Fawkes]156-poor bessy fawkes , and it allays comes into [my]38-silas head when [I]38-silas 'm sorry for [folks]214-folks , and feel as [I]38-silas ca n't do a power to help ['em]2865-'em , not if [I]38-silas was to get up [i]38-silas ' the middle o ' the night — it comes into [my]38-silas head as [Them]2866-them above has got a deal tenderer heart nor what [I]38-silas 've got — for [I]38-silas ca n't be anyways better nor [Them]2866-them as made [me]38-silas , and if anything looks hard to [me]38-silas , it 's because there 's things [I]38-silas do n't know on ; and for the matter o ' that , there may be plenty o ' things [I]38-silas do n't know on , for it 's little as [I]38-silas know — that it is . And so , while [I]38-silas was thinking o ' that , [you]2867-you come into [my]38-silas mind , [Master Marner]42-master marner , and it all come pouring in:—if [I]38-silas felt [i]38-silas ' [my]38-silas inside what was the right and just thing by [you]2867-you , and [them]2866-them as prayed and drawed the lots , all but that wicked un , if [they]2866-them 'd [ha]2868-ha ' done the right thing by [you]2867-you if [they]2866-them could , is n't there [Them]2866-them as was at the making on [us]2869-we , and knows better and has a better will ? And that 's all as ever [I]38-silas can be sure on , and everything else is a big puzzle to [me]38-silas when [I]38-silas think on it . For there was the fever come and took off [them]2866-them as were full - growed , and left [the helpless children]2765-the helpless children ; and there 's the breaking o ' limbs ; and [them]2866-them as ' ud do right and be sober have to suffer by [them]2866-them as are contrairy — eh , there 's trouble [i]38-silas ' [this world]2474-this world , and there 's things as [we]2869-we can niver make out the rights on . And all as [we]2869-we 've got to do is to trusten , [Master Marner]42-master marner — to do the right thing as fur as [we]2869-we know , and to trusten . For if [us]2869-we as knows so little can see a bit o ' good and rights , [we]2869-we may be sure as there 's a good and a rights bigger nor what [we]2869-we can know — [I]38-silas feel it [i]38-silas ' [my]38-silas own inside as it must be so . And if [you]42-master marner could but [ha]2872-ha ' gone on trustening , [Master Marner]42-master marner , [you]42-master marner would n't [ha]2872-ha ' run away from [[your]42-master marner fellow - creaturs]2873-your fellow - creaturs and been so lone . "[38-silas] " Ah , but that ' ud ha ' been hard , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , in an under - tone ; " it ' ud ha ' been hard to trusten then . "[38-silas] " And so it would , "[113-dolly] said [Dolly]113-dolly , almost with compunction ; " [them]2874-them things are easier said nor done ; and [I]113-dolly 'm partly ashamed o ' talking . "[113-dolly] " Nay , nay , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , " [you]42-master marner 're [i]38-silas ' the right , [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop — [you're]42-master marner [i]38-silas ' the right . There 's good [i]38-silas ' [this world]2474-this world — [I've]38-silas a feeling o ' that now ; and it makes [a man]185-a man feel as there 's a good more nor [he]185-a man can see , [i]38-silas ' spite o ' the trouble and the wickedness . That drawing o ' [the lots]362-the lots is dark ; but [the child]451-the child was sent to [me]38-silas : there 's dealings with [us]2879-us — there 's dealings . "[38-silas] This dialogue took place in [Eppie]146-eppie 's earlier years , when [Silas]38-silas had to part with [her]146-eppie for two hours every day , that [she]146-eppie might learn to read at [the dame school]1776-the dame school , after [he]38-silas had vainly tried [himself]38-silas to guide [her]146-eppie in that first step to learning . Now that [she]146-eppie was grown up , [Silas]38-silas had often been led , in those moments of quiet outpouring which come to [people who live together in perfect love]1777-people who live together in perfect love , to talk with [her]146-eppie too of the past , and how and why [he]38-silas had lived [a lonely man]1778-a lonely man until [she]146-eppie had been sent to [him]38-silas . For it would have been impossible for [him]38-silas to hide from [Eppie]146-eppie that [she]146-eppie was not [[his]38-silas own child]1502-his own child : even if the most delicate reticence on the point could have been expected from [Raveloe]1-raveloe gossips in [her]146-eppie presence , [her]146-eppie own questions about [[her]146-eppie mother]2585-her mother could not have been parried , as [she]146-eppie grew up , without that complete shrouding of the past which would have made a painful barrier between [their]1781-their minds . So [Eppie]146-eppie had long known how [[her]146-eppie mother]2585-her mother had died on the snowy ground , and how [she]146-eppie [herself]146-eppie had been found on the hearth by [father Silas]38-silas , who had taken [her]146-eppie golden curls for [his]38-silas lost guineas brought back to [him]38-silas . The tender and peculiar love with which [Silas]38-silas had reared [her]146-eppie in almost inseparable companionship with [himself]38-silas , aided by the seclusion of [[their]1781-their dwelling]1783-their dwelling , had preserved [her]146-eppie from the lowering influences of the village talk and habits , and had kept [her]146-eppie mind in that freshness which is sometimes falsely supposed to be an invariable attribute of rusticity . Perfect love has a breath of poetry which can exalt the relations of [the least instructed human beings]1784-the least instructed human beings ; and this breath of poetry had surrounded [Eppie]146-eppie from the time when [she]146-eppie had followed the bright gleam that beckoned [her]146-eppie to [[Silas]38-silas 's hearth]1785-silas 's hearth ; so that it is not surprising if , in other things besides [her]146-eppie delicate prettiness , [she]146-eppie was not quite [a common village maiden]1786-a common village maiden , but had a touch of refinement and fervour which came from no other teaching than that of tenderly - nurtured unvitiated feeling . [She]146-eppie was too childish and simple for [her]146-eppie imagination to rove into questions about [[her]146-eppie unknown father]1787-her unknown father ; for a long while it did not even occur to [her]146-eppie that [she]146-eppie must have had [a father]1788-a father ; and the first time that the idea of [[her]146-eppie mother]2585-her mother having had [a husband]1790-a husband presented itself to [her]146-eppie , was when [Silas]38-silas showed [her]146-eppie the wedding - ring which had been taken from the wasted finger , and had been carefully preserved by [him]38-silas in a little lackered box shaped like a shoe . [He]38-silas delivered this box into [Eppie]146-eppie 's charge when [she]146-eppie had grown up , and [she]146-eppie often opened it to look at the ring ; but still [she]146-eppie thought hardly at all about [the father of whom it was the symbol]1791-the father of whom it was the symbol . Had [she]146-eppie not [a father very close to [her]146-eppie , who loved [her]146-eppie better than [any real fathers in [the village]247-the village]1793-any real fathers in the village seemed to love [[their]1793-any real fathers in the village daughters]1795-their daughters ? On the contrary , who [[her]146-eppie mother]2585-her mother was , and how [she]146-eppie came to die in that forlornness]1792-a father very close to her , who loved her better than any real fathers in the village seemed to love their daughters ? on the contrary , who her mother was , and how she came to die in that forlornness , were questions that often pressed on [Eppie]146-eppie 's mind . [Her]146-eppie knowledge of [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop , who was [[her]146-eppie nearest friend next to [Silas]38-silas]1797-her nearest friend next to silas , made [her]146-eppie feel that [a mother]1798-a mother must be very precious ; and [she]146-eppie had again and again asked [Silas]38-silas to tell [her]146-eppie how [[her]146-eppie mother]2585-her mother looked , whom [she]2585-her mother was like , and how [he]38-silas had found [her]2585-her mother against the furze bush , led towards it by the little footsteps and the outstretched arms . The furze bush was there still ; and this afternoon , when [Eppie]146-eppie came out with [Silas]38-silas into the sunshine , it was the first object that arrested [her]146-eppie eyes and thoughts . " [Father]157-father , "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie said , in a tone of gentle gravity , which sometimes came like a sadder , slower cadence across [her]146-eppie playfulness , " [we]2880-we shall take the furze bush into [the garden]2830-the garden ; it 'll come into the corner , and just against it [I]146-eppie 'll put snowdrops and crocuses,'cause [Aaron]89-aaron says they wo n't die out , but 'll always get more and more . "[146-eppie] " Ah , [child]2550-child , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , always ready to talk when [he]38-silas had [his]38-silas pipe in [his]38-silas hand , apparently enjoying the pauses more than the puffs , " it would n't do to leave out the furze bush ; and there 's nothing prettier , to [my]146-eppie thinking , when it 's yallow with flowers . But it 's just come into [my]146-eppie head what [we]2880-we 're to do for a fence — mayhap [Aaron]89-aaron can help [us]2880-we to a thought ; but a fence [we]2880-we must have , else the donkeys and things ' ull come and trample everything down . And fencing 's hard to be got at , by what [I]146-eppie can make out . "[146-eppie] " O , [I]146-eppie 'll tell [you]38-silas , [daddy]2833-daddy , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , clasping [her]146-eppie hands suddenly , after a minute 's thought . " There 's lots o ' loose stones about , some of 'em not big , and [we]2880-we might lay 'em atop of one another and make a wall . [You]38-silas and [me]146-eppie could carry the smallest , and [Aaron]89-aaron ' ud carry the rest — [I]146-eppie know [he]89-aaron would . "[146-eppie] " Eh , [[my]38-silas precious un]2884-my precious un , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , " there is n't enough stones to go all round ; and as for [you]2884-my precious un carrying , why , wi ' [your]2884-my precious un little arms [you]2884-my precious un could n't carry a stone no bigger than a turnip . [You]2884-my precious un 're dillicate made , [[my]38-silas dear]2469-my dear "[38-silas] [he]38-silas added , with a tender intonation—"that 's what [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop says . "[146-eppie] " O , [I]146-eppie 'm stronger than [you]38-silas think , [daddy]2833-daddy , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie ; " and if there was n't stones enough to go all round , why they 'll go part o ' the way , and then it 'll be easier to get sticks and things for the rest . See here , round [the big pit]2887-the big pit , what a many stones ! "[146-eppie] [She]146-eppie skipped forward to [the pit]1800-the pit , meaning to lift one of the stones and exhibit [her]146-eppie strength , but [she]146-eppie started back in surprise . " O , [father]2569-father , just come and look here , "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie exclaimed—"come and see how the water 's gone down since yesterday . Why , yesterday [the pit]1800-the pit was ever so full ! "[146-eppie] " Well , to be sure , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , coming to [her]146-eppie side . " Why , that 's the draining [they]2890-they 've begun on , since harvest , [i]38-silas ' [[Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood 's fields]2891-mr osgood 's fields , [I]38-silas reckon . [The foreman]2892-the foreman said to [me]38-silas the other day , when [I]38-silas passed by 'em , ' [Master Marner]42-master marner , ' [he]2892-the foreman said , ' [I]38-silas should n't wonder if [we]2893-we lay [your]42-master marner bit o ' waste as dry as a bone . ' It was [Mr Godfrey Cass]66-godfrey , [he]66-godfrey said , had gone into the draining : [he]66-godfrey 'd been taking [these fields o ' [Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood]2894-these fields o ' mr osgood . "[38-silas] " How odd it 'll seem to have [the old pit]2895-the old pit dried up , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , turning away , and stooping to lift rather a large stone . " See , [daddy]2833-daddy , [I]146-eppie can carry this quite well , "[146-eppie] [she]146-eppie said , going along with much energy for a few steps , but presently letting it fall . " Ah , [you]146-eppie 're fine and strong , arn't [you]146-eppie ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , while [Eppie]146-eppie shook [her]146-eppie aching arms and laughed . " Come , come , let [us]2893-we go and sit down on the bank against the stile there , and have no more lifting . [You]146-eppie might hurt [yourself]146-eppie , [child]2550-child . [You]146-eppie 'd need have [somebody]2086-somebody to work for [you]146-eppie — and [my]38-silas arm is n't over strong . "[38-silas] [Silas]38-silas uttered the last sentence slowly , as if it implied more than met the ear ; and [Eppie]146-eppie , when [they]1801-they sat down on [the bank]1802-the bank , nestled close to [his]38-silas side , and , taking hold caressingly of the arm that was not over strong , held it on [her]146-eppie lap , while [Silas]38-silas puffed again dutifully at the pipe , which occupied [his]38-silas other arm . An ash in the hedgerow behind made a fretted screen from the sun , and threw happy playful shadows all about [them]1801-they . " [Father]157-father , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , very gently , after [they]1801-they had been sitting in silence a little while , " if [I]146-eppie was to be married , ought [I]146-eppie to be married with [[my]146-eppie mother]2776-my mother 's ring ? "[146-eppie] [Silas]38-silas gave an almost imperceptible start , though the question fell in with the under current of thought in [his]38-silas own mind , and then said , in a subdued tone , " Why , [Eppie]146-eppie , have [you]146-eppie been a - thinking on it ? "[38-silas] " Only this last week , [father]2569-father , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , ingenuously , " since [Aaron]89-aaron talked to [me]146-eppie about it . "[146-eppie] " And what did [he]89-aaron say ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , still in the same subdued way , as if [he]38-silas were anxious lest [he]38-silas should fall into the slightest tone that was not for [Eppie]146-eppie 's good . " [He]89-aaron said [he]89-aaron should like to be married , because [he]89-aaron was a - going in four - and - twenty , and had got a deal of gardening work , now [Mr Mott]158-mr mott 's given up ; and [he]89-aaron goes twice a - week regular to [Mr Cass]66-godfrey 's , and once to [Mr Osgood]59-mr osgood 's , and [they]2901-they 're going to take [him]89-aaron on at [the Rectory]237-the rectory . "[38-silas] " And who is it as [he]89-aaron 's wanting to marry ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , with rather a sad smile . " Why , [me]146-eppie , to be sure , [daddy]2833-daddy , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , with dimpling laughter , kissing [[her]146-eppie father]1190-her father 's cheek ; " as if [he]89-aaron 'd want to marry [anybody else]2312-anybody else ! "[146-eppie] " And [you]146-eppie mean to have [him]89-aaron , do [you]146-eppie ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas . " Yes , some time , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , " [I]146-eppie do n't know when . [Everybody]446-everybody 's married some time , [Aaron]89-aaron says . But [I]146-eppie told [him]89-aaron that was n't true : for , [I]146-eppie said , look at [father]2569-father — [he]89-aaron 's never been married . "[146-eppie] " No , [child]2550-child , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , " [[your]2550-child father]2520-your father was [a lone man]2481-a lone man till [you]2550-child was sent to [him]2520-your father . "[38-silas] " But [you]2569-father 'll never be lone again , [father]2569-father , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , tenderly . " That was what [Aaron]89-aaron said — ' [I]146-eppie could never think o ' taking [you]2550-child away from [Master Marner]42-master marner , [Eppie]146-eppie . ' And [I]146-eppie said , ' It ' ud be no use if [you]89-aaron did , [Aaron]89-aaron . ' And [he]89-aaron wants [us]2911-us all to live together , so as [you]2569-father need n't work a bit , [father]2569-father , only what 's for [your]2569-father own pleasure ; and [he]89-aaron 'd be as good as [a son]2225-a son to [you]2569-father — that was what [he]89-aaron said . "[146-eppie] " And should [you]1804-you like that , [Eppie]146-eppie ? "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , looking at [her]1804-you . " [I]146-eppie should n't mind it , [father]2569-father , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , quite simply . " And [I]146-eppie should like things to be so as [you]2569-father need n't work much . But if it was n't for that , [I]146-eppie 'd sooner things did n't change . [I]146-eppie 'm very happy : [I]146-eppie like [Aaron]89-aaron to be fond of [me]146-eppie , and come and see [us]2915-we often , and behave pretty to [you]2569-father — [he]89-aaron always does behave pretty to [you]2569-father , does n't [he]89-aaron , [father]2569-father ? "[146-eppie] " Yes , [child]2550-child , [nobody]444-nobody could behave better , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , emphatically . " [He]89-aaron 's [[his]89-aaron mother]301-his mother 's lad . "[38-silas] " But [I]146-eppie do n't want any change , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie . " [I]146-eppie should like to go on a long , long while , just as [we]2915-we are . Only [Aaron]89-aaron does want a change ; and [he]89-aaron made [me]146-eppie cry a bit — only a bit — because [he]89-aaron said [I]146-eppie did n't care for [him]89-aaron , for if [I]146-eppie cared for [him]89-aaron [I]146-eppie should want [us]2915-we to be married , as [he]89-aaron did . "[146-eppie] " Eh , [[my]38-silas blessed child]2920-my blessed child , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , laying down [his]38-silas pipe as if it were useless to pretend to smoke any longer , " [you]2920-my blessed child 're o'er young to be married . [We]2915-we 'll ask [Mrs Winthrop]111-mrs winthrop — [we'll]2915-we ask [[Aaron]89-aaron 's mother]2921-aaron 's mother what [she]2921-aaron 's mother thinks : if there 's a right thing to do , [she]2921-aaron 's mother 'll come at it . But there 's this to be thought on , [Eppie]146-eppie : things will change , whether [we]2915-we like it or not ; things wo n't go on for a long while just as they are and no difference . [I]38-silas shall get older and helplesser , and be a burden on [you]146-eppie , belike , if [I]38-silas do n't go away from [you]146-eppie altogether . Not as [I]38-silas mean [you]146-eppie 'd think [me]38-silas a burden — [I]38-silas know [you]146-eppie wouldn't — but it ' ud be hard upon [you]146-eppie ; and when [I]38-silas look for'ard to that , [I]38-silas like to think as [you]146-eppie 'd have [somebody else besides [me]38-silas]2922-somebody else besides me — somebody young and strong , as 'll outlast [your]146-eppie own life , and take care on [you]146-eppie to the end . "[38-silas] [Silas]38-silas paused , and , resting [his]38-silas wrists on [his]38-silas knees , lifted [his]38-silas hands up and down meditatively as [he]38-silas looked on the ground . " Then , would [you]38-silas like [me]146-eppie to be married , [father]2569-father ? "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , with a little trembling in [her]146-eppie voice . " [I]38-silas 'll not be [the man]731-the man to say no , [Eppie]146-eppie , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , emphatically ; " but [we]2925-we 'll ask [[your]146-eppie god - mother]2926-your god - mother . [She]2926-your god - mother 'll wish the right thing by [you]146-eppie and [[her]2926-your god - mother son]2927-her son too . "[38-silas] " There [they]2928-they come then , "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie . " Let [us]2925-we go and meet ['em]2929-'em . O the pipe ! wo n't [you]38-silas have it lit again , [father]2569-father ? "[146-eppie] said [Eppie]146-eppie , lifting that medicinal appliance from the ground . " Nay , [child]2550-child , "[38-silas] said [Silas]38-silas , " [I]38-silas 've done enough for to - day . [I]38-silas think , mayhap , a little of it does [me]38-silas more good than so much at once . "[38-silas] While [Silas]38-silas and [Eppie]146-eppie were seated on the bank discoursing in the fleckered shade of the ash tree , [Miss Priscilla Lammeter]80-priscilla was resisting [[her]80-priscilla sister]1188-her sister 's arguments , that it would be better to stay tea at [the Red House]533-the red house , and let [[her]80-priscilla father]1190-her father have a long nap , than drive [home]374-home to [the Warrens]17-the warrens so soon after dinner . [The family party ( of four only )]1809-the family party ( of four only ) were seated round the table in [the dark wainscoted parlour]566-the dark wainscoted parlour , with the Sunday dessert before [them]1809-the family party ( of four only ) , of fresh filberts , apples , and pears , duly ornamented with leaves by [Nancy]67-nancy 's own hand before the bells had rung for [church]363-church . A great change has come over [the dark wainscoted parlour]566-the dark wainscoted parlour since [we]1813-we saw it in [Godfrey]66-godfrey 's bachelor days , and under the wifeless reign of [the old Squire]564-the old squire . Now all is polish , on which no yesterday 's dust is ever allowed to settle , from [the yard]1815-the yard 's width of oaken boards round the carpet , to the old Squire 's gun and whips and walking - sticks , ranged on the stag 's antlers above the mantelpiece . All other signs of sporting and outdoor occupation [Nancy]67-nancy has removed to [another room]1816-another room ; but [she]67-nancy has brought into [the Red House]533-the red house the habit of filial reverence , and preserves sacredly in a place of honour these relics of [[her]67-nancy husband 's departed father]1818-her husband 's departed father . The tankards are on the side - table still , but the bossed silver is undimmed by handling , and there are no dregs to send forth unpleasant suggestions : the only prevailing scent is of the lavender and rose - leaves that fill the vases of Derbyshire spar . All is purity and order in [this once dreary room]1819-this once dreary room , for , fifteen years ago , [it]1819-this once dreary room was entered by [a new presiding spirit]1820-a new presiding spirit . " Now , [father]2569-father , "[67-nancy] said [Nancy]67-nancy , " is there any call for [you]2569-father to go [home]374-home to tea ? May n't [you]2569-father just as well stay with us?—such a beautiful evening as it 's likely to be . "[67-nancy] [The old gentleman]2132-the old gentleman had been talking with [Godfrey]66-godfrey about the increasing poor - rate and the ruinous times , and had not heard the dialogue between [[his]2132-the old gentleman daughters]1822-his daughters . " [[My]2132-the old gentleman dear]2469-my dear , [you]2469-my dear must ask [Priscilla]80-priscilla , "[2132-the old gentleman] [he]2132-the old gentleman said , in the once firm voice , now become rather broken . " [She]80-priscilla manages [me]2132-the old gentleman and [the farm]2935-the farm too . "[2132-the old gentleman] " And reason good as [I]80-priscilla should manage [you]2569-father , [father]2569-father , "[80-priscilla] said [Priscilla]80-priscilla , " else [you]2569-father 'd be giving [yourself]2569-father [your]2569-father death with rheumatism . And as for [the farm]2935-the farm , if anything turns out wrong , as it ca n't but do in these times , there 's nothing kills [a man]185-a man so soon as having [nobody]444-nobody to find fault with but [himself]185-a man . It 's a deal the best way o ' being [master]2433-master , to let [somebody else]739-somebody else do the ordering , and keep the blaming in [your]2569-father own hands . It'ud save [many a man]2942-many a man a stroke , [I]80-priscilla believe . "[1190-her father] " Then manage so as [you]2469-my dear may stay tea , [Priscilla]80-priscilla , "[67-nancy] said [Nancy]67-nancy , putting [her]67-nancy hand on [[her]67-nancy sister]1188-her sister 's arm affectionately . " Come now ; and [we]2945-we 'll go round [the garden]2830-the garden while [father]2569-father has [his]2569-father nap . "[67-nancy] " [[My]1190-her father dear child]2948-my dear child , [he]2569-father 'll have a beautiful nap in the gig , for [I]1190-her father shall drive . And as for staying tea , [I]1190-her father ca n't hear of it ; for there 's [this dairy - maid]2949-this dairy - maid , now [she]2949-this dairy - maid knows [she]2949-this dairy - maid 's to be married , turned [Michaelmas]159-michaelmas , [she]2949-this dairy - maid 'd as lieve pour the new milk into the pig - trough as into the pans . "[1190-her father] When [the sisters]1399-the sisters were treading the neatly - swept garden - walks , between the bright turf that contrasted pleasantly with the dark cones and arches and wall - like hedges of yew , [Priscilla]80-priscilla said — " [I]80-priscilla 'm as glad as anything at [[your]2948-my dear child husband]2567-your husband 's making that exchange o ' land with [cousin Osgood]59-mr osgood , and beginning the dairying . It 's a thousand pities [you]2948-my dear child did n't do it before ; for it 'll give [you]2948-my dear child something to fill [your]2948-my dear child mind . There 's nothing like a dairy if [folks]214-folks want a bit o ' worrit to make the days pass . For as for rubbing furniture , when [you]2948-my dear child can once see [your]2948-my dear child face in a table there 's nothing else to look for ; but there 's always something fresh with the dairy ; for even in the depths o ' winter there 's some pleasure in conquering the butter , and making it come whether or no . "[67-nancy] " It drives [me]80-priscilla past patience , "[80-priscilla] said [Priscilla]80-priscilla , impetuously , " that way o ' [the men]2536-the men — always wanting and wanting , and never easy with what [they]2536-the men 've got : [they]2536-the men ca n't sit comfortable in [their]2536-the men chairs when [they]2536-the men 've neither ache nor pain , but either [they]2536-the men must stick a pipe in [their]2536-the men mouths , to make ['em]2958-'em better than well , or else [they]2536-the men must be swallowing something strong , though [they]2536-the men 're forced to make haste before the next meal comes in . "[80-priscilla] " O do n't say so , [Priscilla]80-priscilla , "[67-nancy] said [Nancy]67-nancy , repenting that [she]67-nancy had called forth this outburst ; " [nobody]444-nobody has any occasion to find fault with [Godfrey]66-godfrey . "[80-priscilla] The large gig with [the steady old grey]1828-the steady old grey was at the front door , and [Mr Lammeter]81-mr lammeter was already on the stone steps , passing the time in recalling to [Godfrey]66-godfrey what very fine points [Speckle]160-speckle had when [[his]160-speckle master]1829-his master used to ride [him]160-speckle .
